My first 500 hours in Slay the Spire were hours I didn't pay for. 

I was a kid in highschool, broke, there was only 3 characters in the game, Vine was alive and Tiktok had yet to really get a foothold in the world. It was a better time.

And I... sailed the seas. Its not something I'm ashamed of, and if you are down on your luck, still a kid, or just don't feel like jockeying the Steam refund policy to see if you like a game, most game devs would prefer thats how you play their game over buying a copy of dubious origin from a reseller. 

Why even bring this up, you might ask? Well, it was only last year that I realized how much had gone into the game, and that there was a 4th character that I had no clue even existed. And, against my better judgement with regards to my ever disappearing free time, I picked up STS again to try that 4th character. And then I started playing the other characters too. And then I started ascension runs. 

Never in all my days have I encountered such a well crafted deckbuilder. Being singleplayer, STS doesn't care if you find a combo that breaks the game and makes the enemy unable to interact with you. Slay the Spire doesn't try and limit your ceiling, it dares you to go infinite, it [i] wants [/i] you to go infinite. My favorite part of the game is how it encourages offense while putting more than enough wrinkles in your path that you can't just go full zerg rush. Fully indexing into any one thing without accounting for the counters puts you on the path to losing. 

Learning the Watcher, the illusive 4th character I didn't know existed as it got added after I put my 500 [strike] pirated [/strike] pre-purchase hours in has been one of the most enjoyable deckbuilding experiences I've had since... well since I played STS the first time. 

The main thing I was trying to do on the Watcher that was so fun was going infinite. There was a really interesting play pattern you can take where you reset a lot and chop your deck down to like 3 powers and then your 2 card combo that goes until you win. The fun part is that by taking your deck down to so few cards, any enemy that adds cards to your deck in any way is immediately the most threatening thing you could encounter. You also have to make illogical decisions in order to get to infinite. You skip like 90% of cards you are offered, you make sacrifices for some things that would never make sense in a normal run. And that is just ONE way to play the game on one character, completely ignoring everything that comes with ascension runs. 

And all of that is also completely ignoring everything that isn't purely gameplay. The art is amazing, the soundtrack is amazing, the sound DESIGN is amazing, and there has never been a better time to get into Slay the Spire because there is a sequel that looks like its amping up everything about the first game and giving more of what is undeniably one of the grandpappys of indie roguelikes. That would've been a silly statement 10 years ago, but there are so many indie roguelikes now that it can be hard to stand out among them. 

Slay the Spire has stood the test of time and remains at the top of the tower. Play this game, and if you can, uh, pay for it while you're at it... I did. Eventually.

[h2][b]This review is not 100% positivel!!![/b][/h2]

If played solo, this game quickly becomes boring, in my opinion. However, when played with friends, the experience changes completely and becomes much more fun.

Unfortunately, during my multiplayer experience with friends, I encountered several bugs that made the gameplay frustrating at times. As I usually try to platinum my games, obtaining all achievements is essential for me. However, with Raft, the multiplayer experience was far from satisfactory. While two of my friends were able to unlock achievements without any issues, I, on the other hand, could barely unlock any, even though I was always with them. This forced me to create a single-player world and replay a large portion of the story, including defeating some bosses alone again...

This was the issue that bothered me the most, but it wasnâ€™t the only one. Many times, when trying to collect loot, I simply couldnâ€™t. Sometimes, the interaction option didnâ€™t appear; other times, even when the option was available, clicking on it didnâ€™t do anything.

One of the coolest games on steam in my opinion. It is a shame it is so dead. I haven't played in a while so I am unsure if the servers are even still up. BRING BACK QUANTUM LEAGUE BUT FOR FREE!!!!! REVIVE THE PLAYER BASE!!!!

Logged 300+ hours into this game on Xbox, absolutely fantastic game! Decided to buy on PC for the bit of DLC that isn't available on xbox.

Artwork and soundtrack are very engaging and create an epic experience. Not many roguelikes keep me entertained for more than 20 hours so this game is truly solid!

Character dialogues and banter have a cynical humor to them, which fits the theme of a never-ending quest to stop the interdimensional swarm.

Only three things I wish were different:
1. that the progeny were a bit more unique compared to there progenitors in stats and abilities
2. the planets and their respective behemoths could be fought in varying order rather than only fighting specific enemies/behemoths at planets 1, 2, and 3.
3. more things to spend meta-currency on!

Entropy IV and V were the real challenge and found I could only beat them with specific team setups.

Overall great game with massive replayability. The devs truly made this game with passion!

Highly recommend!!!! | I love this game. Great challenge. Great music. Great visuals.

I do wish they had been willing to go more serious with it. The intro video and other things set a far more serious tone than the game ever ends up having. Also, you can hurt your odds by unlocking the wrong stuff, though there are systems to cut down on the negative consequences of having a larger item pull, the fewer things you can unlock in the realm of equipment, the more predictable your pool of options will be. | I've got 100% achievements in this game and i can say that this is a WONDERFUL piece of art.

Visuals and Sounds aside.... The gamepley is extremelly well made. Game can be ruthless and you can't comit any mistakes when playing in the final difficulties and to me, that's what made the game SO good.
Every battle is pretty much like a chess game and you REALLY need to think, rethink, think again. The strategy factor is VERY SMART and you need to UNDERSTAND how the game REALLY works to be good at it.

Choosing the better route, knowing when to take risks and LEARNING how to properly build your team is CRUCIAL to success. If you enjoy HARD ROGUELIKES with SCI-FI atmosphere. Pick this.

10/10 game. | This game has been a blast for to play the last few months. The roguelike formula mixed with the turn based RPG mechanics comes together well, and utilizing delays to control the flow of combat and get your team an advantage rewards foresight and planning. | Great little turn based game, eats time like crazy. Fun, challenging a little frustrating but often rewarding.

I love how it looks. But it's not an amazing game either. Half baked. There's nothing that is missing from a minimal viable product, but it is quite minimal. 

I kinda got used to early access type games, so I was hoping for updates. Scoured the internet for an answer of "if we get updates". And found the devs to be incredibly dismissive. "Game didn't sell well, so no. No more updates." Which is a perfectly reasonable internal thought to have, but is a nightmare PR move. I don't trust these devs, I will never buy anything from them ever again.

And ofc, I cannot recommend this game. Just get a game that the devs care about instead. Both you and them will feel better about it.

I love the Door Kickers series, but I refuse to buy it at its current price or whatever sale the devs set it to (smh, it's still expensive). So when I saw this retro swat team Door Kickers game, I instantly bought it. It's repetitive, but you honestly get a good deal for the price. It reminds me of Rainbow Six Siege (minus the goofy lore), as it draws a lot of parallels to the series with its setting and tone. My favourite character would have to be Off-Duty Guy, as I almost have him maxed out, but every time I come off of him, I'm quickly reminded how bad I am at the game. Jokes aside, I've been having a ton of fun with his game; it's also very similar to a game called Police Stories, as they're both 2D retro police RPG shooters, with one being a side-view shooter and the other a top-down shooter. All in all, great game, been enjoying it on my Steam Deck and I can't wait to try the co-op if my brother picks it up.

Hellblade feels like deep depression. Amazing story and world. The sound design is especially very good, I see why it won awards for it. I like that it is also not too long. 

Don't use DirectX 12, way too much stutter. I have RTX 4080 Super and the stuttering was too annoying. Use DirectX 11 for a smoother experience. Game still looks amazing on DirectX 11 | Was a cool experience, gorgeous game! The cinematics and audio design was top notch for sure! | Hellblade is a truly captivating game, edging close to being a masterpiece of artistic gaming. Its tone is somber, tackling a deeply sensitive topic with the use of metaphors and visual intricacies to emphasize its message.

The gameâ€™s visuals are breathtaking, with lush environments that contrast with the desolate landscapes that accompany you throughout your journey. The facial animations are flawless, and the lead actress, while not fitting the typical beauty standard, feels like a genuinely real person. Her performance is outstanding, capturing the anguish and torment of her character. The voice acting is equally exceptional, with a chorus of voices constantly surrounding you, enhancing the feeling of mental distress. These voices serve not just as a representation of psychosis but as your in-game guide, providing directions during traversal and combat. Without a HUD, the voices act as your compass and even warn of incoming attacks, making them an essential part of the experience.

Sound is more integral here than in any other game Iâ€™ve playedâ€”at times, your hearing takes precedence over your sight, with auditory cues playing a major role in gameplay.

The movement can feel slow, especially during traversal, where running feels more like a light jog. The game is linear, which for me, isnâ€™t a drawback. The story is engaging, and the performances are superb, with Druth standing out as a highlight. His tales of Norse mythology, told whenever Senua uncovers a rune, are worth experiencing in themselves. Man those Vikings must have been smoking something strong when they came up with those myths!

Though the gameplay can become repetitive, and the combat is average, Hellblade is far more than a game about mechanics. Itâ€™s an artistic experience, and I highly recommend giving it a try. | Historia muito boa e o sistema de combate entÃ£o excelente, nÃ£o sou fÃ£ de puzzle mais esse jogo tem um puzzle fÃ¡cil nÃ£o precisa pensar muito pra progredir nos capÃ­tulos. Recomendo | I really don't know where to start with this one.

I really enjoyed how enthralling the story was, and how indepth they actually researched mental illness. It was just simply breath taking in places and really immersive in the environment.

Some of the areas were out right kinda scary, not going to lie. It kinda felt like you were experiencing the fear she was. The voices definately added so much personality and the way the story was narrated was also amazing. I will also admit, that the voices could be trippy sometimes, but helpful othertimes.

I really cant get enough of ranting about it, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

The clean visuals and relaxing music contrast with the intense Viking invasions.Easy to learn but challenging to master, itâ€™s a must play for strategy fans! | I have completed the game twice on normal and hard difficulty. The game is minimalistic as you must have seen but I feel this also becomes one of its weakness. I had fun playing this game and here are some point I would like to highlight about the game:

-> Always keep "Allow level restart" active otherwise 1 mistake can destroy hefty progress, sometime it will be the fighter AI mistake and not even yours.
-> This game could have had a better Codex or an info panel current one is not that good (some flash games have better codex that this).
-> Even though the game may look minimalistic and easy to play it is not, if you are planning to complete the game that is. Once you are in the latter half of the game you will need to use the skills to make meaningful progress which is not bad in itself but because how the game is designed most waves of enemies board the island at the exact same time so will have to use skills to ambush them at the same time which is very hard in practice, max I could do successfully was 2.
-> BRUTE ARCHERS !!! Hate these guys, they have arrow and force comparable to ballista while being wielded by one of the highest HP enemy, have the maximum range than any other troop even hugely more than our own max archers, so much so that you would be busy in a fight and their arrow will come like a sniper shot and decimate your helpless troops. On top of all that there is no commander you can have that will properly counter them, shield-men comes as the best answer for them but even they can sometime die to their arrow idk how.
-> Game AI or basically the targeting and fighting of the enemy and friendly troops, its doesn't work that well, especially when against enemy ranged troops. Your melee troops will just stand and die even if the enemy is less than 1 tile away, while shield-men are very homing which sometimes results in them breaking your formation.
-> After these 2 play-throughs on both difficulty I don't feel like playing the game again, so not very replayable. There isnt a lot of combinations or creative and fun ways to play this game because of the limitation of only 3 types of troops and every enemy only having a specific troop to counter them.

Even though I have highlighted mostly negative point I still had fun playing this game, its just that some problems have very obvious solution which could have been implemented or kept when making the game from ground up.

Very hard not to recommend this game. Great art style and some story behind, but core gameplay is a bit odd for a metroidvania. Enemies will randomly spawn instead of fixed position, so at times you will be running around with not much to do (which is a bit slow for my taste); while sometimes many enemies will swarm your screen so you are forced to fight them (which is not bad but can get annoying at endgame). Combat is a bit simple and spammy, movement is a bit janky and slow.

 Overall not a bad game, but a bit weird to be a metroidvania. A good small game about fighting your friends in one of the three arenas where the floor falls off, using the powers of 4 different characters.
Up to four, local and online but never tried online, there is also a mode in which you can fi ght a horde of monsters alone or with friends in the same arenas, but it's not too great.

My girlfriend's favorite MP fighting game, maybe because there's a hint of chance so it's not only skill vs skill.

Great idea, and great mechanics. It has really good/fitting graphics.
The soundtrack and writing both range from good to awesome.
But I think the design and balance are just not fun in the end, and that's not something you can avoid.

First of all, and most importantly: the amount of mindless clicking you have to do is ridiculous. And that's the overwhelming majority of your actual gameplay.
There's no automation or multiple selection; even when you have to manage hundreds of humans, you have to move them one by one. You also have to do this relatively fast, as you can't move humans while paused.
I wouldn't be surprised if this even made the game unplayable for some people, especially with CTS.

There's little to no meta progression in the game, which I didn't expect looking at the Steam page.

The default difficulty is just too high. I will personally do even Hardcore, to have the game 100%, but otherwise the game's difficulty is just not worth for what it offers.
Here I use difficulty for lack of a better word, I mainly mean low chance to win.
When difficulty is offset with progression and/or skill gain, then it can be satisfying. E.g. the overwhelming majority of people won't win Hades or Tainted Grail: Conquest on first try, but there's progression to motivate you. In hardcore games like the old Prince of Persia it feels great to win, because there's skill involved. But in Despotism 3K you rely on random events, and on knowing exactly how to react to those events (to be clear, your reaction is a few clicks at max).
I'm talking about events like ones that either do nothing, or disable one of your 3 crucial facilities for a significant amount of time. The only"skill" in this game is having already encountered a specific event and knowing exactly which option to choose, it's not exactly satisfying. Nor is the game hard to master, despite what the steam page says.

I don't think any of these issues by themselves would be a problem, but combined they seriously affect gameplay experience, constantly and unavoidably. | El juego tiene una premisa interesante, un pixel art bonito, una buena mÃºsica y te reta, no es fÃ¡cil al principio.

I like the game, but since the last update it's gotten so much harder. Not because there are more enemies or shorter days or less money or anything, the AI has just gotten so much stupider and buggier.

Squires and knights will randomly turn around during a portal attack, causing all the archers to go to the other side and just run into the portal. Squires/Knights will no longer try to get closer to the portal after being knocked back a bit causing the archers to be out of range of the portal and any squires/knights you brought from a previous island will sometimes randomly run off to the left (sometimes not even stopping for portals) to their death for no reason.

[h1][i]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/i] is more than a game that scratches your [i]Baldur's Gate [/i]itch.[/h1] 

[i]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/i] is a game many will turn to in lieu of more recent Larian projects. While I understand why, I also feel like this game is much more than just something that can fill the hole in your heart that you will feel after finishing [i]Baldur's Gate.[/i] A solid story is mixed with fun gameplay and really charming settings. This game has a sense of humor about itself that is also very appreciable, as it adds to the distinct charisma of it. There were parts that I didn't like as much however, those things being how I felt unguided at many times during the adventure. On one hand, I appreciate that the game doesn't hold your hand as much although on the other I did find myself lost and directionless at different points. 

The cast of characters that accompany you on your adventure are interesting and have their own unique stories that are fun to explore. The multiplayer aspects, while I didn't explore them for much time, were very fun. It would definitely be fun to play with a group of friends. All in all, a fun game that deserves its own reputation rather than falling into the shadow of Larian's newest and most successful title. | å¼€æ”¾ä¸–ç•Œåœ°å›¾ï¼Œé˜Ÿä¼å››ä¸ªäººç‰©ï¼Œèƒ½æ‰“ååº”å…ƒç´ ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç¥åƒå¤æ´»ï¼Œå¯¹è¯ä¸èƒ½è·³è¿‡ï¼Œæ¤…å­å¯ä»¥å…¥åº§ï¼Œæ˜¯åŸç¥2æ²¡é”™ï¼ | Good Pure RPG game which has good world building, Good characters, decent class variability expecially for the magical school variants. [u]Description:[/u]

Raji is a ARPG (isometric view) without loot elements or character build options. Instead, the game focuses on narrative taken from Indian mythology. The game features linear progression with visual cues to highlight the path forward. It features a mix of platforming elements and arena type combat sprinkled in with cutscene narration.

The game features a few weapons (spear, bow, sword + shield & chakram) which have minor variations in their light attacks & heavy attacks. Health recovery is through shrines and performing "finishers" on low health enemies. 
The game really shines in the world design and "artwork" spread across the game. Levels design is good but contains a few areas where your character can get "stuck". 

The story is good and the soundtrack really drives the atmosphere in combination with the artwork. Audio feedback from weapons are decent. Enemy variety is decent and spread across various levels however some enemy attacks can be very frustrating since they are relentless.

The weak aspects of the game are the the clunky controls (keyboard/mouse) in combat & certain parts of platforming. Certain enemy types also attack very frequently leaving little room for countering them. The perk system is very bare bones as well and could definitely be improved upon. 

I recommend playing on Normal difficulty for a balanced experience since Hard makes the game very frustrating due to frequent enemy attacks and lack of responsive controls to deal with them.

[u]TLDR: Raji: An Ancient Epic is a gorgeous game set in the Hindu mythos but could use some polishing for the combat/platforming aspects.[/u] | æ“ä½œæ€§ã¯70ï½80ç‚¹ã§ä»Šä¸€æ­©ã¨ã„ã£ãŸæ„Ÿã˜ã€‚åˆé–“ã«å…¥ã‚‹ãƒ‘ãƒ«ã‚¯ãƒ¼ãƒ«è¦ç´ ã‚‚æ­£ç›´é‚ªé­”ã€‚

ã—ã‹ã—ãã‚Œã‚’è£œã£ã¦ä½™ã‚Šã‚ã‚‹ä¸–ç•Œè¦³ã¨ãƒãƒˆãƒ«ã«é­…äº†ã•ã‚ŒãŸã€‚
é›£æ˜“åº¦ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã ã¨ã‚„ã‚Šã”ãŸãˆã‚‚ã‚ã£ã¦ä½•åº¦ã‚‚ã‚„ã‚‰ã‚Œã‚‹ãŒã€ãƒªã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒˆãŒæ—©ã„ã®ã§ã‚ã¾ã‚Šè‹¦ã«ãªã‚‰ãªã„ã€‚ãƒ“ã‚¸ãƒ¥ã‚¢ãƒ«ã¨æ¼”å‡ºã‚‚æœ€é«˜ã§å€‹äººã®å¥½ã¿ã«ãƒ‰ãƒ³ãƒ”ã‚·ãƒ£ã ã£ãŸã€‚ | If you're looking for challenging fights or a meticulous customization of the playable character, then this game is not for you.

                                                                                          BUT 

if you want to dive into an out-of-the-box story and you are fascinated by Indian culture, then youâ€™re definitely in the right place.

This action-adventure certainly doesnâ€™t stand out for its somewhat outdated combat system: in fact, here fighting is just a tool to achieve a goal. Guided by the favor of the Devas, Raji will learn the art of war to attempt to restore order where chaos has spread.

The beating heart of this work, however, lies in its story, which gracefully intertwines the captivating tales of the Devas: through beautifully painted walls and poetic imagery, accompanied by an extraordinarily immersive soundtrack, youâ€™ll be  able to reconstruct the origins and the exploits of some of the most important figures in Hinduism.

I absolutely recommend this game if you just want to chill out and let yourself be carried away by a timeless tale. | Feels like the version of Journey with combat and gameplay I've wanted since I was 20. Art and music are fantastic. Some of the best $6 you can spend on a game. | A really well made game. The artwork and music are incredible, and Indian mythology has been showcased in a brilliant way that no other game has managed so far. I enjoyed the diverse levels, especially Vishnu's kingdom. The game is short, but it was time well spent

I played some of the original PS1 versions when I was a kid, but I didnâ€™t get to experience all three games from start to finish until this remaster came out on the PS4.

After becoming more of a "PC plus Switch master race" kind of person, I rebought the game and replayed some of it again.

This remaster is a fantastic way to experience true old-school linear 3D platformer goodness.

While I donâ€™t think the Crash Bandicoot trilogy is the greatest linear platformer of all time, itâ€™s definitely one of the better ones, especially in the 3D space. Itâ€™s a perfect example of keeping things simple but engaging, with enough variety, especially as you progress through the trilogy.

The original Crash Bandicoot 1 on PS1 had a lot of flaws, mainly due to its frustrating save system that was locked to bonus stages and required a memory card. This was particularly tough because Crash 1 is easily the hardest game in the series. I loved its focus on simple, tough, but rewarding platforming, but the unforgiving save system really hurt the experience. Thankfully, the remaster fixes this with a proper save system between levels, which made Crash 1 Remastered easily my favorite in the trilogy.

I still enjoy Crash 2 and Crash 3, though. While they sacrifice some of the difficulty for gimmicks that Iâ€™m hit-or-miss on, theyâ€™re still positive experiences overall. The new gimmicks add variety to the level design and introduce power-ups, which Crash 1 could have used more of.

"Solve a murder where the weapon was the Big Bang." was my understanding of Genesis Noir. This is what the trailers emphasize. The reality, it in many ways, not that at all.

This is a good thing! The plot of Genesis Noir attempts to explore a world where our entire universe is just a spec. In this, it mostly succeeds.

My only real gripe with the game is that its pacing is *really* uneven. The beginning of the game in particular tends to repeat itself thematically, before exploring new ideas in earnest. Additionally, I spent a lot of the game exploring to not miss anything - in reality there's little to miss, and what you can miss doesn't dramatically impact the themes. As far as I'm aware there is no reward for being thorough.

An absolutely incredible game, one that deserves far more recognition. The artwork is breathtaking, with a striking, angular style that perfectly captures the turmoil of Revolutionary France. The story is just as remarkableâ€”layered, morally complex, and filled with weighty decisions that make every trial feel like life or death. Alexis FidÃ¨le is a phenomenal (and hot) protagonist, full of nuance and internal conflict, making it easy to get lost in his journey through power, corruption, and justice.

The core gameplayâ€”handling trials, interrogating witnesses, and balancing your relationships with various factionsâ€”is deeply immersive. It's one of the best implementations of choice-driven storytelling Iâ€™ve seen, blending narrative and mechanics seamlessly. Every verdict carries weight, forcing you to constantly reconsider your morals and strategy. Itâ€™s a hidden gem in the world of narrative-driven games.

And yet, despite all of this brilliance, I cannot recommend We. The Revolution.

The game falls apart in Act 3 due to an incredibly frustrating, poorly designed combat system that feels completely disconnected from the rest of the experience. The battles are tedious, imbalanced, and, worst of all, essential to progress. If you fail too many times, you can end up completely soft-locked from reaching the ending, rendering all of your careful decisions meaningless. The lack of an option to bypass or mitigate this makes it a glaring flaw that tarnishes an otherwise masterful game. I brute forced my way due to my love for this game, but alas I could not expect others to suffer the same.

Itâ€™s heartbreaking, really. We. The Revolution comes so close to being an unforgettable experience, but Act 3â€™s combat turns it into an exercise in frustration. If youâ€™re willing to push throughâ€”or use external workaroundsâ€”youâ€™ll find an incredible story worth experiencing. But as it stands, I canâ€™t wholeheartedly recommend it, no matter how much I want to | Un jeu en demie teinte.

This spoiler-free guide will help you learn to love the game and help you progress when you may feel lost or frustrated.

This game is so incredibly unique that I didn't like it for the first half of my playthrough because I didn't understand HOW to enjoy the game. But once it clicks, you get hooked and you don't want to put the game down because you suddenly pieced something together and you know how to progress.

WARNING: Basic game mechanic spoilers ahead (i.e. mechanics you learn within the first couple hours of playing; the ship log, for example)

So for people who are stuck or confused on how to progress or aren't really hooked in your playthrough yet, here are some tips that will help you learn HOW to enjoy the game and may help you progress:

Tip 0: Use gamepad/controller, not KBM. It's much easier to control your ship and there's also one specific section in Dark Bramble where having a controller will be very convenient.

Tip 1: Your ship log (particularly Rumor Mode) is crucial to the overall experience in this game. It guides you towards what your next objective could be (you don't have to do most of it linearly). Locations marked with a "?" means you haven't fully discovered everything in that area, or you haven't actually been to/in that location. If you're stuck, look through those locations on your ship log and pick a place you want to try to get to.

The ship log notes key details that you should remember from the Nomai dialogue you translate. These will provide you with clues on where to go or what to do to progress. They give you multiple different hints and the fun part about the game is looking at all your clues and piecing the puzzle together on what to do next. This combined with the next tip makes you feel like the most intelligent person in the universe every time you figure out what to do.

Tip 2: Learn the time loop and embrace the time loop. Understand how your solar system works and the differences between the beginning, middle, and end of the time loop. Learn the characteristics of each planet. What is changing throughout the loop? Study them, analyze them. You can also "doze off" at any of the campfires in the solar system to pass time quickly.

Now that you understand the mechanics of each planet, think about how the hints provided to you via the ship log may interact with these mechanics. Be in certain places at certain times. It's a lot easier to do trial-and-error with the next tip.

Tip 3: There is a secret dialogue option that provides you with an extra quality-of-life feature. I will mark sections of this as spoilers rather than the whole thing, so you can reveal small hints one-by-one rather than the entire thing if you want.

The feature: [spoiler]In the pause menu,[/spoiler] [spoiler]you'll unlock an option to[/spoiler] [spoiler]"meditate until next loop", which is essentially just a "restart loop" button.[/spoiler]

How to obtain this: [spoiler]You have to have talked to[/spoiler] [spoiler]Gabbro (on Giant's Deep) in a previous time loop[/spoiler] [spoiler]then come back to him on or after the 3rd loop.[/spoiler] [spoiler]Ask him "How do you stay so calm in the face of repeated impending death?" to unlock this feature.[/spoiler]

Tip 4: USE YOUR EQUIPMENT!!! This is the biggest thing I neglected but it's there for a reason. Your Scout Launcher and your Signal Scope are key features that you will need to progress. I got stuck once because I thought they were just "gimmick" features. No, you are required to use them to progress in some areas.

Tip 5: If you find an "unknown frequency" with your Signal Scope, make sure you get close to the source with your Signal Scope out and it will register it with a name on your Signal Scope. So if you ever need to go back to it in the future, it's labeled for you.

Tip 6: When in "landing mode" in your ship or when you're wearing your spacesuit on any planet, you can see a little globe on the left of your HUD. Red is the north pole and blue is the south pole. This will be helpful later in the game. Remember this by thinking of a compass and how the red arrow always points north.

Tip 7: If you're confused about a specific puzzle or you just don't really understand how to progress in one specific area on your ship log, don't be afraid to just save it for later and go try to solve something else. Many times, you're unable to progress without having specific knowledge from a different branch of the log.

Tip 8: If you're repeatedly trying something and it's still not working, you're doing something wrong.

Tip 9: If you're REALLY really stuck, take a step back and think about all the information you know about something. For example:

- This [planet] has a hidden area I cannot currently access
- This [same planet] has [this specific mechanic] that changes it throughout the time loop
- My ship log told me [these hints] about this planet

Now try to combine all that information and apply logic to the clues.

Tip 10: If you've done the above and still have no idea how to progress, r/OuterWilds on Reddit has a ton of spoiler-free hints on how to progress. Just look up where you're stuck followed by "reddit" and you'll find plenty of spoiler-free responses that will guide you in the right direction without outright telling you what to do. Obviously do this at your own risk though, but I never had a spoiler when I had to look things up.

I will say, it's so much more satisfying to figure it out on your own, but there are some puzzles that are extremely difficult and seemingly obscure (they're not obscure when you have all the clues). So try to spend some time figuring it out on your own before giving up. You really have to think outside of the box for some of the puzzles. Especially for the last puzzle of the game to get to the A[spoiler]sh[/spoiler] T[spoiler]win[/spoiler] [spoiler]Project[/spoiler].

------------------

Seguro has visto otras reseÃ±as que describen a [i]Outer Wilds[/i] como un juego que se puede jugar Ãºnicamente una vez, pero Â¿quÃ© tiene de especial para generar ese sentimiento en tanta gente?

Una de las principales razones, y lo que lo hace tan diferente a otros juegos, es que [i]Outer Wilds[/i]  no se trata de completar niveles, hacer a tu personaje mÃ¡s fuerte ni conseguir nuevos Ã­tems. El progreso lo logras como lo harÃ­as en la vida real: con conocimiento y experiencia.

En [i]Outer Wilds[/i] eres un astronauta que explora un pequeÃ±o sistema solar, mientras un bucle temporal reinicia el universo cada 22 minutos. Durante ese tiempo, se desencadenan eventos que alteran elementos clave en los diferentes planetas que puedes visitar. Sin embargo, la razÃ³n detrÃ¡s de este bucle es un misterio para ti, solo sabes que estÃ¡ relacionado con una civilizaciÃ³n alienÃ­gena desaparecida, cuyas ruinas y textos antiguos estÃ¡n esparcidos por todo el sistema solar.

Tu astronave cuenta con una computadora que guarda informaciÃ³n clave y te ayuda a seguirle la pista a los principales rumores de los planetas que visitas. ConectarÃ¡s los puntos en tu mente y podrÃ¡s resolver el misterio poco a poco, al mismo tiempo que te vuelves cada vez mÃ¡s hÃ¡bil en pilotar tu nave y volar con tu propulsor.

[h3] La primera regla de [i]Outer Wilds[/i]: No hables de [i]Outer Wilds[/i] [/h3]

Como seguro ya lo has deducido, este juego se disfruta al mÃ¡ximo comenzando a jugarlo con la menor cantidad de informaciÃ³n posible. Incluso el mÃ­nimo spoiler podrÃ­a arruinarte un puzzle o un secreto. Pero quÃ©date tranquilo: todos los acertijos del juego pueden resolverse Ãºnicamente con la informaciÃ³n que el propio juego te proporciona.

Si te sientes atascado, no te preocupes, ve a otro planeta, explora un poco mÃ¡s. Los planetas estÃ¡n diseÃ±ados para que puedas identificar puntos de interÃ©s mientras vuelas en tu astronave, [b]deja que tu curiosidad te guÃ­e[/b].

[h3] Lo que nos cautiva de este juego [/h3]

[i]Outer Wilds[/i] es un juego como ningÃºn otro, simple en sus mecÃ¡nicas, pero que logra crear una experiencia completa. Sus misterios te atraparÃ¡n y despertarÃ¡n tu curiosidad, especialmente si disfrutas indagar en el lore de los juegos. Al desentraÃ±ar cada parte del rompecabezas descubrirÃ¡s las formas ingeniosas en las que el juego oculta sus secretos a plena vista.

A lo largo de tu travesÃ­a, conocerÃ¡s a un puÃ±ado de personajes que, de alguna manera, estarÃ¡n contigo en cada paso. Es este contraste entre la inmensidad del cosmos y la cercanÃ­a de estos encuentros lo que hace que [i]Outer Wilds[/i] deje una huella permanente en quienes lo experimentan. | Outer Wilds Ã¨... difficile. E tutto questo sproloquio riguarda solo il comparto narrativo, perchÃ© se si entra nel gameplay, nel sublime game design che gli sviluppatori hanno creato con cosÃ¬ tanto evidente amore e nella colonna sonora che intreccia interazione, esplorazione e narrativa in un connubio sostanzialmente perfetto che ti accompagna per l'intera esperienza, non finirei piÃ¹ di parlarne.

Ma se stai leggendo per curiositÃ  o se vuoi scoprire cosa ne pensa la gente prima di prenderlo, ti farei un enorme disservizio se te ne parlassi nel dettaglio, perchÃ© meno sai del gioco prima di giocarci, piÃ¹ la tua esperienza sarÃ  genuina e piacevole, te lo assicuro.

Questo gioco Ã¨ un'opera d'arte, in tutti i sensi, e sono sicuro che, anche fra molti anni â€“ soprattutto quando sentirÃ² quelle prime due note al banjo â€“ ripenserÃ² all'esperienza che ho vissuto e a quello che ho provato nel viverla.

The gameplay is fun and really easy to pick up, allowing you a much lighter & quicker character building experience without needing the deep time sink that many games do (though I also enjoy that). The procedural story generation system can occasionally lead to some oddities but all in all makes for a very fun and replayable experience! 

I also love the concept of adventures spanning multiple generations, and characters becoming too old to fight. it adds an element of scale and realism to the adventures that I really appreciate. Also very slow walking and multiple playthroughs necessary. Very hard to 'complete' all translations. | One of the most unique games I have ever played.

I was a little surprised by all of the negative reviews, but after reading through them, I agree that a lot of the common complaints are valid and I can see how this game just isn't for everyone. However, I will say that there is a sort of fast travel where you can pass control to your robot while sailing, but I'm not sure if that was added in a later update, or you have to have sailed in a certain area X number of times or something like that.

Any negative criticisms were far outweighed by all of the things I loved about it: the art, the music, the world, the mystery, and most of all, I loved deciphering the ancient glyphs, which is really the core hook of the game.

Also note that you probably won't be able to solve everything or go everywhere in your first playthrough, as I believe you are really meant to play through it multiple times. Each time, you are able to carry over any glyphs you have solved in previous runs, and the phrases get longer and more complex each time. I can see how that wouldn't appeal to some folks, though, especially if the first playthrough didn't really capture you.

So I'd recommend reading through both positive and negative reviews and deciding for yourself if it feels like something you would enjoy. It might not be for you, but it also might be one of the most memorable experiences you have in a game. | æ‰£äººå¿ƒå¼¦çš„é…ä¹ï¼Œå¨“å¨“é“æ¥çš„å‰§æƒ…ï¼›ç²¾å¿ƒè®¾è®¡çš„æ–‡å­—ï¼Œå¾å¾å±•å¼€çš„å†å²ã€‚
é©¾é©¶ä¸€å¶æ‰èˆŸï¼Œä¹˜ç€åœ¨å®‡å®™ä¸­é£èˆçš„æ²³æµï¼Œç©¿è¡Œåœ¨æµå…‰æº¢å½©çš„æ˜Ÿäº‘ä¹‹ä¸­æ¥ä¸€åœºæ˜Ÿé™…è€ƒå¤ï¼Œåœ¨å¾ªåºæ¸è¿›çš„æœé›†ä¸æ¯”å¯¹ä¹‹ä¸­é€æ¸å˜æ¸…å¤±è½æ–‡å­—çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œåœ¨æ¼«é•¿çš„æ–‡çŒ®é˜…è¯»ä¸å®åœ°è€ƒè¯ä¹‹ä¸­é€æ¸æ‹¼å‡‘å†å²çš„çœŸç›¸ï¼Œåœ¨æ¢ç´¢ä¹‹ä¸­ä½“ä¼šåˆ°æ¢ç´¢æœ¬èº«å°±æ˜¯èˆªè¡Œçš„æ„ä¹‰ï¼Œç®€ç›´æ˜¯æµªæ¼«åˆ°æç‚¹çš„æ¸¸æˆã€‚ | [h1]I love it![/h1]

The game is beautiful. The locations to explore are beautiful, and the universe is gorgeous. There aren't a whole lot of characters, but they are all memorable and unique. Deciphering the language is fun, takes a lot of time but it's thrilling to piece the puzzle together and there's always something different to try when you play the game again to collect more information.

I like the hieroglyphs, and they are fun to write on actual paper. I think they look pretty. 



[h1]There's a but...[/h1]

As much as I love it, the game is a bit tedious at times. Walking is slow, despite locations being relatively small. After the 1st playthrough I am just exhausted of walking around to try something new. I am exhausted of dialogue that I can't mash a button to speed up, and although there is a slider to really make the dialogue move fast, it makes it hard to read at those speeds. It should've been a button.

I do not like the moments where the game takes control away from you, 7 out of 10 times it just walked me away without any reason and it's frustrating because that's not where I want to go. 

I did not like the endless monologue during translation process. Fading into the translation screen only to be pulled out by Aliya talking to herself and then fading back to the same translation screen does not make me happy. I just wanted to check what I've done on previous translations... but the game likes to interrupt you often with filler monologue.

[b] Backup your saves if you want to experiment! [/b] It's really not worth it to play the whole game from start if you realize that you've messed up. Oftentimes there is no undoing what you've done, and that means hours of replaying, not to mention that if you want to keep your knowledge you have to reach the end of the game for another new game+

That doesn't mean you shouldn't try rolling with your mistakes, as unintended effects could reveal something new! And you should enjoy your 1st or 2nd run first before doing any save saving. But if you're aiming to try something specific, backup and backup often.

If all you want is to get to an ending and be done with the game, you probably won't be too frustrated by this. It's only an annoyance if you want to explore further in new game +, but you probably will want to dig deeper. Until then, it's quite interesting and fun as everything is new. Except walking, walking is always too slow.

Chances are you watched the trailer and couldn't help but notice how nuts the game looks.

Sadly that's all Fluffy Horde gets right.

As an actual game, Fluffy Horde sucks.

The tags for this game inaccurate. Fluffy Horde features tower defense and strategy, but that's not what the game is. I'd describe the game as more of a physics based puzzler. The pacing of the game makes it slow, stale, and boring contradicting the frenetic zaniness of the trailer. The superficial attempts at humor also fall flat and conflict with the genuine talent put into the insane premise.

Beyond that, Fluffy Horde has one fatal issue:

The unpredictability of the physics. 

This is what quickly turned me off to the game. Anyone who's played Fluffy Horde will know exactly what I mean. Every once in awhile, you get one of 'those' levels. You'll do exactly what the game wants you to do, but fail because the bunnies are fucking and reproducing so aggressively, a few will somehow bypass whatever hazard intended to contain them and they win since a single bunny somehow spontaneously generates into a giant bunny cloud on its own. So you've got to replay the level until the physics engine decides it wants to cooperate and not violently spray bunny fetuses out of the pit you're supposed to get the bunny cloud to fall into. I wasn't able to get far into the game because of this. Which is a shame since the goofy concept of Fluffy Horde actually works.

 | Superb game. The story and writing are very well done. It follows the story of Jack Boyd from the first game, and I must say I really enjoyed it. All the gameplay mechanics from the first game are improved - they are much more polished, immersive, and engaging. The "time wasted by waiting," which bothered me most in the first game, was significantly reduced in this sequel. It's still present but not to a level that would bother me.

The game itself covers a much shorter time period but feels fuller thanks to the improved content. The X-com styled missions were an interesting addition - even though at first, I thought they wouldn't fit the game. The truth is, they did. It was a good decision.

Graphically, the game is styled and presented in a way that won't wither with time. Even in 2025, I wouldn't be able to say whether the game was made today or seven years ago.

Lastly, the music is just great. I love that the devs invested in the soundtrack even more than in the first game. I missed the song selection at the start of the game a bit, but the fact is, that the first game, it was one of the things that started getting on my nerves after a time, and I often just skipped the music. Here, they pick one for you, and every single one I enjoyed and felt fit the atmosphere. So it was probably a good choice because I never got bored of the music.

[b]Overall, I highly recommend this story driven narrative game. However, I would recommend you to play the first game first. It adds much of the needed context for the Jack's motivations and character.[/b] Without it, I am not sure I would get invested into this sequel enough to finish it because I would feel like I am missing pieces of a puzzle. If you didn't like the first game however, then I do not think you will enjoy this one. It is improvement on every level, but it retains the core systems and core gameplay elements.

I feel like I was duped by the reviews on this game. Bots?

Pros:
- The custom art is excellent and easily the best part of this game. I love the large sprites. This artist obviously loves the game of basketball and did a fantastic job of capturing the likenesses of NBA legends, without crossing copyright lines... Unfortunately, the art direction is also a con (will elaborate later).
- Fully customizable rosters.
- Multiple game modes. The game mode where you create a team of legends by means of 5 different challenge games is neat.

Cons:
- Gameplay. Shoot, pass, steal, block, jump ball to start the game... Even the dunking mini game gets old quickly and I find it to be immersion-breaking. Pretty much every single time you dunk the ball, if there's a defender nearby/in front of you, you're going to be pulled into a mini game that frankly takes too long and becomes tedious quickly. No turbo to run faster for a period of time (Although, if you call a play on offense like pick-and-roll, the "roll" guy will have a temporary boost of speed. Not all that well implemented though.) The gameplay is incredibly tedious.
- Graphics. With a pixel art game, it's reasonable to expect some good old-fashioned pixel sprites. Unfortunately, you play with a bunch of stick figures who are marginally discernible from one another. Big missed opportunity here to make some great 16-bit sprites. While the custom art in the menu and in the dunking mini game is great, everything else leaves a lot to be desired. Also, the camera is so far zoomed out at all times...just sort of makes it a stale and boring experience.  It's like looking at a board of marbles going back and forth.
- There's a mode where you can play through a season, but it's as basic as it can get and you can't really do anything other than play each game in the season. No trades, no player development or mini games between the season's games, no draft, etc. More tedium and boring gameplay.
- The way you call offensive plays is certainly unique, with there being three options drawn on the back court as you inbound the ball. These sort of "buckets" are triggered by standing on them for a second or two. The buckets you stand on should really be smaller, as sometimes you'll inbound the ball and BOOM you called a play you didn't want to call. It pulls all your players across half court when you call a play. Honestly, I don't care for this system at all. Just map the play-calling to buttons on the controller (the game only uses two anyway...).
- No player development, coaches, or really anything other than very basic arcade-style gameplay. This game's creators actually had the gall to post something suggesting this as a successor to Super Techobowl. It has a long way to go.

All in all, $10 isn't much, but I would rather have my $10 after purchasing this. There are much better options out there for the money (or for free).

nota: gta medieval de 10 | After roughly ten hours you finish all the quests. The game is original but familiar in every aspect. The cheesy story, soundtrack, characters everything is a play or a reference to anything from popculture. The gameplay is easy to get used to and the whole thing is fun to play, to extend you even read the actual dialogues. Finished in two days and loved it. | A short medieval version of Grand Theft Auto. It took me about 12 hours to complete the game including all the side quests (DaVinci DLC included) and the main quests. The combat is lacking a little bit but still functional enough to work. The enemies tend to hit you and then back up forcing you to lunge at them to get in a hit. I couldn't figure out how to parry correctly no matter what I tried. 

The best part of the game is the humor and the setting. It just works and is entertaining. Maybe a little heavy handed on the Monty Python skits but I did laugh in spots. I wish the map was bigger and there were more quests. It felt too short when I completed the game. The DaVinci DLC is worth it but the Murder DLC doesn't really add much to the game unless you enjoy murder sprees. 

The game goes on sale often and is worth picking up if you like Grand Theft Auto/mission based games. I played on the easy setting mostly because the combat isn't that much fun. | The medieval GTA version in isometric view is out and this one really hit the target. The graphics and aspects of its gameplay is simple yet this kept me playing for hours. I have no issue spending my my whole weekends to follow playing this. its worth Guys I'm telling you! Grab this one Now!

First full run through and first daily challenge. Game's got a dead-simple premise, but it's a lot of cheap fun. If you like to over-analyse each action, be constantly thinking three turns ahead and then f*cking it up anyway, this game's your jam.

Lots of replayability, graphics/sound are fun, game doesn't feel too numbers-y or too strategy light, and they've managed to nail that sweet spot between action analysis and quick fun that a lot of turn-based strategy games miss. | well-made tactical roguelike with a solid degree of depth

A nice dice-rolling roguelike

+ Unique mechanics for each class
+ Fresh Final Stage
+ Although the theme is a bit light, at times the game dialogues were fun to watch

- A bit on the easy side
- AI not always finding the optimal move
- Not all enemies feel unique | I hate rouguelikes and rougelites. I hate deckbuilders. I literally couldnt even finish the Splatoon 3 dlc, despite being an OG WIIU fan, because I just hate the genre so much.

But this game. Something about this game. It is phenomenal. I have been chipping away at it for hours on end, just trying one step more to reach my goal of completing them all. I keep it open at work and do a battle or two as a break, I play it at home when I need to refocus myself, I play it all the time, and i have been since it came out. I reccomend this game to literally anyone, and I am genuinely going to be so sad once I finish all that I have set out to do and have to lay this game to rest, | Amazing roguelike with addicting gameplay and outstanding soundtrack.
The lucky factor can be a little anoying sometimes, but it's a dice game, so nothing wrong with it.
The gold lies on the challenges, and replaying levels when you fail does not feel bad, but engaging.
Love it. | fun little dicey game and i like the funny clown man | Incredibly fun dice-based rouge-lite.  A lot of variation in how to build each character.  Gameplay is very unique, never really played another game like it.  Love the humor in the game and soundtrack slaps.

Rendering, beautiful, soundtracks, great, noir, it's there. Though, you get minimal when it actually comes to expression or detailed animation. You are actually reading a book, book with moving pictures that is not yet cinema. You get some interactiveness in the beginning, some tiny little puzzles, but then.... it stopped. The rest of the game is about go somewhere, talk to someone, ala "walking sim". 

Did I like the story though? It was... acceptable, there's a specific mood to it, which might not be everyone's cake. I tend to like that kinda thing though. Aside from that, the writing and world building are just at my average bar, it pass, but not as memorable as some other stuff I have played.

So, yeah, "y-yes" or "mouais"

Lots to explore, 12 hours in on first playthrough i probably touched the surface
Interesting worldbuilding and cool systems
Can be very addictive once you've gotten used to the system

Cons: 
- Many tasks feel like grinding. A lot of repetitiveness, be it work, reading books or studying skills. E.g. to improve your [spoiler]  "reason" [/spoiler] skill you have to  combine 8 [spoiler] "Erudition" [/spoiler]  which takes 60 seconds each to combine, and 60 seconds to make, all on timers before they run out... 

- The way cards get added to your field sucks ass and is beyond annoying, just dumping them wherever with no possibility to have a dedicated place for a certain type of card. Let me have all books in one place, all vitality in another etc... being unable to stack cards with different timers is also extremly annoying and creates a mess all the time. 

Overall, a 6/10 which would be probably a 7 or 8 if the quality of life wasn't so miserable at points. 

If you like management in games | This game is a passionate love affair I keep coming back to.  It's not something I recommend to everyone (honestly I don't think any game is, but this one is more "has a highly specific target audience" than most) - you have to be some combination of a fiddly detail obsessive, wiki-diver, and opaque lore-enjoyer to really get the most out of it.  

Watching the previews will give a decent sense of the actual gameplay, which I would have difficulty describing, but the *feeling* of playing the game can't really be communicated as easily, I think.  Cultist Sim is incredibly atmospheric, and a lot better at creating interesting tension than a few gameplay clips can really convey.  The timer progression is such an integral part of not just the mechanics, but the mood.  Is your current Dream action (20 seconds remaining) going to turn up the card you need to dispel part of the Fascination counter (45 seconds remaining) currently spelling your doom?  etc.  

Also, it pays to actually read the descriptive text on things - it will all sound like pretentious bullshit at first, but there is a kind of shockingly cohesive, deep, and interesting setting and story going on, here, behind all the timer-watching.

My one main criticism is that it is really, really bad at teaching you how to play it.  I'd recommend spending a few minutes on youtube to help get the basics down; there are a lot of aspects of the game that are satisfying to find out in an exploratory manner, but the basics of stuff like, how to recruit and promote Followers are not that.  Thankfully, the fan wiki is also excellent, and basically an essential resource if you get in deep. | ç®€å•æ¥è¯´è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆå°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šä¸ªå€’è®¡æ—¶çš„å¡ç‰Œæ”¶é›†ç»è¥æ¸¸æˆï¼Œå€’è®¡æ—¶ç»“æŸæ²¡æœ‰è·å¾—å¯¹åº”çš„å¡ç‰Œä¸¢è¿›å»é‚£æ¸¸æˆä¹Ÿå°±ç»“æŸäº†ã€‚è§„åˆ™æ¯”è¾ƒå¤æ‚ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰æ–°æ‰‹æŒ‡å¼•ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰æ•…äº‹èƒŒæ™¯ï¼Œå…¨éƒ¨çš„æ–°æ‰‹æŒ‡å¼•å’Œæ•…äº‹èƒŒæ™¯å…¨é wikiå’Œç½‘ä¸Šå„ä½å¤§ä½¬æ€»ç»“çš„æ”»ç•¥ï¼Œå¯¹æ–°æ‰‹æå…¶ä¸å‹å¥½ï¼Œåœ¨æ¸¸æˆå½“ä¸­é€‰ä¸­å¡ç‰‡å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°éƒ¨åˆ†çš„æç¤ºæˆ–è€…ç‰‡é¢çš„æ•…äº‹èƒŒæ™¯ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸æ˜¯å¯¹å¯†æ•™è¿™ç±»é»‘æš—é¢˜ææ„Ÿå…´è¶£çš„ä¸å»ºè®®æ¸¸ç©ã€‚

It's quaint! But I'm not sure it's for me. The game is an arcade-style, top down hack-and-slash. And it's stylish at what it does, with a silly little cyberpunk aesthetic and simple, direct battle mechanics.

But it feels really shallow to me. The limited nature of the mechanics means there's not exactly a lot going on here; there is probably progression later, but it's clear the core is a Hotline Miami style, one-shot-kill type of combat, where it grades your performance at the end. There's a story and good art, but having it all be based on that gamey formula feels a bit limiting.

For the people who read everything I said and thought, "that actually sounds kinda neat," you'll probably like this. But if you see the slick art style and are tempted, just be forewarned that it might not exactly meet the standards you're hoping for. Inevitably, this is just fine. | This game is fast and fluid. The cyberpunk  aesthetic along with the retro pixel design blends perfectly. I absolutely recommend taking this game a for spin, you won't be disappointed. | Great little game, in theory.
In practice, the conditions for unlocking are diabolical, which absolutely takes the fun out of it.
Still, give it a slash!
 | Good and fluid game design but playing with controller is little bit harder since this game is fast paced and you have to aim all the time. There should be aim assist at least somewhat. Because when u miss you even for once you lose your combo meter which happened to me at 99 kills so that i missed the new upgrade. This by itself tilted me a lot and now im writing this. And also gameplay sometimes felt RNG. U miss your strikes so randomly. But good game for 2-3 hours of play. I'm not going to be douche and leave bad review but this game is not as good as its ratings. 7/10 | If this game let me move while I was shooting and didn't have a stamina bar it'd be an easy recommendation. It's so close to being good but ends up being infuriating in a way where the mechanics of the game and the type of the game it is are at odds with each other.

Although that game does not take place in hell, it is certainly similar to the grotesque and vulgar humor present in the game. There is even an unlockable "squirrel" outfit that resembles Conker. Boy do I miss the old Rareware.

Nostalgia aside, Hell Pie is a must play. | It's exactly what it looks like.

Hell Pie is a 3D Platformer that attempts to capture the same tone and comedic style as Conker's Bad Fur Day while doing none of that and instead overdosing on grossout and vulgarities. 

I have only played 2 levels of this game. The Whale level and the Fascist Turd level in the demo, and I think it's safe to say that it is not going to get any better than this. I feel like I'm playing through an episode of a hybrid series of Mr. Pickles and Ren and Stimpy. 

I can appreciate the artistry in the ingredient images, the music's pretty nice, and the game DOES definitely have interesting movement mechanics. But there's just too much pointless gross in here for me to want to continue.

If you like emptying the contents of your stomach and staring a copious amounts of bare @ss, Hell Pie is for you. I really don't know why 3 years ago me thought this was a good idea.

Valheim has become a cherished part of our family time since its release, and we often find ourselves diving into new adventures during the holidays. We all contribute to the game in our own ways, but itâ€™s clear to see each of our preferences. The Longing is a delightfully lonely experience, with your only company being a quiet timid creature simply named "The Shade." 
The moment you finish the intro, a timer appears at the top of the screen, counting down 400 real time days. Time passes even when the game is closed, or your device is powered off. 
From there, it's just you, a sprawling cave system, and a lonely little shadow who just wants to find some sort of comfort in their solitary life.

Pros: 
-Lovely hand drawn scenery
-Incredibly simple, yet pleasing, controls.
-Occasional comments from the Shade that just make you want to give the lil fella a hug
-A massive 'detox' from the widespread high adrenaline, constant input games that have become commonplace.
-Hidden treasures that appeal to those with a goblin hoarding instinct

Cons(?):
-I found the music to annoying, but you can toggle it (as well as atmospheric lighting and sound effects) very easily
-It can be occasionally frustrating just how incredibly slow the Shade walks, especially when you travel across a vast tunnel, only to find you've already been there, it's a dead end, and you must walk all the way back. (But as long as you save the "memory" of signifigant places like your home, you can simply click the location and wait for the lil fella to automatically walk the distance)
-The lack of explanation before beginning a time consuming task makes it so you never know if the time spend (whether it be minutes, hours, or even days) will be worth waiting for. (On the flip side, it makes it that much more rewarding when you *do* discover something special)

Conclusion:
If you're one to pursue high adrenaline, stress inducing games with fast paced gameplay, this is not the game for you.
Then again, perhaps it's just the game you need to re-discover the art of slowing things down, finding joy in the simple things, and empathize with the lonely. | like an anti-game. really cool concept and execution. excited for the next 396 days | The artwork is amazing as well as the story. I quickly became invested in Shade's well-being and love checking in on him daily. This is definitely worth a try if you're looking for something casual and cozy. This is meant to be played at a much slower pace. | A game with no rules that moves along pretty slowly until you figure out you can save locations and just send your little player there.  I really enjoyed playing the game.  The ending was a little weird for me but it was over then.  It is really a puzzle game because there are no rules, very few clues, and basically just discovery and guessing. | Para aqueles que zeraram sem querer igual a mim, que sem querer esperaram os 400 dias por nÃ£o ter tido tempo para jogar normalmente, esperem por 10 minutos na tela de final do jogo que ele reiniciarÃ¡ do zero!
Esse jogo Ã© muito bom e tem muito o que ensinar com esse LONGO tempo de jogo, Ã³timo para passar o tempo e surtos de madrugada, VALE SUPER

7/10. | There's fun to be had here but it's weighed down by a build system that is almost entirely RNG-based.

You collect gold, plus mana in each of several categories (obtained by your students studying that subject). When you get enough of a category you can draw a card for an item or new room of that category - you're presented with three options and pick one. These options are entirely RNG-based.

What that means is that you may go into a map thinking you want to try an Arcane and Nature school and then just never draw the requisite cards to get it going. Or, you may know you need more dormitories for your students but the game just never gives you the card. You can't really plan the school out because you really have no idea what the game is going to let you build with the bizarre luck-of-the-draw system.

On the plus side, there's a lot of charm in the graphics and the game does a great job with the "feel" of magic. The classrooms are cool and your kids can get items like devil's horns, staves, regalia, etc. It really does feel like a magic school.

It's just such an odd choice from the developers to make the build system completely based on dice rolls. | I love this game, the main campaign is perfect, there is some replay ability, if you like experimenting, I do. Definitely recommend, my only gripe is that I selfishly want more.

At a certain point i started playing endless, but I wish there was more story, unless I'm missing something, I wish there was a secret to uncover or the dungeons just available or for quests to keep coming. In endless mode it hits a lull, I'd like for there to be more action, maybe the factions go to war or something, see what happens if you and the certain groups are friends. See students join different factions and maybe that gives you influence during encounters because your student runs a specific department for that faction. I think fleshing out a little more story based details would make endless actually go on for a lot longer before hitting a lull. | å¥½ç©ä½†æ˜¯å¾ˆå¡çœŸçš„å¾ˆå¡ï¼Œæ…ç© | Great theme and art style. Rules become very clear after playing one level and it really fun gameplay loop.

At first the fact that every action can be done with only one key, (space) looks like a great approach, but given that -everything- is perfomed by that, very often unvanted actions occur/trigger, which is very annoying.
You should forget about this and use a proper key assignment layout like other decent games.

Also the item handling, splitting, etc. is very different from the already widely established scheme based on common sense.
On its own it would not be an issue. If it would work fine. But it is messy and don't have much logic.

In the mazes, the camera movement is quite unfortunate as the snapping or stationary camera is not a good idea when all of the other parts of the game use a camera fixed on the player.
As the camera stops on the border of rooms and only snaps to the next room when the player enters, it cannot be seen exactly what is on the other side of the door, even when open. So a situation when a player enters another room in the face of an enemy without seeing it, can happen and get attacked.
Which is silly.

Quite often we had desyncs and players dropped, which is also very annoying.
The last drop was when in a maze all of our progress got lost due to a disconnection/desync error.

Due to these and if a game produces this many bugs and is this unstable, then at least a usual rotating autosave feature would be nice, so users would have a way to restore the lost content and time.

I guess no devs will read this or will not give a damn anyway, but if you want to improve your game, then here you go.

Have seen beta games in better shape than this. | This game got old really, really fast.  The monkeys were kind of annoying more than helpful, and I get the impression the game was just kind of dumped mid-development.  Gonna be a nah from me. | I really wanted to like this game but i just can't. I tried to finish it twice but i gave up.
The visuals are great, i really like the pixel art and i got it really cheap.
But it all falls apart with the gameplay, the monkey system is okayish when you have a few monkeys around.
-The game has only four directions of combat, but everything can attack you from a diagonal
-The ui is terrible, whith constant shuffleing of items and materials with very non-intuitive controls
-one button to interact with everything makes the game frustrating after a while (random weapon swaping with monkeys during gathering).
-if there are more items on one tile. welll... though luck, you need to pick it all up (also move the monkey standing there)
-after about an hour or two it becoms a total grind for resources, which involves only going from island A to island B click a bunch of items and return.
-building a base is very bare bones and i had no satisfaction in doing so. (god forbid you want a wooden floor everywhere)
-every aspect of the game feels like its strapped on only to get the game to be longer and not interesting or fun. | This game has an issue with saving whenever I tried to load one of my saves it sets me back to when I first saved (when you generate a world)

[h1]A [spoiler]8[/spoiler] out of 10 game.[/h1]

[h2][spoiler]Easy and fun to play through like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2379780/Balatro]Balatro[/url] in many ways, at less than 20% of the price. The sound-effects are also cute and equally pleasing in that same vein[/spoiler].[/h2]

Upgrades at the shop, along with re-rolls happen after every round, and any/every round/level lasts no longer than 30 seconds, thus turn-arounds and pivots at the shop happen in pretty quick succession, multiple times a minute from the get-go, allowing you to quickly build/draft your set of fighters from something or nothing at any point during a run. After about every 5 levels or so you also get to choose 1 global enhancement for all the respective fighters you've collected. It's that simple along with boss encounters and minimalistic controls, with practically no learning curve.

[h2]There's no b***s***'n with tutorials or any story line before you start. It takes less than a minute to directly jump into the game after purchasing.[/h2]

Everything is there in front of you, short and sweetly after that; ready for your 'full attention' & low-friction neuron-activating enjoyment with a steady, unbroken stream of combat and rogue-like choice-making gameplay. | Minimal instructions were initially befuddling, but it was actually fun to figure out the subtleties of control and snake design. Very satisfying to build a nice overpowered snake with stacking abilities and items. | It's a fun little game and for the price of a mobile game? Absolutely the sufficient content to match. Solid replay-ability through testing different builds and strategies. | A simple game where you build your snake from segments that all have their own "class." Activate powerful class bonuses by having enough of the same type. It's a neat little game with tank controls which feels kinda weird at first but you get used to it. | bought because i said in a discord server "say, what if there was a game like slither.io but with roguelike mechanics and you could build your snake out of synergizing segments?" and was recommended this.
a truly underdeveloped, unbalanced and all around flawed game. all luck, no skill. unclear UI that i only started to understand almost 7 hours in. the core gameplay of fighting enemies is unsatisfying and unfair due to controls that do not facilitate the game design. or perhaps the other way round? who bloody knows.
Please do not buy this game, there are other games similar to it that are more worth your time IMO, the closest thing is Brotato and despite not having the snake gimmick thats practically a benefit since the snake gimmick is this games biggest fumble

ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ½Ğ°Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ´ĞºĞ¸, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ² Ğ¾ÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ²ÑÑ‘ Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ-Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞ½Ğ¾, Ğ¸ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ ÑƒÑĞ¸Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¶ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ Ğº Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ»Ñƒ | This game has a number of arrows in its quiver:
-the premise is solid. Even though the cyberpunk, corporations-ridden setting is nothing to write home about, the profession of GameDec is enough to keep things fresh.
-switching from one digital setting to another keeps the player engaged and even hyped pertaining the next level;
-aesthetics are solid across the board, wether you're looking at in-game models, dialogue avatars or scenes design as a whole.

Unfortunately, it ends up lacking in the departments that should have you interested in a cRPG in the first place:
-NPCs are not memorable, and that's underselling it. Aside from Ken and maaaaaybe the CEO from the DLC case, there isn't a single character whose writing dares to dip below the surface;
-the plot starts in an interesting place and then it manages to pull a turn that is somehow both out of nowhere and predictable (I won't go into further detail in order to avoid spoilers, but the game ends up revolving around the pseudo-SciFi mumbo jumbo that the first half oh so wisely keeps its distance from);
-while there's a lot of branching when it comes to single cases, each and every single thread leads to the same ending, and you can "unlock" the harder ones by a single choice in the last 10 minutes of the game; it is narratively fitting, but quite disappointing nonetheless.

In the end, the worst flaw of them all is how rushed this game feels, especiallt in the second half. There are interesting ideas aplenty, some of them even evading the cliches of such a historied genre, but none of the original ones gets to breathe and be developed in full. 

That being said, I will look forward to subsequent projects from this team :) There's a lot of good in this here title and it could be fixed without seismic changes. Here's hoping for the next one!

DO NOT BUY | TrialsÂ® Rising is an exhilarating physics-based platforming game that masterfully blends high-octane action with a steep learning curve. Developed by RedLynx and Ubisoft, it delivers a satisfying mix of challenge, humor, and creativity, making it a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike.

Positives:
One of the gameâ€™s greatest strengths is its accessibility. TrialsÂ® Rising welcomes players with a gradual difficulty curve, allowing beginners to enjoy the fun of navigating its intricate courses while still offering veteran players a true test of skill in later stages. The tutorials are clear and effective, making it easy to pick up and play.

The level design is outstanding, with tracks set in diverse, real-world-inspired locations. From roaring stadiums to exotic landscapes, each track is bursting with personality and creative obstacles. The game strikes a perfect balance between spectacle and precision, challenging players to master its physics while delivering breathtaking visuals.

Multiplayer adds another layer of excitement, with both online and local modes that encourage friendly competition. The inclusion of a tandem bike mode, where two players share control of a single bike, is a hilarious and chaotic addition thatâ€™s perfect for couch co-op.

Customization is another highlight, with players able to design their riderâ€™s appearance and bike to their liking. The community-driven content creation tools allow for a virtually endless supply of user-generated tracks, extending the gameâ€™s replayability far beyond the core content.

Criticisms:
Despite its strengths, TrialsÂ® Rising has a few rough edges. Progression can feel grindy at times, with repetitive tasks required to unlock certain events. The gameâ€™s emphasis on earning gear through loot boxes, while purely cosmetic, might not sit well with players who prefer more straightforward rewards.

Additionally, while the challenge is part of the gameâ€™s charm, some of the later levels can feel punishingly difficult, potentially alienating more casual players. The balance between fun and frustration isnâ€™t always perfect, and retries can occasionally feel tedious.

Finally, while the tracks are visually diverse, the gameâ€™s environments sometimes lack the graphical polish expected from modern titles. Certain textures and details can feel dated, though this doesnâ€™t detract significantly from the overall experience.

Conclusion:
TrialsÂ® Rising is a thrilling and addictive game that offers a unique blend of skill-based gameplay, creativity, and humor. Itâ€™s a game that rewards perseverance and mastery, providing immense satisfaction when you finally conquer a challenging track.

While it has its minor flaws, such as a grindy progression system and occasional difficulty spikes, the sheer fun of its gameplay and the vibrant community make it a standout in the platforming genre. Whether youâ€™re a longtime Trials fan or a newcomer, TrialsÂ® Rising is a ride worth taking.


8.5/10

You won't regret it. | Blood Card is an absolute gem for fans of challenging deck-building roguelikes! While the gameâ€™s difficulty level can be punishing at times, itâ€™s this very challenge that makes every victory feel so rewarding. The unique mechanics, like sacrificing your health as part of your deck strategy, add a fresh twist that sets it apart from other card-based games in the genre.

The blend of roguelike elements and strategic gameplay keeps things exciting. Every run feels different, and the satisfaction of crafting a winning strategy through trial and error is unmatched. The process of discovering new card combinations and tactics makes it fun.

The visuals and atmosphere are simple yet effective, creating a dark and gritty tone that perfectly matches the gameplay. For anyone who enjoys strategy games with a high skill ceiling and plenty of replayability, Blood Card is an absolute must-play. Prepare to die a lotâ€”but have a blast while doing so!"

Recommended for players who enjoy a good challenge and the thrill of figuring out the perfect strategy. | Oui.

Ğ’ÑĞµĞ¼ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°, ÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹! ^_^[/i] | Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ñ„Ğ°ĞºÑ‚Ñƒ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ĞµĞ¹ Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ³Ğ´Ğµ Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ€ÑÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ Ñ‡ĞµĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµĞºÑƒ Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½ĞµÑ† Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ absolute cimena | ä¼˜åŒ–æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰çš„ï¼Œå¤‡å—è¾±éª‚æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰æ‚”æ”¹çš„ï¼Œå¤–æŒ‚æ˜¯ä¸€å¤§å †çš„ï¼Œåˆ›æ–°æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰çš„ï¼Œè¢«æŠ„äº†æ˜¯ä¸ç®¡çš„ï¼ŒçœŸæƒ³ä¸åˆ°è¿™æ¸¸æˆæ˜¯æ€ä¹ˆæ´»ä¸‹æ¥çš„ | [b]Among Us took the gaming world by storm, proving that sometimes, the simplest games create the most unforgettable moments. Whether you're completing tasks like a diligent crewmate or plotting deception as an imposter, this game is all about strategy, teamwork, and betrayal.

The gameplay is easy to understand but leads to intense, hilarious, and sometimes frustrating interactions. One moment, you're quietly fixing wires, and the next, you're passionately defending yourself in an emergency meeting after being falsely accused. The mix of deduction and deception makes every round unpredictable and fun.

What makes Among Us special is the social experience. It thrives on communication (and miscommunication), whether you're playing with friends or random players. The joy of convincing others to vote someone off, only to realize they were innocent, creates endless entertainment.

Visually, it's simple and colorful, with cute character designs that contrast the brutal reality of getting ejected into space. The sound design, from the satisfying task completion beeps to the ominous kill animations, adds to the tension.

While Among Us is at its best with a group of friends, public lobbies can be hit-or-miss, depending on how people play. The game has also evolved with new roles, maps, and customization options, keeping things fresh for long-time players.

In conclusion, Among Us is a fantastic party game that blends strategy and chaos in the best way possible. Itâ€™s proof that great multiplayer experiences donâ€™t need complex mechanicsâ€”just a solid concept and the right group of people. If you love games that test friendships and create hilarious memories, this oneâ€™s a must-play![/b] |
