Absolutely beautiful art style that does not give away the punishing gameplay. In As Far As The Eye, you play as the wind, guiding a nomadic tribe to safe land. I very much enjoy the different take on the resource-management genre, with the journey broken up into multiple halts and obstacles. The short-term goal is simply to make it to the next halt before the step counter runs out and the flood arrives. The non-combative gameplay focuses on harvesting different resources instead, and actually provides a decent goal-oriented focus within which to use them.

Since each halt is procedurally generated, with varying amounts of ressources available, planning the journey ahead is essential for a realistic chance of making it to The Eye. Resources must be carefully managed, since they are simultaneously needed for the journey and the progression of the tribe per halt. At the beginning, I often struggled with rations and faced starvation among my Pupils. Only after many hours spent figuring out the mechanics, the gameplay finally started to feel fair. The challenge lies clearly in the fact that mistakes canâ€™t be undone, with the single save file being overridden every turn.

Overall, I enjoy the simplicity of the gameplay, setting up camp over and over again, strategically placing buildings, and managing resources. The task-based progression of the tribe fosters a sense of attachment to the success of the Pupils. And I particularly love seeing them shapeshift into animal spirits based on their assigned trades. Although limited, the lore of As Far As The Eye fits seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. This even makes me appreciate that excess resources gathered and left behind count against the final score, since the Pupils live in harmony with nature. | 6.5/10 - Decent

Buy on sale.  Worth the campaign and a run or two.  I can't remember how much I paid for it but about $10 CAD feels reasonable.

Really cute game.  Pretty decent challenge and strategy.  Satisfying to play once you learn.

Tip: 1. Start training a druid early.  2. If you can't find your pupils, look for their balloons.

If I had anything interesting to say, it would be that the bottlenecks between halts serve to really narrow my focus.  I'm not talking about the requirements to reach a halt, I'm talking about the inventory bottlenecks to reach it.  I found myself caring less and less about my pupils, their really cool skill trees, and what capabilities I could unlock, because I would likely need to throw away resources anyway to make room for food and the one mobile building I threw together.  It's really hard to get extraction up and running without a good supply of food for the beginning of each halt.  But the amount of food that requires takes up most of your caravan's inventory, making it hard to build anything right out of the gate.  
If I could change one small thing that would make the game significantly better, it would be to double the amount of food per stack in the caravan's inventory.  That would open up way more possibilities for interesting choices per run on what buildings to make mobile and what resources to take with you. | nicely done city builder in turn based | æ°›å›´æ„Ÿæ‹‰æ»¡äº†

The best things about "Curse..." is that you can master it and has no BS mechanics that will kill you. If you died, it's on you. 

The worst thing is that it is bothersome. 

Somewhere in the middle of the game you will become spammed with spongy enemies. Full of HP with armors that are easy but time consuming to dispose. 

Moreover darkness mechanic is bothersome w/o adding any meaningful layer to the game. 

Also RNG is strong in this one. Which again - os bothersome considering that most of weapons is on "meh" or worse side.  Some goes for traits etc. 

So yeah, most of your runs you will end up with things that aren fun to use, takes time and you will start getting hurt because you tried to cut corners so you dont have to play it for so long... And this. This exactly what makes it thumbs down game. | A great little roguelite, deceivingly simple, incredibly addictive, and fairly challenging.

The combat system is pretty tight, easy to learn but challenging to master. I wish there were a few more weapons to add more variety, but there's already quite a few to choose from, depending on your playstyle and what you're comfortable with.

The game is just soooo challenging that I can't stop playing! 10/10 highly recommended for those whose minds won't stop thinking haha best game to play before going to sleep <3 | Reviewed after 100% achievements. This game gets significantly more fun the more you view it as a puzzle game rather than a city planning game. You are not trying to build a nice place to live. Instead, you are trying to funnel the right cars to the right places in whatever way works best. This leads you into some city designs which would make absolutely no sense in a normal city builder, but looking at it as a puzzle game, this is not a problem whatsoever. To be clear: there is no goal in the game other than to make roads for the cars to reach the right color of business. The cars will always go the fastest route, and always deploy from the nearest available house, so you don't need to do any management at all other than setting up the roads and trying to plan it so that there isn't gridlock. This simple task never gets boring for long because the demand for cars will ramp up to inifinity until you lose. You can play "endless" mode once you lose, but trying to get the most trips completed before that point is the real draw, like trying to get the highest score or level in Tetris. | SchÃ¶nes Spiel zum entspannen, ich mag die Grafik sehr. The fact is that the game is difficult, and even a little inconsistency will easily piss you off. For example, a shield usually protects against traps, but not from a trap that removes all the cards from your hand. But why?! Or thunder usually works on all opponents of the same type, and this rule works on all hydra except red ones. But why?! Or usually, before exiting a level, you can play useless cards like sadness and thus get rid of them. But not when you exit the treasure room level. The game just freezes. The gameplay is simple to pick up, and the visuals and sound design are easy on the eyes and ears.

The game attempts to tackle the theme of depression, but its approach is more akin to a sledgehammer than subtlety, which ironically made me laugh out loud. In a strange way, I enjoyed that too, so all's well.

Definitely worth checking out for its charm and effort.

I've spent so many hours on this game it's painful

While the game has a cute story and was well-produced, you get about 3 hours of playtime for $20 with no replay value. This is a great concept for a game and unique from everything else on the market yet the team is staunchly against expanding on this. Sadly, I don't recommend the game just due to the price point to entertainment ratio. | å¥½æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œæ˜¯å¤§ä¼™ï¼ˆæŒ‡æˆ‘è‡ªå·±ï¼‰æœ€çˆ±çš„æ”¶çº³å°æ¸¸æˆï¼åæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œä¸å¤ªé€‚åˆä¸­å›½å®å®ä½“è´¨çš„æ”¶çº³é€»è¾‘ï¼æœ¬æ¥ä¸»æ‰“è½»æ¾ä¼‘é—²ï¼Œå¾ˆå¯èƒ½å› ä¸ºå“ªå“ªéƒ½ä¸ç»™æ”¾ä¸€ä¸‹å­å˜æˆé«˜è¡€å‹æ¸¸æˆï¼ˆå±ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸€å‘¨ç›®å¡å…³çš„åœ°æ–¹ç©å¾—ç«å¤§è®©äººåªæƒ³å¿«ç‚¹æ”¶æ‹¾å¹²å‡€é€šå…³ï¼ŒäºŒå‘¨ç›®è½»è½¦ç†Ÿè·¯å¼€å§‹å…±æƒ…ç»†ç»†ç ”ç©¶å‰§æƒ…ï¼ŒåŸæ¥ä¸»äººå…¬æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæƒ…å²åå·æ¼‚æ³ŠåŠç”Ÿå½’æ¥ç»ˆäºå’Œè€å©†å¤•é˜³è¥¿ä¸‹HappyEndingï¼Œä¸€æ‰‹æŠ±ç€å´½å­ä¸€æ‰‹å¼¹ç€å°¤å…‹é‡Œé‡Œåœ¨å¼€æ»¡é²œèŠ±çš„BigHouseåº­é™¢é‡Œå–ç€ä¸‹åˆèŒ¶å“¼ç€æ­Œçš„å¹¸ç¦å°å¥³å­©ï¼

It was both hilarious and intriguing, and I really loved the gameplay. I would restart chapters over and over just to get perfect scores. Honestly, I can't really think of any negatives. It's very unique and interesting.

Absolutely love this game.  Has all the theming of Binding of Isaac in a unique take on a match 4 game.

Negative:
Let me get the bad out of the way first.  Yes, the game can be buggy at times, but not unplayable.  Also, the game feels a bit short with a limited number of enemies; hoping the team returns to this game someday and it gets the Binding of Isaac treatment.

Positive:
To help with people struggling, this isn't about matching 4 tiles and you win.  At its core, it's actually about intelligent resource management.  Knowing what spells to cast when and how to extend your turn as long as possible.  If you're being damaged, you're doing something wrong (or you have bad luck when building your deck)!

I also appreciate how each character forces you to approach the game wildly different.  Tactics vary from straight up "Match 4" to "Use spells and only spells this whole run".

Lastly, the music/sound/design all feel right at home in the Isaac universe.  Incredible work.

TLDR;
If you like strategy games, you'll love this.  If not, it can feel unfair at times and be frustrating.  Just stick with it and it'll grow on ya. | I actually really like this game. It's engaging to play and provides a good amount of challenge.
The visuals are fun and I enjoy the added lore the TBOI that you get with this.

But I just cannot endorse it with how buggy it is even years after launch.

I had to install a mod just to get achievements to sync properly with the game progression.
And several times I've had to manually quit the game because it froze in the middle of a run.
(Which the game punishes you for by restarting the last encounter with several curse tiles :))) )
There's also several visual glitches that occur every once in a while.

Nice artstyle, interesting graphics, whats there to hate | Going Under is a parody of modern society and capitalism. The setting, characters and jokes are funny, but in a quite depressing way. The game is a roguelike, but unlike other games in the genre, you don't have to die a million times to understand the game, which is nice. However, I did find it very challenging at some points. What atracted me to this game was the artstyle, as you may have noticed Going Under uses the style known as corporate Memphis, which is used by every corporation on Earth to sell an image of inclusion and friendliness in a very soulless way. On the other hand, this game feels very soul-full, so I'm very happy to have played it and I recommend it to anyone feeling down about the inevitable collapse of modern society.

Based on the ratings it already has, this game clearly has an audience that loves it. Personally I got it because I liked "Papers, Please" and this was recommended as being similar. I don't find it very similar at all.

I found the design and presentation to be perfectly fine and attractive and all that.

Rather than tear apart a perfectly serviceable project with opinions that almost nobody will read, I'll simply say that the gameplay loop didn't work for me. I gave it a full 28 day in-game cycle, just to be sure, but ultimately it left me uninspired to give it another cycle. Given that the developers clearly intend for the player to take several passes at it, and I'm left feeling more like I'll never get those two and a half hours back, I can't recommend it.

å¥½ç©ï¼Œå‰§æƒ…å’Œå…³å¡å¾ˆæ–°å¥‡ï¼Œåˆšå¼€å§‹ç©çš„æ—¶å€™ä¸ç”¨å°å¿ƒç¿¼ç¿¼ï¼Œé™¤éçœ‹æ”»ç•¥èµ°æ­£ç¡®è·¯çº¿ï¼Œè¦ä¸ç„¶éƒ½å¤§å·®ä¸å·® | What I enjoyed:
At first I started this game trying to go in blind. I greatly enjoyed playing the various cards and discovering various interactions and hidden away tidbits in each area and loved being rewarded when I completed small side jobs in each chapter with a new card that gave me new strategies. Plenty of parts of the game have various conclusions & ways to complete tasks that make it fun. Bribe, boast, threaten, discourage or simply defeat enemies during combat, lots of fun routes to play. Sometimes there are even story related resolutions to a conflict via certain items. Some events end differently depending on the items you have on hand or number of pursuers, an early example is the prison break having a satisfyingly obvious difference between having pursuers VS no pursuers. You can even be rewarded depending on how well you perform certain story events. The game has certain consequences along the story as well if you rack up a body count. The game is designed to be played multiple times through each avenue to reach the finish line, and certain knowledge previously obtained helps make future runs easier (figuratively & literally, as prison break has multiple entrances and one can literally be recalled in game and is given as a card item).

What I hated:
There is no skip dialogue or cut-scene button, and for a game that is LITERALLY about replay-ability this is fairly unacceptable. And considering a release date of 2022 that issue isn't likely to be resolved. To top it all off, if you BEAT the game, your save becomes disabled for some insane reason and it simply says congratz thanks for playing (so bear that in mind for true ending pursuit, or lookup how to copy over your save and finish it on a secondary file). Some routes have only a single conclusion to reach, and if you lack the cards to get there or don't understand you might replay a chapter over and over again being stuck and walking in circles not understanding the objective. While you do unlock new cards, they are only for THAT RUN, meaning even tho the games story literally circles back until you reach the "true ending" you lose those new abilities. I personally found this disappointing as getting new tricks only to lose them feels bad.

What I recommend:
If you purchase this game, understand that unless you follow the guide on the forum you WILL fail a few missions or intentionally restart them. And you will have to sit through some dialogue you've already heard until you can get back to the fun. There is lots of fun finding where cards can be used, conventionally and unconventionally (elephant sneeze) and it honestly feels very well thought out in some area's and not so much in others. Near the end you WILL find some "not so obvious" clauses that, so far as i've seen, have only one proper resolution. There is only one walkthrough for this game that I have found and its not all encompassing but DOES get you to the finale, so even if you get frustrated with walking circles you will have a cheat sheet, don't hesitate to use it.

The game is fun, but unless the developer finally decides to fix the lack of dialogue & cut-scene skip for something you will see multiple times, its definitely not for everyone. I would very much recommend the game, but definitely understand "what" you are getting does have a few missing key features and poor design choices in general & later chapters (some are my opinion, some are factual "why is this feature missing"). | å¥½ç©ï¼Œé£æ ¼ç±»ä¼¼è·‘å›¢æ¡Œæ¸¸ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æ¢ç´¢ä¸åŒåœ°ç‚¹å’Œå®ƒä»¬äº§ç”Ÿäº¤äº’ã€‚ç¼ºç‚¹æ˜¯å›æ¡£åŠŸèƒ½åœ¨ç»“å±€å‡ºç°åå°±ä¸èƒ½ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æœ‰æ—¶å‰§æƒ…çªç„¶ç»“æŸï¼Œäº§ç”Ÿå¤§é‡é‡å¤å·¥ä½œã€‚ | I really like this game for his gimmicks. To anyone wanting to play this game but worried about the difficulty being too high:
The "assisted mode" is a great way to play though all the content without being frustrated by particularly difficult levels. If you're not great at pure action game but still want to experience The Ambassador because you think the art style or time ability is awesome, don't worry there's a mode for you! This is how I've chosen to play the game.

To anyone wanting to play this game but worried about the difficulty being too low:
There's a hard mode available after finishing the game on standard and each map has a challenge time to beat that is going to take some serious skill to beat. I don't think there's a lot to worry about if you want a challenge. | This is just such a simplistic game, I don't see why it's rated so highly.. and it costs $15 to top it off?!

The combat is boring and repetitive. The gameplay doesn't seem to go anywhere special. For a game from 2020 this is unacceptable for me.

The loop is literally "Here are some enemies, go chase them all and click with your mouse on them". "You finished it. Here is the next level.". "Do this a few more times until you get to the boss". "Click on the boss when the red sword comes up". "Rinse and repeat".

Yea, no thanks.

Among the top roguelike games I've played. Unlocks are expansive and get really fun when combining abilities and boons from different quirky characters that show up over time. | Top tier roguelite. Should be talked about alongside Isaac/Dead Cells/Gungeon. Loads of unlocks/secrets/content.

Only major complaint is that it's another game in the genre that's afraid to let you feel overpowered. My favorite thing about Binding of Isaac is having runs with insanely strong combos/synergies (or just overall damage) and the second you walk into a room everything dies. 18 hours into this game and I'm yet to have anything close to that. You can definitely feel strong and have a high winrate, but you still need to be locked in for the final boss fight of a run. A 2.5% damage increase will never be exciting, let me feel powerful.

If you're a fan of the genre though, definitely try this one out. ĞŸĞ¾Ñ„Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒÑ Ğ·Ğ´ĞµÑÑŒ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğµ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾) | This game is incredible, I see people saying the game isn't balanced right for two players but my friend and I made it to the end on every single run we played and even won one. And we were both playing mage on the one we won. Team composition doesn't seem as important as synergy between each other's builds. We were constantly moving bad guys around and detonating bombs to stun and hurt them. I can't recommend this game more than enough. It's challenging, has 5 classes, and a lot of rewards. It is basically co op slay the spire with more tactical combat.

The game itself has potential but where it falls down is how outdated the game design feels and the AI control over your units. It harkens back to an era of micromanagement of unit abilities which we really should have moved beyond. I don't find it personally enjoyable to have to babysit my infantry units telling them when to use their grenades or other such basic combat abilities. Realistically that sort of micromanagement should be toggleable or in cases where it's not limited by resource but is time delayed by cooldowns should be automatic. 

I've also come across serious AI issues in which sometimes I would tell three rifle units to attack move and on seeing the enemy well within range they will continue to move rather than stop and fight. In those cases I mention their firing lanes were not blocked. On other occasions where their firing lanes were blocked they did indeed stop and contributed nothing to the fight. This has led to me losing pushes when I was counting on that to function properly in taking an area I knew they only had warriors while I focused on retaking a bigger fight. The end result being the fight which should have been a clear victory instead resulted in my troops being annihilated because I could not micro manage two fights simultaneously.

If these two key things are improved - AI and the abilities - I can see this being much enjoyable and a recommend for those interested in this sort of game. | Thoroughly enjoyed the main campaign, sadly lacking replay value. Glad the devs have committed to adding a mode specifically designed for replay. | Man, the ai in this game is dumb as a box of rocks. You cannot leave them alone for a single nano-second. The fact that you cannot fire and move with 90% of the units means you have to stagger your assaults. One unit moves up to cover the next unit moving up and so on, if you try giving orders to your whole army youll just end up having them slowly walk forward into the arms of the bugs while not firing. I like the concept of staggering your approaches more than I like it in execution because you will inevitably run into a situation where youre moving up some of your units while one or more cover the rear only to realize that in the 3 seconds it took to move up said units, a tanker bug came around a corner and instantly killed a full rifle squad, and your recruitment base is on the other side of the map so youre SOL. I know it's sacrilegious to say but this game really would benefit from a pause or slow time feature. "But then it wouldnt be an RTS" Shut up they have it in Terminator: Dark Fate and that game slaps.

Idk I wish steam had a "Meh" review option because I do really like this game, its thematic and really does a good job of capturing the essence of Starship Troopers. The levels are engaging, the enemy variety is good, and when it works, it WORKS you feel great after accomplishing a task because the entire time its an uphill battle. I suppose if I could summarize my experience with the game in one word I would use "Frustrating". | If you enjoy the franchise than you will love this game...The only negative I have is I wish it had a skirmish mode or conquest mode | One of the worst RTS games I think I've ever had the displeasure of playing. The balance is bad and the AI is just downright stupid. Your soldiers will just walk into bugs half the time with attack move if you don't babysit them.

Ã‰ uma mina de ouro para mim. | This is a Visual Novel with a Political theme to it, not an actual Political Simulator. Once you've accepted that, it's a very good Visual Novel about building the "Story" of the character you take charge of.

If you come in with the expectation that you'll be able to do your own thing the way you want them to, like any PoliSim, then prepare to be disappointed. Choices are limited to a select number of options with little degree of variance and you can only tackle issues as they come up, as the story demands. You do not have the ability to proactively decide when or how to handle various issues because as mentioned before, this is a Visual Novel, not a Political Simulator.

As a Visual Novel, is it any good? It's okay, but nothing extraordinary. More variety in routes and endings stemming from past choices would make this more memorable, but the variations are only mild, enough to see some change,  but not significant enough to completely alter the trajectory. That, and the story has tendencies to throw "gotcha" moments near the end that force you to steer your character in a specific direction very early on unless you like repeating the same ending for a dozen playthroughs.

 | A 8/10 text adventure game, probably the best political simulation game on Steam

+ Excellent writing
+ Interesting plot
+ Great UI design

- The economic part is confusing, no clear indicator of growth trend and limited policy tool, everything seems fine then suddenly you are in a deep recession
- While it's a good thing to have many in-game geopolitical events that mirror the 20th century in our world, it breaks my suspension of disbelief when there's a cold war stand off between the East and West, a League of Nations/UN like international organization, but there are no fictional WWI and WWII equivalent that leads to such scenario just like in our world. It feels like forcing a 1950 world setting onto a 19th century Europe

I respect Supergiant going for a non-traditional game, not your usual fight enemies and bosses till you win. As usual for them the art and music and setting are just spectacular. | To this day, I think the experience I had playing Pyre was the absolute pinnacle of all of the gaming I've done in my 50+ years.  I literally only played a single playthrough (hence my few hours), but it was such a pure, beautiful experience that I never touched it again out of fear of lessening the impact.

The music, the story... God, these folks know how to make  a GAME. | Lore detallado con mitologia interesante, una banda sonora muy bien trabajada y personajes con personalidades bien caracterizadas.
El gameplay es original y bastante entretenido, yo lo jugue en la dificultad mas alta disponible al principio y hubo un par de contrincantes que resultaron verdaderamente un desafio.
El como es llevada la historia puede ser un tanto tedioso debido a la alta cantidad de dialogos que tiene el juego, personalmente no me gusta mucho pero entiendo que el genero al que pertenece se desarrolla asi comunmente.
Plantea tomas de desiciones interesantes y te te atrapa con el como procedera la historia ya que este parece variar bastante dependiendo del resultado en los enfrentamientos, los cuales son muchos. Personalmente quitaria la opcion de reiniciar los enfrentamientos ya que le daria mas emocion al tener que ganar para lograr los resultados deseados.
En sintesis, disfrute mucho el gameplay, esta muy bien pensado y es divertido el dominar todas las formas que tnes de jugar con cada personaje, resulto tedioso en los momentos de mucho texto y personalmente no termine aprendiendo mucho del lore ya que para hacerlo se debe leer una gran cantidad de texto (opcional) para enterarte. Los personajes son entraÃ±ables y te encariÃ±as facilmente con ellos.
Divertido para pasar el tiempo.

This game is really fun ...at first.

But then it's unintuitive "realistic" controls get in the way, the harder levels just aren't fun to play and the controls aren't fun to master. The assist options aren't quite good enough to compensate either. The slow down mechanic isn't usable when going for speed medals. The grab assist mode is just a bad targeting ai that points at the nearest grabable and often lands you in awkward positions. If the controls could be toggled from always relative to body position to relative to the game world, or even make it so just the arms/shoulders have this ability then it could be really good.

While I appreciate the character DLCs, I don't really like the direction this game has taken for replayability. Having seasonal mechanics tacked on seems like the easy approach but doesn't add much to the overall game. They really should take the Dead Cells model with the stage scheming and add more branching zones and tilesets to make things feel fresh. Add more variety to the rooms per stage, like with the recent anxi desert change. Stick to one overarching mechanic that players can keep grinding on instead of adding seasonal ones that shift character useability and run approach every 4 months.

Subsequent updates also seem to be introducing some lag to the game. Tabbing out, even in singleplayer makes the game hang for a split second. Entering one room in multiplayer after someone else causes the game to hang at times. If the devs really do want to stick to the seasonal plan, then expand the skins to include the characters as well and make them limited to events! Soul essence is already a persistent currency that players can acquire with a grind. | I've sunk a few hundred hours into this game; once you grasp the connections between guns, abilities, and scrolls, it becomes  seriously addicting. I've played every season variation, and the way star link expands upon your character build is the most fun yet. I can easily justify $20 due to the amount of content it offers. | I didn't give this game much thought until I started playing it. The game is a well-made rogue-lite that's fun to play. The experience is even better with friends, up to three people, or you can find online matches.
I've highlighted 3 points that I think are important to mention:

Seasons
The season system is well-made. I've only played the last 2 seasons. At first, it's hard to understand the mechanics, but you get the hang of it over time. You just have to pay close attention to the readings, but they're very fun and varied. The season pass is free, easy and quick to get, and gives you beautiful and well-made cosmetics, which is a very positive point.

Replayability
I particularly enjoyed replaying the game. Putting on a playlist to listen to while playing is a pleasant experience. The game has many achievements and some of them require time and effort to complete, a huge variety of weapons to unlock, which gives a great feeling when you get a new weapon, in days when in any game you have to keep paying to get new things in the game (the game has 3 DLC with weapons, but the game also adds free weapons in each season).

Game modes
The game has few modes, only three, being the conventional mode, the main game mode where you have the stages and their difficulty to choose and challenge yourself and it is in this mode that you unlock most of the weapons and achievements in the game. The daily challenge mode, nothing special, the name already says what it is, a mode with a modifier that changes daily, just to get some achievements and challenge yourself. And the last mode, the horde mode, is a mode where you can equip some improvements to your characters and fight against large hordes of enemies that get harder and harder over time, but it has a final boss, so the hordes end. It's fun, but it only has two maps so far, and it ends up being repetitive.

My final thoughts are that the game is worth it for those who like games of this style, it's very different and diverse from the others. For the base game I think the price is worth it, but for the DLC I think it's worth waiting for a sale.

Everhood is one of my new favorite RPGs. This is a game that wants to offer you a new experienceâ€”and it delivers!

Everhood is an existential, musical-psychedelic game where battles take place on a bullet-hell rhythm track. On the surface, it seems like an Undertale-like, but only in the same sense that Undertale is an Earthbound-like. As the player, you control a wooden doll who resembles Geno. At the beginning of the game, your arm is stolen, and you are sent on a quest to retrieve it... but it is not so simple.

The battles in Everhood are my favorite part of the game. The simple concept of dodging notes on a rhythm track is built upon and constantly remixed during the experience. The battles are choreographed to music (which is great), as one would expect from a rhythm-based game. You will particularly enjoy the music if you are into bass. Certain battles can become quite psychedelic and distorted, as though time, purpose (â€œwhy are you here?â€), and the whole universe are dilatingâ€”fitting the theme of 'immortality' and giving the player a radical experience.

Everhoodâ€™s plot is interesting, though difficult to understand. Sadly, because Everhood is shorter than it needs to be, we do not learn much about the characters. The player is also not given enough time to grow attached to them, lessening the impact of emotional beats in Everhoodâ€™s late-game. The same applies to the world-buildingâ€”many players might finish Everhood feeling confused, as information is given in bits and pieces. My last complaint is that a certain choice in the game is shoehorned as the 'correct' choice, but it can only be weakly justified in retrospect. These are my only issues with the game (it is too short!).

For players who want a challenge or to experience more gameplay, you can find alternate endings with difficult boss fights. One of the bosses was so tough that I ended up lowering my difficulty settings. For experienced gamers who want an extra challenge, you can, of course, crank the difficulty up. As of right now, I am tempted to replay Everhood to achieve the no-hit achievements and experience the game all over again. The brevity of Everhood can be a positive, in that the replay value is quite high.

Everhood was a very memorable experience. You may even feel like jumping back into it after you complete it!

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
Reviews:
Stay away from this game, Go join a game that doesn't try to dumps your wallet well over fifty dollars every month for misc items then just a Subscription.
-This game has an OK community
-The issue is the Devs, trying to dump hundreds of outfits to whales to sale to a very inflated market
-The Devs have also backstabbed several times the community
-Making a Gunslinger after stating they would NOT make a gun class(Nice)
-If you want to play this game, DO NOT SPEND MONEY.
-The community is mostly dying as less and less people fight world bosses on NA, it use to be an all server wide thing but now only a hand full. | DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME.

Developers are completely out of touch, servers as unstable as the Somalian economy. They make promises they never keep or if they keep them its years after they said they would do it. Really wish I could recommend it but I can't. | As fun as the gameplay is, that's like literally the only compliment i can give it outside of the game looking beautiful, it's a sadistic grindfest that is so unbelievably overwhelming for any player, i have 200 hours and i still have zero clue what im doing because i am being constantly bombarded with new items and systems that by the time i get a grasp on one thing, i have to learn 5 more new things. | I didn't really doing anything in the first 6 hours and ended up with a full inventory of stuff... just stuff. The combat early on seems pointless as you can be surrounded by 20 mobs and take no damage. The graphics in the game are quirky with a ton of lighting issues making the game look awful most of the time. The user interface is horrid with overlays overlaying other overlays upon more overlays... it's a mess visually. Why would I want to get notified of other players failing crafting when I am just starting the game? It's a UX/UI designers nightmare. Early story and quests are meh. If I were to summarize my new experience, I wouldn't say it was "bad", I would say it's "a turn off". | Black Desert Online has one of the best early and mid-game experiences. Progress feels rewarding, the world is vast and fun to explore, and there's a real sense of discovery. However, the late game is a completely different story.

Once you hit the late-game grind, progression slows down dramatically, taking anywhere from 20 to 100 hours just to see any improvement. Season characters are a great addition, but they also remove the early game entirely by handing out free PEN gear, which can feel like skipping one of the best parts of the game.

The biggest issue is how demanding the late game is, both in time and money. The game leans heavily into pay-to-win mechanicsâ€”you can buy Crons, making enhancement much less painful for those willing to spend money. While Black Desert has an incredible combat system and PvP is amazing, there's just not enough meaningful PvP content in the open world.

Overall, Black Desert isnâ€™t a terrible game, but the late-game grind and monetization model make it hard to recommend unless you're ready to sink an absurd amount of time (or money) into it.

Sehr befriedigendes brettspielartiges Strategieerlebnis. Mir gefÃ¤llt besonders, dass es ein Aufbauspiel ohne militÃ¤rische Komponente ist. Jede Art Planet hat "Rezepte", wie man ihn nutzen kann, wenn man ihn kolonisiert. Es geht darum, ein florierendes Netzwerk zwischen den Planeten aufzubauen. 

Dabei gibt's eine Vielzahl von Problemen zu managen: Am Anfang fragt man sich, lieber schnell etwas zum Laufen bringen, um frÃ¼hes Geld zu verdienen oder lieber erst die ganze Umgebung entdecken, um die Konstellationen zu optimieren? Im mittleren Spiel sollte man neben den klassischen Strategie-Dilemmas (zuerst Wirtschaft ausbauen oder Forschung?) immer auch die bestehende Infrastruktur im Blick haben - oft entstehen im Spielverlauf noch MÃ¶glichkeiten zur Verbesserung. Und gegen Spielende willst Du immer mehr expandieren, aber ab einer gewissen Anzahl Planeten wird alles exorbitant teuer. 

Hohe Varianz durch die Auswahl der VÃ¶lker beim Spielstart. Die VÃ¶lker haben eine klare IdentitÃ¤t (auf welche Spielmechaniken und Spielstile sie sich beziehen), aber in jeder Partie bieten sie eine andere Auswahl an Technologien aus ihrem Pool an. Dadurch spielen sich die Partien vom Anfang bis Schluss sehr unterschiedlich.
Im Standardmodus gibt es zusÃ¤tzlich noch "Modifikatoren", die die Eigenschaften der Karte verÃ¤ndern, auf der man spielt. Die sollte man fÃ¼r die ersten Runden erstmal ausschalten, weil das Grundspiel schon abwechslungsreich genug ist. Wenn man das Spiel besser kennt, sind sie sicher eine willkommene Abwechslung.
Es gibt auch eine Kampagne mit etwas mehr Story, aber ich finde den Standardmodus eigentlich genau richtig! | It's fun. I like it. It's the sort of space-based resource management game that appeals to my brain. Getting things to work is very satisfying! Not having that ONE RESOURCE you need within range is VERY FRUSTRATING! It's a good game to start up when you want to play SOMETHING and aren't sure what. Standard runs are pretty quick. There's still plenty of the game that I haven't interacted with, yet, at 10 hours in. If it looks like the sort of thing you would also like, I highly recommend it. | Love it!
Much more a puzzle than a 4X game.
Interesting mechanics, high replay value.
I absolutely recommend it.
Scalable UI makes it perfect for gaming on the Steam Deck.
(Search YouTube for better tutorials though.) | The game seems simple at first but optimizing for maximum efficiency is very tricky and satisfying to learn. Discovering all the interactions between mechanics has been very addicting and fun. Instantly one of my favorite games of all time. | Un bon jeu d'optimisation en environnement incertain. C'est paradoxalement un bon jeu de dÃ©tente oÃ¹ le fait de se casser la tÃªte n'a pas d'autre implication que d'avancer plus loin dans le temps et d'avoir un meilleur score. 
But du jeu: coloniser des planÃ¨tes pour obtenir des ressources, qui elles-mÃªme demandent des ressources. Il faudra donc explorer votre espace, coloniser des planÃ¨tes, puis les relier entre elles (sans croisement, d'oÃ¹ la difficultÃ©). Un fois Ã©tablie, de nouvelles ressources sont demandÃ©es, etc.
Le retour dans le temps permet aussi de faire des tests si on est pas sÃ»r Ã  100% de notre coup, ou si on fait une erreur (attention cependant, il n'est valable que si les inconnues le reste, donc pas d'exploration). Les parties sont assez courtes (entre 1 et 2 heures selon votre rÃ©flexion), et la rejouabilitÃ© assez Ã©norme (entre les bonus de races, les technologies, les types de systÃ¨mes et les anomalies si on les actives, on a de quoi faire).

En bref, un bon jeu de rÃ©flexion (d'optimisation) qui vous fera perdre la notion du temps.

Amazing story, interesting resourcce managment system. I liked it even more than frostpunk! | After watching The Terror season 1 way too many times and having this game on my wishlist forever, I finally decided to buy it. It does not disappoint to get that dreadful cold, environmental feel when playing it. Getting stuck in the ice where the world is trying to kill you.

It is a great story, survival-management game where you have to balance several things at once. The survival basics of heat, food, and the health and morale (decorum in this case) of your crew. On top of this, you also need to balance the loyalty of the certain members of the crew for certain end-game events and endings. Your choices will matter as it will affect the loyalty of your crew, certain events may arise throughout the story based on your actions or inaction (pay attention to what your crew tells you), and of course it will affect your endings.

It has plenty of replayability with different endings and achievements to go after. I would say your first playthrough will last around ten hours, but once you know how things work and what lies ahead after playing it once, you could probably breeze through most of the game to get to certain endings and get achievements if that is what you are after.

Rating: 8.5/10

Overview: Tomb Raider (2013) is a reboot of the classic action-adventure franchise, offering a fresh origin story for the legendary adventurer Lara Croft. Developed by Crystal Dynamics, the game takes a more grounded and gritty approach to Lara's character, portraying her transformation from a vulnerable young woman into the hardened explorer she's known for. Combining exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat, the 2013 iteration offers a blend of action and survival mechanics set on the mysterious island of Yamatai.

Story: The story follows Lara Croft, who, along with her crew, becomes stranded on the island of Yamatai while searching for the lost kingdom of Himiko. The island, however, is home to many dark secrets, including a dangerous cult and other perils that put Laraâ€™s life in constant jeopardy. Throughout the game, Lara faces various challenges and fights to survive, all while uncovering the islandâ€™s mysteries and discovering her own strength.

The narrative is engaging, focusing on Lara's personal journey and her development as a character. The story touches on themes of survival, trust, and the cost of discovery, with the stakes rising as Lara delves deeper into the islandâ€™s secrets. The characters are well-developed, though the focus is primarily on Lara, making her transformation and growth the heart of the plot.

Gameplay: Tomb Raider (2013) brings a mix of exploration, platforming, puzzle-solving, and combat. The controls are smooth and accessible, with an emphasis on both exploration and action. As Lara navigates the island, players engage in intense combat against various enemies, including mercenaries, wild animals, and the islandâ€™s cultists. The combat system is robust, offering a variety of weapons, from bow and arrows to firearms, as well as a range of stealth and melee attacks.

The game also features light RPG elements, allowing players to upgrade Laraâ€™s weapons and abilities as they progress. This adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, encouraging players to explore the island thoroughly to collect resources and improve their equipment. There are also collectible items and hidden treasures scattered throughout the game, rewarding those who take the time to explore off the beaten path.

Graphics and Performance: The graphics in Tomb Raider (2013) are exceptional, with lush environments, stunning character models, and impressive lighting effects. The island of Yamatai is beautifully designed, ranging from treacherous cliffs to dense jungles, all rendered in high detail. The character animations, particularly Laraâ€™s, are lifelike, and the facial expressions convey emotion and intensity. The cinematic cutscenes are integrated seamlessly into the gameplay, making the narrative feel fluid and immersive.

The game runs smoothly on most modern systems, with well-optimized performance. On higher settings, the visuals are breathtaking, but even at lower settings, the game still maintains a high level of quality.

Audio Design: The audio design in Tomb Raider is excellent, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that complements the gameâ€™s tone. The sound effects are realistic, from the sounds of Laraâ€™s footsteps on different surfaces to the crackling of fire and distant roars of danger. The voice acting, particularly from Camilla Luddington as Lara Croft, is solid, adding depth to the characterâ€™s emotions as she faces peril after peril.

Challenges: While the game is generally well-balanced, some sections can feel a bit repetitive, especially in terms of combat. Some of the puzzles are relatively simple, and while they provide a nice break from the action, they donâ€™t challenge players too much. The difficulty ramps up during some of the more intense sequences, especially during the combat-heavy portions, but overall, the game provides an enjoyable experience without being overwhelmingly difficult.

Final Thoughts: Tomb Raider (2013) successfully reinvents the franchise, offering a modern and more personal take on Lara Croftâ€™s origin story. The game blends action, exploration, and survival mechanics into a thrilling adventure, with a great narrative that makes you care about Laraâ€™s journey. Its visuals, gameplay mechanics, and immersive world design make it a standout entry in the action-adventure genre.

Pros:

Engaging story with strong character development
Beautiful graphics and immersive world design
Satisfying combat mechanics with a variety of weapons
Excellent audio and voice acting
Exploration and collectibles add depth to gameplay
Cons:

Combat can become repetitive
Some puzzles are relatively easy
Certain sections of the game feel linear
Tomb Raider (2013) is a fantastic reboot that blends classic Tomb Raider elements with modern gameplay features. It offers an emotionally engaging and thrilling adventure for players who enjoy action, exploration, and survival mechanics. I bought my copy tonight and played the tutorial and a full game against the AI. I think there are some opportunities for DAISU but overall the gameplay itself is solid.

Opportunities:
- Tiles could be clearer on zoom in. I like that the text is there, but I want to explore the art on those tiles too. I want a button to do a big zoom like I can do on Tabletop Simulator or Tabletopia.
- The tutorial has text that cannot be sped up and it doesn't always fit in the text bubble. That needs to be a) easily skippable and b) fit in the text bubble. I know you need to read the text, but you shouldn't be guessing how fast I can read. I can read much faster than the "next" text arrow appears.
- Play Local has New Game and Tutorial buttons that appear to be greyed out, but they aren't. And you're supposed to click them.
- When playing with AI, you can't see what your partner drew/chose for use in your castle, so you can't synergize with them. This led to me making decisions for my castle in a vacuum.
- I finished the second tutorial, but it never acknowledged I finished it. It just wouldn't accept feedback anymore and I had to hit escape and 'exit' to go back to the menu.
- Music sometimes behaves odd. Leaving the tutorial to the main menu made the music abruptly stop and then go to a new music track. Perhaps a fade out and fade in would be less jarring.
- The green "Ok" or select button is an odd design choice, it doesn't feel like it matches the same aesthetic of the rest of the game, but I find myself punching the spacebar to accept my changes anyway. It's not a real big deal.

All of that said, I really enjoyed my time with BTCoMKL. The beta was ROUGH on my PC, it was very choppy, very jerky, this has been completely resolved. It runs so quick and it says all settings are on Epic despite me not having a gaming laptop at all. It's a cheap Dell my father-in-law bought that I put a SSD in.
Everything I love about BTCoMKL is still here in the PC version except for the plotting and planning with my partner. BUT it did feel significantly better to crap on one of my castles to try and take the lead from the AI who had the lead.

I like how quick the gameplay was. It was a delight. I hope the online lobby picks up. I think the price for the game was fair too. Of course I always find myself wanting to wait for a Steam sale but I'm not much of a PC gamer, so I typically have no problem waiting. That said, I don't regret not waiting. Congratulations Team Daisu.

Oh, one more item of delight I wanted to mention.. I love how adding tiles to the castle actually causes the castle to grow behind you. You see walls come up and towers rise. It's a very neat effect that made me smile a couple of times. Also, great job identifying the castles by color. That made it very easy to identify which castle I was working with. | Actually, the only way I would play this game is through this app: unlike the board game, this digital version permanently displays your and your opponents' score throughout the entire game.  In the board game you had no idea how well you or your opponents are doing, except until the very end.  This digital version totally solves that.  I own the physical game, but I will provably almost never play it again, unless one of my friends desperately requests it. And finally, the interface of this (digital) game and the overall design is done near-perfectly. I had a lot of fun playing this game on my steamdeck while traveling but I will 100% say this game feels kind of unfinished and poorly balanced. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from trying to figure out how to win on the harder difficulties with each character in spite of the poor balancing. 

It's definitely a neat concept that I havent seen done before and I enjoyed discovering neat combinations of tiles on the map like Village + Vampire Manor = Vampire Town. But I wish there was more of that. There should be dozens and dozens of combinations and interactions, but there's really not. It feels like there's content waiting to be implemented but it just never came. 

It's got some soft "gambling" elements in that you can end runs early to cash in your treasure or you can always go for another loop or attempt a boss in an all-or-nothing kind of way. It's a cute townbuilder, in a similar vein to rimworld or dwarf fortress. The main feature that sets it apart is its economy, where every household needs to buy/sell to get the food/clothes/goods they need.

While the game mechanics themselves are explained decently enough (though often lacking in the minor details), the game doesn't present nearly enough information to allow the player to understand the consequences of those mechanics and make any informed decisions. The issue is that the game has a lot of small moving parts, and the UI doesn't give the player the tools to get a clear picture of what is happening and why. 

Just as some examples:
- My carpenter family was repeatedly going bankrupt, despite having (more than) enough work to do. The game doesn't give any quick overview of how much income they have and where their money is going, making it rather challenging to understand why they're having money problems. While it's theoretically possible to track the individual sales/purchases they're making, this is isn't really practically viable for a player to actually do because you also need to be doing other things.
- There's no real tools to get a good overview of the production in your town. Am I producing enough food? Way too much/little? I've no idea. A simple screen that just counts up all of the food/goods production/consumption would make it much easier to know why something is/isn't happening.
-Every family in your town pays taxes to you every season, in the form of money or produced goods. The game gives you no way to know how much money/goods was paid to you in the last season, or will be paid to you in the next season. Theoretically you could go over each individual zone and tally up the totals, but this gets unfeasible if you've got 50+ zones.

The game is riddled with this type of interface problem, where there's a ton of small actions happening, and there's no aggregate information that lets the player get the big picture of what is happening. This in turn makes it impossible to make informed decisions about, f.e. whether to add some family of craftsmen to the town because I've no idea whether there's enough raw-goods production to support them.

A second issue is that economy-simulation isn't quite working, leading to things like a profitable family just piling on the money without having anything they can spend it on. Or some professions that produce goods that you need for a couple constructions but have not sustained demand, leading a family with barely any income. | nice game with good clony mechanics havent plaid alot or do a war but is good for me | ä¼˜åŒ–ä¸€ä¸‹ å¤ªå¡äº† | Do you want to do 20 hours of tutorial scenarios where they insist on you doing the same thing over and over again? Okay, so I went into Cult of the Lamb expecting some cute, mindless dungeon crawling.  What I got was a surprisingly deep and emotionally engaging experience. Yes, it's adorable â€“ the art style is fantastic, the little lamb protagonist is charming, and the followers are undeniably cute.  The dungeon crawling is fun, challenging enough to be engaging without being frustrating.  I actually really enjoyed the combat; it's simple but effective, and finding new weapons and abilities kept me coming back for more.
 
But the real hook? The cult management.  I'm not gonna lie, I got way too attached to my followers.  I named them all, I built them the best houses, I made sure they were always fed and happy.  And then...I sacrificed some of them to eldritch gods.  It was necessary for the greater good of the cult, of course, but it still felt...bad.  The game cleverly plays on that emotional tug-of-war, making you care about your followers even as you're making difficult choices that affect their fate.
 
The strategic element of managing resources, keeping morale high, and balancing the needs of your cult with the demands of dungeon crawling was surprisingly intricate and rewarding.  I found myself constantly tweaking my strategies, trying to optimize everything for maximum cult growth and happiness.  It's a surprisingly addictive loop.
 
While the repetitive nature of the dungeon runs might bore some players after a while, the constant upgrades and the ever-evolving needs of my cult kept me hooked.  Overall, Cult of the Lamb exceeded my expectations.  It's a unique blend of cute and creepy, strategic and emotional.  Highly recommended, but be prepared for some unexpected feelings along the way. | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° ĞºÑ€ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ» Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°  Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ¸ . Please fix it! | I do not gravitate to automation and factory games due to generally the levels of complexity, the moving parts and the sheer amount of things you have to do in them to get a working, self sufficient, well optimised factory. While I thought Shapez would be the same kind of thing, I was delightfully surprised that after playing a handful of hours - Shapez gives you the bare bones of "Hey, here's a hub - put shapes in it". It isn't pretty, there is light and dark mode! 

What I really like about Shapez was the fact that although it clearly states "This is not an idle game", I can play it as slow or as fast as I want. Nothing is going to implode if I don't get 5,000 squares in the hub within a 10 minute window with the slowest belt making me start ALL OVER AGAIN. The only thing that happens is that it just takes more time. There's no pressure to need to get good at the game really, really quick or suffer. You as a player can do really whatever you want. Make the most complex, well optimised, efficient factory and find joy in that. Or be like me - take one thing at a time (generally) until you get the hang of it and then just run with it. 

This was a great introductory game to start me off in a genre of game that I generally steered clear of. 
I am very glad I got good at Shapez before really diving into Shapez 2. It gave me a solid start in understanding the beautiful upgrades Shapez 2 got and made me appreciate the growth from Shapez 1 to Shapez 2. I recommend this game to anyone - but in particular people that need to learn the foundations of factory building.

I went from playing about 10.5 hours to dumping 70+ hours within a week into this game. It's that good.  

Now, if you'll excuse me - I have a rocket to make. 
Go buy this game - and then it's awesome next title Shapez 2, right meow! | å¥½ç©ã€‚å¯¹äºä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆéœ€è¦æ­£åé¦ˆçš„ç©å®¶ç‰¹åˆ«å¥½ç©ã€‚

You want a platformer with imprecise controls that can randomly make you fail alongside the camera that give you the impression of difficulty and fights that base all on knockback and are not really that difficult? Then this is the game for you. And I come from many, more difficult and more enjoyable platformers that are still difficult even when giving the player precision even at high speed, be them paper styled like this one or not. I suppose I will go back searching for games with real challenging battles, were damage really count. And btw if someone wants a 3d platformer that has some slight and minor imprecision problems with some hitboxes from enemy hits but still has some really fun and engaging fights and share the same imprecision problem of the walljumps but with more fluid movements, play Blue Fire, it's so fun and still fluid that the problems won't matter and there's SO MUCH to explore in every corner of the areas of that game.
HOWEVER I must say that Demon Tides seems much more promising from the trailer so I look forward to it
Edit: I gave this game another try, just to find worse things unfortunately. The knockback that is what the "combat" of this game is about is more random the more you go forward, and the camera worsen the more mechanics are added to the game... while new gadgets should make everything more interesting while covering eventual game flaws with its fluidity, at least that's what happens in the other games. And most of all the mods bought with cakes... it's a miracle if they work as intended, it's like those animes where they sell someone a wonderful-looking gadget with even a video showcasing it and maybe it does in a very downgraded and almost useless way, literally a scam for the majority of them. At least Neon Splash tells you that the mods are just a little change in the gameplay of some moves, more than a real advantage, and they do how their description says, even without the need of a showcase.
P.s.: Demon Turf - Neon Splash seems to be already a great step forward towards more platforming precision though, it's still not that precise, but much better, so this gives me even more hope for Demon Tides, at least for the platforming side | Demon Turf is a 3-D platformer and feels like a first for the developers. It is pretty fun but also not necessarily that memorable. I chalk up this lack of memorability to 3 factors.

Bad first world syndrome: When coming with a theme for the first world in a platformer, desert is probably the worst choice you can make. Once you get past the first world you see some more interesting locales. I know some people think world 2 is bad but I liked the diversity that is in the beach level such as going up a volcano or exploring a sewage treatment plant. I would argue world 4: Plateau Peak is much worse as it's just so needlessly large to show off the new bird power-up you got. 

In other words, the world design is like a bell curve: bad first and and final worlds, really good 2nd and 3rd worlds. Additionally, needing to revisit worlds to unlock the final boss is tedious and unnecessary. I understand why showing us the aftermath of our actions could be good from a story-telling perspective, but it's not like you get to see or hear Beebs react to what she has done with the turfs.

Confusing hub world: I barely explored it except for finding things like the badge shop or the dye shop. It was just so confusing with very few noteworthy landmarks or signs.

Bad power-ups: The first and fourth power ups are awful. The first is a grappling hook that: only works on certain grapple points, and is the only way of beating the first boss which turns said boss into an autoscroller (not a good idea). The fourth power up isn't so bad but it's outshine by the wheel. 

The wheel power that you get at the end of world 2 is peak. It feels like you're able to just turn into a car whenever you want and go fast, like it's a 3-D sonic game.

Overall I wish I had more positives to say. The game I think is good but it has more glaring issues that you really need to squeeze past before you can enjoy it. | éŸ³ä¹ä¼˜ç§€ï¼Œå…³å¡è®¾è®¡ä¸é”™ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œäººç‰©è„šæ»‘çš„ä¸è¡Œï¼Œç¢°æ’ç®±ä¹Ÿä»¤äººè¿·æƒ‘ï¼Œä¾¿ç§˜ä¸€æ ·çš„å¹³å°è·³è·ƒæ‰‹æ„Ÿæ‰£å¤§åˆ†ã€‚æœ¬æ¥è¿˜ä¼°æ‘¸ç€èƒ½ç»™ä¸ªå¥½è¯„ï¼Œç»“æœä½ å¥–åŠ±å…¨æ”¶é›†æ¢å›¾çš„ç©å®¶é¬¼å›¾è·³è„¸ğŸ‘ï¼Œæˆ‘å¥–åŠ±ä½ ä¸ªå·®è¯„ã€‚ | If you're going to buy this game for anything, buy it for the two free DLCs (Neon Splash and Tower). The base game is a perfectly serviceable platformer and is fun for what it is, but it has some rough edges that make it a bit frustrating at time (mainly due to the awkward combat system and underutilized abilities). The two DLCs take a reworked approach to the controls that honestly fixes all of the biggest faults with the original game. The movement is fluid and gives you a ton of control over how you want to get through a level. The game and its DLCs aren't particularly strict on precision, but have a ton of movement options that allow you to really shmoove through their levels.

The Tower DLC in particular was something that I wasn't actually expecting to enjoy as much as I did. The DLC is different from the main game and Neon Splash in that it's a sorta roguelike challenge in that your goal is to ascend a 50-floor tower with the risk of falling down several floors or worse, dying and having to start all over. As you climb, you gain various movement abilities (as well as a few safeguards to protect you from dying), and you keep those even if you die. So if you do have to start back from floor 1, those abilities will make it far easy to speedrun your way back up. Even as someone who normally dislikes the "frustration platformer" genre, the movement in this game was more than enough to keep it enjoyable all the way through. | Hab das Spiel ein paar mal neu angefangen, aber die schwammige und teils ungenaue Steuerung zusammen mit der Kamera haben mich jedes Mal frustriert und ich hatte nach ein paar Level keine Motivation weiter zu spielen. Ich mag Herausforderungen, aber ohne kÃ¼nstliche Schwierigkeiten.

Wenn man auf 3D-Plattformer steht verpasst man nicht, wenn man Demon Turf auslÃ¤sst!

A fun roguelite turn-based tactics game with clever gameplay mechanics and a roster of unique characters to experiment with. With an appealing visual style, clever anti-stalling mechanics that are narratively justified, and multiple difficulty tiers make this an easy recommendation for fans of the genre!
My only nitpicks are some minor bugs (not every ability and capsule does exactly what it claims to do), some unclear tooltips (presumably due to translation errors), and a controversial mechanic on the final boss on the Eldritch timeline that - in my opinion - is both downright unfair and unbalanced.
But don't let those dissuade you from giving this game a go. You'll probably get between 15 and 30 hours of fun out of it, and at an affordable price!

It's rare but every now and then you find one of those special games that you know will stay with you, and Stray was one of them for me. Man, I don't even know where to start. The game is truly beautiful, I had to keep stopping just to snap screenshots. The story is emotionally beautiful (I might say beautiful a lot but oh well, describes the game perfectly  Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯) and it was just an enjoyable and beautiful experience from start to finish. 

No bugs or stutters, played perfectly on a middle of the road PC and you can tell there was so much love and care put into making this game. I'm not usually a fan of stealth but actually had fun with it in Stray when it came to those little stealth sections. This review is all over the place because I'm still emotional after finishing this BEAUTIFUL game.

[h3]Real Yakuza use a gamepad.[/h3]
There's (currently) two entry points to the Yakuza series. Yakuza 0 and Yakuza: Like a Dragon. However, they feature completely different combat systems. At the time of writing, I have only played a few hours of Yakuza 0 and this title. So I would consider this game to be my first. But you can't go wrong entering the series at either place, regardless.

[h3]Tradition â€” combat mechanics[/h3]
Much like the Yakuza culture, being steeped in tradition. This series has you normally playing as Kazuma Kiryu. With the games he's in being beat 'em ups. However, in Like a Dragon, you'll play as Ichiban Kasuga. Who is obsessed with Dragon Quest. No really. The whole game is turn-based because that's how he starts to envision fighting.

Moreover, the game is effectively a traditional JRPG set in a 'low-fantasy' setting. That said, the skills are secondary to the core of the combat, which is positioning and timing. This might sound odd in a turn-based game. Let me explain â€” the characters are always moving around each other. All mixed up. Enemies and party members alike. If you do a basic attack when there are enemies in the way, there is a significant chance you'll not only take damage from an opportunity attack, but you may be interrupted entirely. Making your turn completely wasted. So the core of the combat really comes down to selecting targets that are open to attack as everyone is moving around.

Of course, the combat is deeper than this, there are status effects, types of attack, melee, blade, etc. Resistances to the aforementioned. There is also a job system which can be leveled individually from character level. You're able to use some special attacks to avoid the chance of being interrupted by targeting enemies far away. I'm unsure if that was intentional, but I ended up doing it a lot.

There's also a mechanic to block attacks to mitigate damage, you must press the associated button right before the attack lands. It's a little like Super Mario RPG â€” that's what it reminded me of anyways. Some special abilities also have a timed button press to increase damage.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3419070558

[h3]There is a TON to do in this game.[/h3]
In spite of this, I did not find the game excessively grind-y. Given the genre, you might expect that. But you can do mini-games that are rather involved and some that are less involved. See movies with companions, build a relationship (bond) with them â€” this also increases your own chance for opportunity attacks as well as allow non-active party members to gain experience points.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3419070716

The city itself is teeming with life. While it feels oddly restrictive, in that you cannot really interact with the world, there's a ton of items and things to find though exploration. It can be rather rewarding.

Doing sub-stories will often gain you characters that can be used in other aspects. Typically either for â€œPoundmatesâ€, which act as summons in the combat, or for one of the more elaborate mini-games introduced as â€œIchiban Confectionsâ€. This one is unlocked a little later in the game. You'll run a business, manage employees and decide when to expand. There are even shareholder meetings which has an entirely different â€œcombatâ€ system.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3419070955

At one point I even traveled to the park just to collect bugs for the â€œPart-Time Heroâ€ side missions. There's some really, genuinely funny and enjoyable side stuff in this game.

[h3]Deck Specs[/h3]
This is gonna pull around almost the full 25W all the time. But it runs phenomenal on the deck. 800P native, no scaling â€” the game will run 35-60FPS depending on the area. But as the game is turn-based, this shouldn't effect much. I personally think it also looks very good on the OLED screen and I think that the JRPG genre is simply perfect for handhelds.

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
Fantastic story, good combat. Great entry point to the series. Very satisfying still if this is the only Yakuza game you play. I can't honestly say anything bad about it. The cutscenes can be a little long, I guess. I'd recommend it to everyone unless you truly just cannot stand JRPGs.

A strong visual novel with a gorgeous art style and interesting world. The actual gameplay aspect is very light as it mostly revolves around having conversations with other witches and your behemoth. You have limited time so you have to choose which people are most important to discuss with and what tasks they should be completing. The idea of covens of witches separate from the mortal coil was such an interesting setting to explore. Meeting witches from different eras of Earth as well as alien witches made me excited to meet new witches. The art design in this game is another strong positive from someone who is a sucker for a good pixel art game.  | It's ok, but not something I'd recommend. It's definitely pretty, but the gameplay aspect of it is pretty weak. The game keeps telling you how the stuff you do is important and has consequences, but it's hard to tell if just throwing things together in any random order make any difference at all. Old choices pop up in random conversations, but don't really have much impact. The game will find a way to shoehorn all the pieces where it wants them to be for the next scene. The writing is interesting at a surface level, but the story is not very coherent. Character motivations are weak and get pushed aside to set up dramatic scenes or fill the air. The only consistent and pervasive trait to the writing is that everyone is obsessed with interpersonal relationships. So you forged magic daggers to enslave a demon race and have them invade the dreams of your rival clan? Nvm that, tell me more about this guy you're dating.

Genres: Action, Casual, Free To Play, Indie, Sports, Strategy
Reviews: No Reviews

Fun and paced nicely, though I don't think its difficulty scales very well, even on the later days with more difficult mini games and supplementary patient illnesses. There are hard choices to make that suck away your resources, but with enough practice the mini games grow easy, even repetitive. Thus, the weight of your choices don't have a lot at stake. While I appreciate the visual design of Mind Scanners, its gameplay loop isn't quite as meaty as it could be. Nonetheless, the game does not overstay its welcome, so the repetition of what you're doing isn't as hard to swallow.

[spoiler]Regarding its story, you are again the sand in the machine of an evil fascistic regime, and the rebels make lots of mistakes that are I guess worth it in the end, but you never really see their interactions with the people of The Structure. You're mostly just told that the ruling class is oppressing everyone, and all you really know is that people get exiled for treason. I wish more games that feature a "movement of the people" showed more people.

While I found state-sponsored mental healthcare hilariously the most fantastical piece of the world, it feels like there's a disconnect between what you're doing and the goals of the state. It seems they would rather you erase the personalities of all your patients (who are potential threats to the state) but that also seems to remove their labor potential, which the state also requires to survive. The state doesn't seem to care one way or another if you're erasing personalities, it's just up to you if you want to go the extra mile. Surprisingly, for a game where you're against autocratic regime, there isn't enough conflict. From a gameplay perspective, it's mainly "do I have the ability to play mini games fast and well enough to avoid ruining peoples' lives?" The moral choices aren't weighty enough, probably because the focus is about rescuing your daughter, but a more antagonistic force that's more forthcoming with putting heavy decisions in front of you could've made this story stronger.[/spoiler] | Another clever dystopia simulator much like Papers Please. An immersive experience mostly due to its graphics and sounds, retrofuturistic interface framing the game's main elements, well implemented playability with in-game manuals which blend into the story-telling, great plot and very interesting characters, whose minds you explore their from the perspective of their mental abnormalities - if any. Everything comes together very nicely into the game's theme, and in a short time you'll see yourself chasing patients across the Structure, sometimes even forgetting about the main quest. Definitely scratches the Papers Please itch, and well worth the 8 hours from start to finish. | ì´ ê²Œì„ì„ í”Œë ˆì´í•œ ì‚¬ëŒë“¤ ì¤‘ ëŒ€ëµ 10%ì´ë‚´ì˜ ì‚¬ëŒë“¤ë§Œì´ ì—”ë”©ì„ ë³´ì•˜ë‹¤

I honestly really wanted to like this game. Iâ€™m a big fan of these kinds of dystopian maintenance games (Papers Please; Thatâ€™s Not My Neighbour, Orwell) so Mind Scanners seemed perfect for me.

First: the positives. Well, positive and a half. 

1) The character design is pretty unique. I liked their appearances; I liked peeking into their lives; I liked their personalities both before and after treatment. 

1.5) The mind scanning part of the job is pretty cool. Itâ€™s simple and mostly easy, but cool. 

Now, for the flaws, this is just my personal preference. Iâ€™m sure there are some aspects people will like.

1) The treatment part of the game is, at least for me, hard. There are multiple factors to this:
-You can have over 10 â€œinsanitiesâ€ to remove, but as you remove one, the patientâ€™s personality depletes. Itâ€™s almost impossible to balance, and I am genuinely amazed whenever anyone can do it.
-Your original treatment tool is broken. This is fine and adds a nice challenge, but the â€œupgradeâ€ sections is what I see as a flaw. These tools are not broken, and can treat multiple insanities of one type at once. So whatâ€™s the issue? You only see the silhouette until you buy it, and thereâ€™s no guidance on how the hell to use them. 

2) You have 200 time each day, which is the amount of time you have to treat patients. This would be okay, if it also didnâ€™t take sometimes 60+ time to travel to them. The upgrades section I mentioned earlier also cost you time. Even without upgrades, this left me able to treat one person per day, maybe two if I was lucky. 

3) You diagnose the patients as either sane or insane, with the latter allowing you to treat them. If you misdiagnose someone, money is taken away from you. My issue with this is that the system sometimes doesnâ€™t make sense, with seemingly sane people needing to be declared insane and vice versa. I guess that might be based in the deeper theme of the government and the people, but itâ€™s definitely irritating as a player. 

While it seems like simple flaws, it definitely impacted my experience and enjoyment as a player. It just felt like a game where youâ€™re meant to hate the government, but you just end up hating yourself.

[b]Iâ€™ve beaten the game all the way up to floor 10, and feel satisfied with this accomplishment up to now. Luck be a Landlord is casual fun, and for a casual price I think thatâ€™s pretty awesome. But itâ€™s missing the X factor that makes me think itâ€™s really special.[/b]

This will probably be short since the game itself is very condensed. The premise isâ€¦ completely nonsensical, but whatever. It took me until my 5th run or so before I even bothered to read the text. Itâ€™s irrelevant.

The gameplay is simply two loops, one very miniature, and another bite-sized. You spin the slot machine, earn some amount of money, and you choose to add a symbol to it (or not). After a certain number of spins, you have to pay rent, get an [b]item[/b] (different from a symbol), and then the next rent payment is even higher.

Once you reach a high enough â€œfloorâ€, you begin receiving essences after some of the rent payments, too. These are, at the risk of being overly simple, like temporary forms of the items, with usually greater (but time-limited) payoffs.

This is everything you do in the game.

The symbols themselves are not the most pleasing things to look at, but the thematic synergies are cute. Dwarves drink beer. With an item they can also smash ore. Billionaires synergize with wine and cheese. Divers collect aquatic type items and give permanently higher payouts after collecting them. Itâ€™s cutesy like this.

It also does a very good job at showing you with a little animation and sound effect [i]when the effect happens[/i]. I appreciate that as itâ€™s a relatively common complaint of mine in other roguelike/lite games that these games are opaque.

What prevents me from really loving this one is the stark contrast between a run feeling completely blessed by the gods, and a complete car wreck. And the best way to go about beating the game consistently, is the least satisfying way of doing so.

The best way to go about beating the game is just simply to take whatever symbol and item best synergizes with what you have going on in your slot machine already. What this means is that playing best often means two things:

[b]1)[/b] You finish with a hodge-podge of different good symbols and items, without a unifying theme and identity.

[b]2)[/b] Thereâ€™s not much looking forward to anything or building toward something.

Some runs you [i]will[/i] pick every club, spade, heart, and diamond, and you will be blessed by like 2 jokers to perfectly tie it together. But nothing you did before that moment you received the jokers helped you get them. Sometimes youâ€™ll take every aquatic item there is, and then snag a diver who after a few rolls is already giving you 12 per spin. But again, nothing you did before that moment helped you snag the diver.

More often than not, building toward a specific synergy will result in a loss because you never get the payoff. And why would you take the payoff before you built up the base?

My personal recommendation for the game would be to have a system similar to the boons in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1145360/Hades/]Hades[/url]. In Hades you need certain boons before you can earn others. They donâ€™t [b]increase[/b] your odds at getting the boon, but there is a level of satisfaction to knowing youâ€™re building toward your goal, so to speak. And I think Luck Be a Landlord would benefit from this, even if it meant the gameâ€™s difficulty had to be increased in conjunction.

Itâ€™s not about difficulty as much as it is about satisfaction.

The other limiters are things like a collection log, a list of run modifiers to toggle, among other things. There [u]is[/u] a Steam Workshop, which I will readily admit Iâ€™ve yet to explore, but I will later. And maybe these things can be found there. In all likelihood they do exist there. And without developer effort, the workshop wouldnâ€™t be there, and easy to use, so despite the fact the developer didnâ€™t make the mods, they provided the framework. That deserves credit.

Ultimately though, Luck be a Landlord is limited by its core build philosophy. Itâ€™s a fine game, and has a good feel of low stakes. The price point is low, and the gameplay is simple and cute. But itâ€™s not one Iâ€™ll really remember or recommend above many other games, although the very affordable price on sales is noteworthy!
