Decent game. Drops the ball at the very end. (No spoilers in this review)

I'm going to be listing out criticisms only because I think that overall, this is most certainly a good game, and whilst I think the game falls short on alot of it's most promising aspects, it does step up and do alot of things that an overwhelming majority of games refuse to do. Before I get to that, I want to say that mechanically the game is quite fun. It does a good job throwing in variety, minigames and captivating moments while slowly building up and presenting the story. I was not bored once during my entire playthrough. My compliments to the chef.

The crux of the issue I have with this game is that it ultimately feels as if it is scared of being left-wing, in an inherently left-wing narrative that it has created for itself. It has alot of pleasantly surprising displays of faux-anarchism, a confident antifascist identity and a consistent anti-authoritarian theme.

I'm afraid the game just doesn't go far enough, which is a shame because it opens the door to alot of really interesting themes and important topics, but lacks the courage to fully flush them out. It has you interact and cooperate with armed revolutionaries against a totalitarian state, which is great! But... It rarely displays the real, valid reasons why these characters aren't complicit in the status quo.

Are they rebels out of principle, risking and even giving their lives to achieve democracy for philosophical reasons? Doesn't seem like it, the game refuses to specify where on the political spectrum the 'black brigades' even sit - sure, their symbol may evoke anarchism, but we never get to hear what a post-revolution regime may look like from the revolutionairies themselves. Are they then rebels out of neccesity? Are members maybe marginalised groups who face an oppression so extreme that it leaves armed insurrection as the only option? I never got that impression or anything that hinted at it in my playthrough.

I think that's a shame! I think that it is really cool that a game is willing to have an overtly political narrative where 'extremists' are portrayed as good guys, that the premise centers around a situation in which radical political action is morally good! Even if it takes you siding with them actively. I just really, really wish the game would take that one extra step to show and tell *why* authoritarianism is horrible, *how* it systematically discriminates and oppresses members of it's own society, and *who* those members are.

Besides this, the game is quite good. Some, if not many of the characters, are actually really charming and memorable, even one 'villain'. However, given how the game's rotation of characters can only be interacted with semi-randomly, I often found myself forced by the game to spend time with and complete narratives that I was extremely disinterested in. I do not want to spend my time with a pretentious 14 year old and be forced to do their chores. I do not feel inclined to speak to police officers who are arresting me at all, actually. The worst parts of this game are easily ones where you are forced to do random shit with and listen to monologues of characters you couldn't care less about.

In some ways, it also felt like the game spent alot of time giving you really important choices and communicating strongly that you are influencing the story in tangible ways, but then when the consequences of your decisions and actions actually come around, the game pulls whatever narrative magic it can to make it's preferred sequence of events happen anyway if you didn't pick the "right" option. It's hard to go into detail without spoiling, but unfortunately, I think this applies to the ending too.

I got this game on sale for 5 euros, I consider it a steal. I do not think the full price is unreasonable, if you have the money to spend for this kind of thing, do it. I hope that we get more games like this one that are willing to have overtly political premises, but are willing to spell out or seriously engage with it's viewpoints and narrative in a less sanitized manner. | First played on the Pass and Enjoyed the game.

Road 96 is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece. The developers crafted a truly unique experience that stands out in the crowded world of narrative-driven games. From its thought-provoking storytelling to its brilliantly executed game play mechanics, Road 96 delivers a journey that resonates deeply, offering something fresh and innovative at every turn. This is a game that feels truly special, and it's easy to see why it deserves a perfect score of 10/10.

What truly sets Road 96 apart is how it combines procedural generation with meaningful, choice-driven gameplay. Each time you hit the road, the game generates a new set of characters, events, and locations, ensuring that your journey feels unique every time. Itâ€™s an adventure where every decision matters, whether itâ€™s helping a fellow traveler or choosing to take a dangerous shortcut.
The gameplay loop is addictive. Managing resources like money, food, and gas is crucial, but it never feels like a chore. Itâ€™s a constant balancing act between survival and risk, where you have to weigh the consequences of your choices. Do you trust a stranger and take a risky detour, or do you play it safe? The emotional payoff from these decisions is what makes the game so compelling.

The characters you meet along the way are some of the most well-crafted in recent memory. Each one feels like a fully realized individual with their own backstory, personality, and goals. Whether youâ€™re chatting with a kind-hearted truck driver or a rebellious punk, you can sense the depth of each character.

The art direction in Road 96 is a visual treat. The game blends a stylized, almost cartoonish aesthetic with a gritty, dystopian world, creating a perfect balance between hope and despair. The environments are varied and beautifully crafted, whether itâ€™s a dusty highway, a small gas station, or a bustling town. The art gives the world a sense of place and mood, perfectly complementing the gameâ€™s narrative.
The soundtrack is equally fantastic. A mix of 80s and 90s-inspired synthwave, itâ€™s the perfect soundtrack for a road trip through a world on the brink of collapse. The music not only enhances the atmosphere but reacts dynamically to the story, making every encounter feel more immersive. The voice acting is top-tier, with each characterâ€™s performance adding layers of authenticity to their story.

Road 96 is a triumph in every sense. Itâ€™s a game that takes risks, offering a truly unique blend of narrative depth, procedural gameplay, and emotional weight. Itâ€™s a game that challenges you, makes you think, and stays with you long after youâ€™ve finished playing. With its incredible characters, unpredictable storylines, and a stunning visual and audio design, Road 96 proves that video games can be powerful, thought-provoking, and deeply personal experiences.

While I am not a fan of the pixel art (what's up with that weird vodoo doll image of the vulnerability ray?), I am absolutely in love with the clever gameplay and tricky combinations.

Despite the relatively few modules, there is a ton of replayability and enjoyment from this utter gem of a Slay-The-Spire inspired Rogue-Lite.

TL:DR - This game is overhated. Is this a great game? No. Is this a decent fun time? Yes. 
What the game gives us is an â€œaliveâ€ everyday Gotham. People minding their own business, bank robberies happening etc. This is done well enough. 
It gives you the opportunity to go on patrol every night and punch random thugs. This is done quite well albeit quite repetitive after some hours. 
The boss fights are better than Arkham Knight. They actually let us fight bosses.
Story is simple and fun but they couldâ€™ve went harder. Court of Owls is such a fun storyline it could be way longer and more impactful. 
The main issue is that it was to inevitably be compared with the Arkham series despite being a different game whatsoever. It is a multiplayer adjacent game, the point was for the player to patrol Gotham together and have fun defeating enemies in â€œdungeonsâ€. This caused the graphics, physics and gadget complexity to be way downgraded as compared with Arkham series.
The multi is dead now and even when it was not the multiplayer options themselves were quite weak. 
Also, I donâ€™t think anyone asked for a live-service Batman game. If this was a single player focus with 4 slightly different stories depending on the main character chosen it couldâ€™ve been so much better.

[h1]"I think all four of us have some unfinished business"[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Yakuza 4 was my fifth dalliance with the Yakuza franchise, which has had many highs and lows but has generally been an epic adventure to this point. So when I finally worked up the courage to play 4, especially after the challenges of 3, I was warily sceptical but excited for what could come next. But was this one a true sequel to the series, or was it just another casualty in the path of the Dragon?

[table]
[tr]
 [th][b]ğŸŸ© Positives[/b][/th]
 [th][b]ğŸŸ¥ Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
 [td]ğŸŸ©One of the best-written stories that culminates five games of plot and character development into a single point of impact.

ğŸŸ©Combat is far from perfect, but it is an enormous step forward from Yakuza 3's block fest mechanics.

ğŸŸ©Mini games still dominate the experience but are seemingly less tedious than before. Clearly, effort has been made to make them more enjoyable pastimes.

ğŸŸ©As always, the OST in this game was phenomenal. Tangibly nostalgic with just enough hints of refreshment to keep the heat ready to boil.

ğŸŸ© Not a huge step forward in the graphical department, but RGG has made significant efforts to ensure the game has no bugs, issues or tearing whatsoever.
[/td]
 [td]ğŸŸ¥ While Yakuza 3 opens up a new map to explore, Yakuza 4 seemingly restricts you to Kamurocho again. Not that this is inherently negative, but it feels like a step backwards in terms of world development.
[/td]

[tr][th]ğŸ†Achievements[/th][/tr]
[td]A relatively easy 100%, to be entirely honest, especially compared to others in the Yakuza franchise. There are no 100% in-game completion requirements, only some standard challenges across quite a lot of mini-games and some time-consuming challenge completions.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
Yakuza 4 follows the story of Yakuza 3 in a somewhat refreshing way. You begin the game not as the beloved hero, Kiryu, but as Shun Akiyama, a money lender in Kamurocho and a previously unknown character in the franchise.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3423878336

But as his story unfolds and revelations begin to unfold in his life, we again step into the shoes of a new playable character, this time Taiga Saejima (Yes, THAT Taiga Saejima). And we begin to see how his storyline ties into Akiyama's.

And now, as that climaxes, we shift another time to the third playable character of the game, Masayoshi Tanimura, a beat cop in Kamurocho with an axe to grind and heads to crack. With his plot unfolding and once again incorporating Akiyama's and now Saejima's into his own we reach new heights of understanding as we are now thrown to the last protagonist of the game.

We arrive at Kiryu, and finally, after what feels like an entire lifetime away, we are back home. Kiryu arrives back in Kamurocho as he discovers a plot that could devastate the Tojo Clan to its very core. With his plot now incorporating the other three, Akiyama, Saejima and Tanimura, it is up to this unlikely team to unveil the secrets of their pasts and shake the world like it never has been before.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]So, this time around, your test will be...[/h3]
This section won't be particularly lengthy because this far into Yakuza, I doubt many will be surprised by the gameplay mechanics or the general flow of the experience.

Combat is pretty streamlined in this game, functioning in a very similar way to the previous games where throwing punches and kicks or grappling with enemies does damage and generates heat. Heat is then used to do devastating attacks on your foes. Your reward for overcoming challenges is experience points, which level your characters up, as well as an additional reward that is mostly randomised between money or some kind of healing item.

Items such as armour or weapons can also be equipped to help make encounters easier, though I found the general difficulty of the game, even on "normal" to be relatively fair, and it won't be necessary to use these unless you want to decimate your foes.

[h3]No crying like a baby If I break you in half.[/h3]
The only other major part worth mentioning is the enormous quantity of side content available in Yakuza 4. Much like every other Yakuza game in the franchise to this point, this game has a lot of side content to do and try, from substories across each of the four characters to the usual side activities such as bar games, gambling and hostess maker mini-games.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3423880847

These have been streamlined to be less tedious experiences, which is a remarkably welcome improvement from the likes of Yakuza 3.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
As I mentioned before, this game isn't a particularly beautiful experience, only barely improving upon the likes of Yakuza 3 from a visual standpoint. But it still does a tremendous job of detailing the world and making Kamurocho feel like you're returning home after a long time away. I genuinely hope the next games push the aesthetic threshold just a bit.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3423884479

The audio on the other hand is just as astounding as ever. A genuinely gripping soundtrack that gives off hints of nostalgia and feels fresh at the same time, coupled perfectly with the atmospheric and animation audio that does the same, this is truly an iconic Yakuza game.

[h1]Performance and Specifications[/h1]
Running the game as high as it goes on a 2560 x 1440 monitor, I didn't see the game drop below the frame cap even once, though this wasn't particularly surprising as these games generally run buttery smooth.
RAM: Kingston Fury Beast 64GB 6000 MHz DDR5
CPU: Intel Core i9 14900K 24 Core
GPU: MSI Gaming X GeForce RTX 4090 24GB

[h1]Final Thoughts - Very Good[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Again, not the perfect Yakuza game, but perhaps the best one I've had since 0 to be entirely honest. The addition of three new playable characters all unfolding their stories into the perfect culmination of five games feels like a truly epic experience and one that definitely shouldn't be missed.

[h1] æ‰€ä»¥ç§‹å±±ç¤¾é•·ï¼ŒLike a Dragon:9èƒ½å†ç•¶ä¸»è§’å—ï¼ˆç¥ˆç¦±nia[/h1] | From adding Mark Money the MrBeast of Japan, the MC from Hatred who is actually a pretty chill guy, one of the few cops in this series who isn't corrupt, and ofc more Kiryu-chan, Yakuza 4 is one of the best in this series of amazing games.

Playing 3 and 4 back to back, the gameplay is so much more fun, and truely made me want to savor all the content of the game. 

My only complaint is with 4 playable characters, most of the content is only unlocked for them *right* before you finish their part, with no way to go back to them until the finale. I didn't get to do much of the Hostess for Akiyama or the Colosseum and dojo for Taiga because its only unlocked when you are just at the very end of their part. Also the Kiryu part felt short compared to the others.

This game is a great experience, the best and only way to really grasp the story of the game is playing it, and i couldnt recommend it more, the story itself is excellent, which makes sense for a visual novel, but the soundtrack and art are also things to admire here, the characters are my favorite thing in this game. But if you are not fond of choose your adventure visual novels, or games that require a lot of reading, this game isn't for you. But if you are into this kind of game than you really should play! | ive never thought so much for a video game
its like sort the court but if you had 20 cryptic responses and every prompt was complex political predicaments | A game about connection and failure, tailor made based on the choices of the player. Really beautiful in terms of art direction, with a minimalist game-play loop that works perfectly, with shake ups through out the campaign that make it not get old. There are some slight hiccups, with a certain story formulating segment being a bit esoteric in solving. Keep in mind there aren't to many guides at the moment, so be willing to trust the process. The story is where it all really shines in, with impeccable writing, tonal depth, masterful political commentary, and intricate character development. Really hope more people can experience this! | i love killing kids

This is a real hidden gem. The mechanics feel absolutely tight and the gameplay is very engaging. I really enjoy the "bullet-heaven" style mechanic of auto shooting once you get in range. Since most of the weapons are projectile based and not hit-scan, the enemies may be able to dodge the shots, so the platforming becomes very dynamic, dodging the enemies as you try and lock down your shots, as well as stomping on them once you get the chance.

I've encountered plenty of various synergies so far, there seem to be tons of different modifiers, abilities and weapons. Although so far I've found relatively little in terms of player choice in regards to the various power-ups (most of them randomly picked from chests and such), at no point did I feel underpowered or doomed, and it does have the upside of feeling quick and snappy, as usually, given too much choice, I fall into analysis paralysis which slows down the game too much. 
With that said, there are some ways to mitigate the randomness (seller/trader rooms,re-rolls etc).

The runs usually last I'd say between 10-30 minutes, with an option available to save the run and continue another time. The game is quickly becoming my go-to for when I have a few minutes to spare between things. Also Worth noting that it runs beautifully on the Steam Deck.

TL;DR
Absolutely fantastic game, a rare hidden gem which feels absolutely premium. | Squib goes boing boing | NB

A very addictive RPG visual novel set in a sci-fi/cyberpunk future.

You play as a sleeper, an emulated consciousness uploaded into a synthetic robotic body. A victim of corporate propaganda, you signed a contract of servitude, selling your real body away for the promise of a life off-world. But after losing faith in this promised future, you escaped with others from your indentured servitude. Being the only one to make it out alive, caught between a stolen past and an uncertain future, you find yourself on a decaying space station where you must evade the hunters after you and survive, all while trying to buy or synthesize the stabilizer you need to postpone your planned obsolescence.

I found the writing excellent and became completely engrossed by the different life stories of the station's inhabitants. It was easy to get attached to the various characters living on the station.
I also really liked the game's characters design, which reminded me of Katsuhiro Otomo's art style.
And the electronic music was a perfect fit for conveying the atmosphere of isolation and desperation on the station in the game's dystopian world.

Gameplaywise, I didnt find the game particularly difficult. After getting the hang of the mechanics, completing tasks and progressing through the game was fairly easy. Failure was ok as the game was quite forgiving. In my single playthrough, I only missed three achievements. The game has many endings, but you can continue playing by pressing [continue] after the end credits. To experience more endings, always choose the option to leave the station first, when given a choice.
It also didnt seem like the type of sleeper you started with really mattered. I finished the game with 4 out of my 5 sleeper skills fully upgraded.

The game's main strength lies in its fantastic writing and storytelling. So, if you enjoy great sci-fi/cyberpunk stories, you should definitely play this. | Impossible vibes. It's like if the comforting isolation of falling asleep to a white noise generator was a RPG. Incredible game and a very cool interpretation of a distant sci-fi/ cyberpunk future. | This game has some of the most beautiful stories and characters I've seen in a video game, or even some novels I've read. Over the years, you just don't find things like this. I'm a war hardened, grown man, and some of the story threads in this cut me deep. Thank you for this experience. | Citizen Sleeper is an OK game. In this glorified VN you play as a rogue "Sleeper" (hey, that's half the name of the game!) a robot with the brain of someone in cryostasis trying to escape the clutches of the evil corporation that employed you. Citizen Sleeper utilizes its cyberpunk influence to make a very compelling college brochure / kinetic novel, but not necessarily an interesting game.
To not be entirely dour on the game I'll conceit, I played the game, I got 3 of the 6 endings, and I only fell asleep twice. The core slash only gameplay mechanic of knowing what your dice rolls will be before you have a skill check is pretty nifty, and lets you choose to prioritize succeeding at the things you want to succeed at and fail at things you don't really care about. The game actually has an interesting cyberpunk setting and world its built, as opposed to the usual "future city but neon and bad" sloppa you usually get. The game can be finished in one or 2 short sittings. The look of the game is fairly iconic and inspired, and while you might not like the vaguely zog adjacent character designs, it is its own style and you're not going to see other games of the similar setting even remotely attempt this ambition, especially with its small 3 man team, even larger in breadth of scope and intention of design, so you have to admire the sheer passion and care involved.
And we've come to the part where I become a big fat meanie, so if you read that and are like "wow, hey wait, [i]I[/i] like words and pictures! I'm going to buy this now!" please, be my guest, its not bad.




[i]However[/i],,,
Citizen sleeper is not a game!!!! It's a VN with extra clicking!!!! The writing is one note, every character speaks in the same voice and I can't tell you anything a character said beyond aphorisms, cliches, occasional vague left footed marxist toe steps, and brief fellations towards the unnamed player character. A former soldier tells you his adopted daughter "saved him, actually", another tells you that you just don't get it do you, and my personal favourite, when you help a bounty hunter kill a man and she pays you, you drop the money on the ground and say "what life is worth this". I promise you, that you can google every cliche movie line and I guarantee its somewhere in this game spoken by the widely diverse cast of characters. That dice thing I talked about earlier becomes negligible past the first or second hour as once you've gained a couple levels, you can acquire the ability to reroll at any point during a turn, even when you only have one die left. Naturally, I abused this to get the main ending i wanted out of the game, because why not. In general though, levelling up trivializes the game, your first level, if you so choose can be spent to negate any weaknesses your character class had, you CAN add plus 2 bonuses to your rolls but by the end i was rolling too many 5's and 6's to even think of that as an investment. There's a skill to regain health and stamina for free, but you get so much money for every little thing you do you have to go OUT OF YOUR WAY TO FAIL AT ANYTHING. The game constantly terges and teases impending doom and choices mattering, however, I realized early on you don't actually have any agency in the solipsistic monologues the characters speak to you, so I said the meanest dialogue option I could, every time, and, every time, they would just ignore me and keep monologuing about the world. Speaking of doom, I'll let you know now, if you run out of health? You get put back to half health at the cost of one of your buffs/debuffs, if you run out of time on your bounty hunter missions? You get the same cutscenes as you would if you were a good boy. You are simply watching the story unfold from the eyes of another, the room starts spinning and I begin experiencing extreme depersonalization, is this how it is in the game? or is this every day for me? Do I truly want the life I lead? Do I have the choice to not want it after all? These are the questions I ask myself as I click through dialogues, rush through sidequests for my favourite characters, then distributing my worst rolls in a pyramidial manner to characters I like slightly less and so on so forth.


In the world of Disco Sleeper, there's a heavy dearth over the whole universe that capitalism has made things as awful as they are, and I don't mind me a good rage against the machine, hey, I rage against the machine myself too sometimes,

[i]However[/i], 
I do have a problem when its so piss easy to progress in whatever way you want it makes the evil society look ideal. Like in the world of citizen sleeper, you save every minute so you can walk away whenever you want, and there's no consequences for doing absolutely nothing to help yourself. And even moreso everyone is so nice to eachother there's no danger in the world at all. People in mortal bitter rivalries talk out their problems, people steal and get stolen from with no desire for reprisal. The one character that does anything remotely morally questionable immediately renounces her 'evil' (she was in the right btw) ways and decides to abandon her current life for that similar to one of a nun. So its not just the player that all this is just insanely easy for. This world is awesome to live in, this awful world is better to live in than my actual real awful world. If this is the world that the evil capitalists built for the people of Erlin's Eye, sign me up. Sign me up for 2 even, so I can wreck one.

And despite all this, the game was alright. There IS an interesting world and ideas behind all the genera and eye-rolling, I'd buy it on a sale or something if you're willing to live with the big howevers mentioned above.

If you're looking for a similar idea of what you're getting into I'd liken this game to Va1ha11a cyberpunk bartending, where there's an incredibly shallow gameplay mechanic and an incredibly shallow story and they're both smushed together so you don't really realize why neither portion are as good or fleshed out as they could be. | I enjoyed this one quite a bit. More of a visual novel than a typical game.

Pretty good writing but not mind-blowing. The gameplay mechanics are under-developed, especially towards the end they become a bit of a chore. 

But! The story, characters and situations as a whole make up for the flaws. This a very immersive and emotional experience, it really manages to transport you into its world. So overall it's worthwhile.

es bueno un historia god y las deciones son muy buenas | While I get the moral of this game, the degree of which the game pushes against you for the choices you make can be infuriating at times. 

The game itself is a big guilt trip where you're targeted for every single choice that you make, regardless of what it is. While this has meaning behind it, there are many touches and details throughout the game that can bury that meaning under frustration. There were some points that made me feel insulted rather than stop and think like it wants you to:

- Any case where the narrator berated me for one decision, then berated me for the other after I switched choices.
- The dog, which would have been tolerable to bring up a few more times, if it weren't for the joke that the devs "saved the dog" and the achievement for saving the dog by simply leaving the question. (I get the best way to win the game is to not play, but come on).
- You have hardly any effect towards the story at all, yet the game wants to pretend that you do.

This game is cool! It has a clever way of bundling cards with car upgrades and allowing you to customize constantly.  The strategy is pretty solid.  It gets a tad repetative but it's lots of fun and I hope they add complexity via expansions and new game modes. | Yeah, this is an excellent game.

But it isn't without a few bumps and the occasional pothole.

The tutorial doesn't cover some fairly important mechanics and, whilst once you grok how to read the cards things get quite a bit easier, the presentation of the cars is a little lacking in that it isn't clear at first how priorities work, in what sequence certain things happen, and generally, there are quite a few moving parts under the bonnet (hood for our North American friends).

But once you get behind the wheel for a few runs, the handling starts to make sense, and you can put some pretty satisfying builds together. 

I'm a dabbler in deck builders but hardly a committed theory-crafter. I do get the impression that there is less variety of potential builds in this than in some other deckkies, but your mileage may vary. I'm probably not the best to make a definitive judgement on that front.

I'm judging the game purely on whether I enjoyed my time with it, and it's a definite yes.

It's a green light from me!

Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
Reviews:
Palworld isn't your typical creature-collecting game.  It's a bizarre, beautiful blend of monster taming, base building, and surprisingly intense third-person shooter action.  The core gameplay loop revolves around befriending (and sometimes battling) a huge variety of adorable, yet potentially deadly, Pals. Daedream is my favorite companion pal â€“ its cute looks and powerful abilities are a total game-changer!
 
My base is a testament to the game's robust building options. I've got a castle-like residential area for my Pals, a bustling factory for crafting, a relaxing Japanese hot spring where my Pals can unwind (and, let's be honest, maybe get a little romantic), and a dedicated farming zone to keep resources flowing.  It's a little slice of organized chaos, perfectly reflecting the game's spirit.
 
My combat strategy?  Pure, unadulterated pandemonium! I release my Pals, yell some words of encouragement (mostly incoherently), and hope for the best.  It's less strategy and more controlled chaos, but hey, it works more often than you'd think! 
 
The unpredictable antics of my Pals during combat are constantly hilarious.  I've seen them get stuck in the most ridiculous places, accidentally launch rockets at my own base (oops!), and generally cause more mayhem than a troop of caffeinated monkeys.  It's all part of the charm!
 
While the graphics aren't groundbreaking, and the story is fairly simple, the sheer joy of collecting, training, and battling with these adorable yet deadly creatures makes up for it.  The blend of cuteness and carnage is unique, and the base-building aspect adds a welcome layer of strategic depth.  Palworld isn't perfect â€“ it can be repetitive at times, and the occasional glitch can be frustrating â€“ but the overall experience is incredibly enjoyable.
 
Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys a good dose of cute chaos! | fazia tempos que queria ficar cheio de pals, agora da pra colecionar pal, mt bom, pals de varios tamanhos, formas e cores, recomendo apesar dos apesares, bora segurar nossos pals e amalos | gfæ²¡äº§èƒ½ï¼Œæˆ‘è‡ªç„¶æ¥ç©å¸•é²äº†ï¼Œè¿™ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆæ­£å¸¸å˜›ï¼ŸæŠ„è¢­çš„ç¡®å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä¸å¯å¦è®¤ï¼Œä¸”é’‰åœ¨è€»è¾±æŸ±ä¸Šã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å¸•é²ä¹Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šåœ°æ–¹è¶…è¶Šäº†å®å¯æ¢¦ä¸æ˜¯ä¹ˆï¼Ÿä»–éš¾é“ä¸æ˜¯ä»å–„å¦‚æµå˜›ï¼Ÿä½ è¯´gfè€¿é¬¼æ¼‚æµ®ã€megaåœ°é¾™ç©å®¶è¯Ÿç—…å¤šå°‘å¹´äº†ï¼Ÿæ”¹äº†å˜›ï¼Ÿå‰‘ç›¾dlcç¥å…½å¼ºåº¦è¶…æ ‡ï¼Œåƒæ»¡æå·¨åŒ–å’Œé’›æ™¶åŒ–çº¢åˆ©ï¼Œå‰ä»£ç¥å…½æ²¡äººç©ç¯å¢ƒå˜çš„æ¶è‡­ï¼Œæ”¹äº†å˜›ï¼Ÿå¸•é²å®˜æ–¹åšåˆ°äº†ç©å®¶åæ˜ ä»€ä¹ˆå°±æ”¹ä»€ä¹ˆï¼ˆè€Œä¸”æ˜¯å”®åå“¦ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ç‚¹è¶…è¶Šäº†ä¸çŸ¥é“å¤šå°‘æ¸¸æˆå®˜æ–¹äº†ã€‚ | Ğ¯ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ±ÑƒĞ´Ñƒ ÑƒĞ³Ğ»ÑƒĞ±Ğ»ÑÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ğ² Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹, Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑĞºĞ°Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚, Ñ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‡Ñƒ Ğ°ĞºÑ†ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ½Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼, ĞºĞ°Ğº Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ‡Ğ¸ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑÑ‚ÑÑ Ğº Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğµ.

The fun I got from playing Palworld was mainly from exploring the world, finding and catching new pals and collecting collectibles. But when you enter mid game, which is around level 30 you can't progress by simply exploring anymore. You instead need to farm materials to craft necessary items and farm the same pals you've already caught to gain exp. And this loop of farming and running around can go on for hours.
Me and my friend changed the world settings (higher drops etc) to make it more bearable but even so the game was too boring for me to want to continue. And it's so frustrating because the beginning of the game was so much fun and I wish the developers would've designed the game progression to be like that through out the whole game.
There's more stuff I could criticize the game for but what's written above is the main complaint I have and what made me stop playing.

Game Name: Who Pressed Mute on Uncle Marcus?
Reviews:
Bienvenidos a otro tÃ­tulo mÃ¡s de Wales Interactive, otra pelÃ­cula interactiva mÃ¡s y otra experiencia que, en este caso, no ha despuntado pero tampoco ha decepcionado. "Who Pressed Mute on uncle Marcus?" es una pelÃ­cula interactiva que sigue la misma dinÃ¡mica que todos los videojuegos de Wales Interactive, manteniendo asÃ­ una fÃ³rmula que se centra sobre todo en la trama principal que recae directamente sobre la actuaciÃ³n de los actores que representan cada personaje que compone la susodicha historia. 

La historia es aceptable. Encarnamos a Abby , quien se ve obligada a tener que interrogar a cada uno de sus familiares durante una reuniÃ³n de juego de familia debido a que su tÃ­o Marcus cree fervientemente que ha sido envenenado por alguno de estos. SerÃ¡ nuestro objetivo principal, encontrar quiÃ©n lo ha envenenado, porquÃ© y cÃ³mo curar a nuestro querido tÃ­o Marcus. 

El gameplay es simple aunque funcional. La dinÃ¡mica principal serÃ¡ interrogar a cada uno de nuestros familiares con la intenciÃ³n de que estos acaben diciendo algÃºn que otro comentario que nos ayude a resolver esta situaciÃ³n tan complicada. Contaremos con diÃ¡logos que, dependiendo quÃ© opciÃ³n elijamos, nos acercarÃ¡n o alejarÃ¡n de las respuestas que buscamos tan fehacientemente. 

Los personajes estÃ¡n bien construidos y actuados. Por un lado, los personajes estÃ¡n bien construidos dejando entre ver que cada uno tiene su pasado, ambiciones e incluso rencillas con otros personajes y, por el otro lado, nos encontramos con unos actores que, lejos de ser perfectos, dan la talla para representar a sus respectivos personajes haciendo de la historia, una creÃ­ble y, por ende, disfrutable. 

Los logros son de dificultad fÃ¡cil. Dejando a un lado que todos los logros se consiguen con simplemente jugar al tÃ­tulo, es imperativo jugar varias veces al susodicho en caso de que se quiera conseguir el platino, desbloqueando asÃ­ todos los finales. 

En conclusiÃ³n, Â¿Recomiendo este tÃ­tulo? Lo cierto es que sÃ­, aunque a regaÃ±adientes. Este tÃ­tulo se me incluyÃ³ con el pack de juegos de Wales Interactive (opciÃ³n que, en el momento que decidÃ­ comprÃ¡rmelo, parecÃ­a una buena idea) por lo que decidÃ­ que me los jugarÃ­a todos. La historia es aceptable, los personajes estÃ¡n bien construidos y los actores hacen una actuaciÃ³n medianamente buena (siendo el tÃ­o Marcus el menos creÃ­ble de todos, lo cual me parece irÃ³nico). Al final, todo lo mencionado previamente acaba por desembocar en un tÃ­tulo que estÃ¡ bien para echar la tarde pero no es nada memorable. Si has jugado a otros tÃ­tulos de Wales Interactive, ya sabes lo que puede esperarte. Si no has jugado a ningÃºn otro tÃ­tulo de este desarrollador (que tambiÃ©n es un editor), antes recomendarÃ­a que probaras "Late Shift" o "The Complex". | [h1]Decent enough murder mystery.[/h1]

[h2]The Good:[/h2]

1.  The acting is fine, and quite funny at times; they are all exaggerated horrible people.

2.  The set up and playing style.  Interesting way to have a murder mystery game.

[h2]The Ok:[/h2]

1.  The story.  It is quite short, although you need more than several playthroughs to see everything.

2.  The price.  Regular price won't be worth it to most people, but I got it for under 5 dollars, which was definitely great for what you get from this.

[h2]The Bad:[/h2]

1.  The lack of detail and evidence.  Especially for the true murderer, there is scan evidence that is actually collected, and in fact most of it (if not all) is hearsay from other people. 

2.  Overall how it is more of a guessing game in the choices, as opposed to using any deductive thinking.

[h2]Overall:[/h2]

I would recommend this, as long as you don't expect anything deep, thoughful, deductive, or detailed.  This is quite a simple and fun game that has a bit of mystery to solve.  The most fun part was seeing the interactions of the different people together, although solving the murder was also enjoyable.

Probably accurate with where it stands in steam ratings (as of now).  I'd give it a:

[b]7 out of 10[/b]. | Fun, great characters | ĞĞ° Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ĞµĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ² Ğ½Ğµ Ñ‚ÑĞ½ĞµÑ‚, Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ 30 Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ¶Ğµ "Ğ´ÑƒÑˆĞ½Ğ¾". ĞĞ¾ ĞºĞ°Ğº "ÑĞµÑ€Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ»" Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¹Ğ´ĞµÑ‚.

Game Name: Behind the Frame: The Finest Scenery
Reviews:
[h3]Let's paint the finest scenery. [spoiler]Shall we, Amber?[/spoiler][/h3]

This game has a story so good that even though I got it for free on epic games, I had to go buy it on steam to show my support.

Also, it's a nice touch that it's free there on January 23rd, it's very fitting. If you are seeing this review before January 30th, 2025 go get it for free now! | Probably one of the most gorgeous games I've ever played. Took me about 2.8 hours (Base Game + Jack DLC) to complete so it is kind of short but I enjoyed it nonetheless. Both characters are thoroughly thought out! Spoilers on both characters: [spoiler]During the DLC, you can tell Jack misses Amber but just doesn't believe he deserves to stand by her and honestly my heart broke when I discovered that. Jack severely misses her which you can tell during the whole snow scene in the DLC. Also the fact that at the end of the base game, you realize that you aren't Amber's daughter (like i originally thought), but actually Amber herself! And that means that old man Jack wasn't ignoring us because we weren't actually there! Also the fact that the ending of the DLC is a parallel to the base game is [i]killing[/i] me![/spoiler] If you enjoy the Studio Ghibli style of animation and enjoy a heartfelt/somewhat bittersweet story, then I highly recommend this game to you! And definitely grab the DLC at the same time that you get the base game so you can play them back to back! | ç”»é¢å¥½çœ‹ã€é…ä¹å¥½å¬å™äº‹æŒºè‰ºæœ¯ï¼Œæˆ‘è®°å¾—å¼„å®Œç»“å±€å¥½åƒé¼»å­éƒ½çº¢äº†ã€‚æ¸¸æˆä¹Ÿä¸éš¾ï¼Œè§£è°œå‘çš„ï¼Œåˆ°å¤„æ‰¾æ‰¾ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œé‡Œé¢çš„æ„Ÿæƒ…ä¹ŸæŒºæ„ŸåŠ¨çš„ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚å‰§æƒ…4/5  éš¾åº¦2/5 æ“ä½œ2/5 | Ich habe "Behind the Frame" und "The Star Named Eos" zusammen gekauft. In gewisser Weise war das wohl eine gute Entscheidung. Ich hatte eigentlich nach einem Puzzlespiel gesucht (also so eins, wo man ganz klassisch viele einzelne Teile zu einem Ganzen zusammenfÃ¼gt), und bin Ã¼ber "Behind the Frame" gestolpert. Irgendwas mit Bildern, Kunst? Super. Und es gibt auch noch ein weiteres Spiel was sich mit Fotografie beschÃ¤ftigt (The Star...)? Fehlt eigentlich nur noch ein Teil, der sich mit BÃ¼chern und Poesie auseinandersetzt. BÃ¼cher im Sinne von lesen, Poesie im Sinne von selber schreiben - was auch immer, Briefe, Geschichten, Gedichte. Damit wÃ¤ren die drei Dinge abgedeckt, mit denen ich in Jugendzeiten (ist man eigentlich schon sehr alt, wenn man so denkt?) massive RealitÃ¤tsflucht betrieben habe, was mich gleichzeitig aber in genau dieser halten konnte.

Genaugenommen ist der poetische Teil auch in diesen Spielen enthalten. In Form von Gedanken, Briefen, Erinnerungen. Kein Wunder also, dass mich beide Werke letztendlich in ihren Bann gezogen haben. Eine gewisse Identifikation war durchaus vorhanden. 

"Behind the Frame" brauchte anfangs ein wenig, um mich erwÃ¤rmen zu kÃ¶nnen. Das liegt an der Eigenheit des Spieles, was sehr lange Pausen hat in den Erinnerungsteilen. Wie viele andere schon schrieben, hÃ¤lt man das schnell fÃ¼r einen Fehler - oh, Spiel hat sich fest gefressen? Muss neu gestartet werden? Ist kaputt? Nun, das ist es nicht. Scheinbar ist es so gewollt. Gewollt, das man lange warten muss. Keine Ahnung, so eine ganz klare Antwort habe ich fÃ¼r mich darauf nicht finden kÃ¶nnen.
Wer auch immer es spielen will, sollte wissen, dass dies im Spiel passieren wird. Ein Bild, ein Satz, dann nichts... Nach einer (langen) Weile geht es dann weiter. So gesehen ist diese Erfahrung eine der Entschleunigung. Anfangs hatte es mich genervt, am Ende fand ich es gut so. Es hat tatsÃ¤chlich etwas beruhigendes gehabt, gleichgÃ¼ltig, ob das nun der Sinn dahinter oder schlicht schlechte Programmierung ist.

WÃ¤hrend man sich in "Behind the Frame" mit Farben und Bildern und Skizzen beschÃ¤ftigt, bekommt man in "The Star Named Eos" eine Kamera zum fotografieren. Im ersten Spiel kann man durchaus in die Welt zoomen, sie nÃ¤her heran holen. Oder weiter weg schieben. Im zweiten geht das nur Ã¼ber die Kamera. Sozusagen ist die Welt hier starr und fest (kein zoomen), und mit dem Werkzeug Kamera macht man sie lebendig bzw. entdeckt sie. 

Beide Spiele enthalten RÃ¤tsel. WÃ¤hrend die in dem "Kunstspiel" sehr einfach sind, sind jene im "Fotospiel" um einiges komplexer. Vielleicht wirkte darum auch das erst genannte lockerer und leichter auf mich. Das andere tiefgehender und ernster. Wobei es das zweite vom Thema wohl auch ist. Das muss wohl jeder fÃ¼r sich beurteilen, was ihn mehr berÃ¼hrt (oder ob es Ã¼berhaupt einen Unterschied gibt). In beiden Spielen werden zwischenmenschliche Dinge behandelt. Oder man kÃ¶nnte auch sagen, in beiden ist man irgendwie auf der Suche. 

Ich kann beide Werke empfehlen. Schon alleine die kÃ¼nstlerische Umsetzung hat mir sehr gefallen. Damit meine ich jetzt die Gestaltung und Aufmachung des Spiels. Diese passt sehr gut zu den Themen, ist sehr liebevoll und - ja - malerisch umgesetzt. Dazu kommen die kreativen Werkzeuge Malen und Fotografie, mit denen die emotionalen Inhalte verarbeitet/bearbeitet werden. Im Teil "The Star Named Eos"  kann man insgesamt kreativer werden.

Beide Teile sind relativ kurz, das stimmt. Und vielleicht sind sie ein wenig zu teuer. In meinen Augen nicht (was aber eben auch damit zusammenhÃ¤ngt, dass sie meinen Nerv getroffen haben). Wer sich nicht sicher ist, ob Thema, Aufmachung, Umfang das richtige fÃ¼r ihn sind, wartet darauf, die Spiele mal im Angebot zu bekommen.


 | The art is great, the music is beautiful and the story is adorable. It looks and feels good. But this is not a game. The puzzles feel unnecessary and the achievements seem forced. And yes, I do understand that this type of story could only be told through the medium of games. However, it could've been an animated short film, and it would've been way better, considering the fact that the game itself can be finished in less than 2 hours.

Still tho, everything above would be acceptable if not for the price. The price is a BIG NO for what you get. Wouldn't recommend the game. However, if you really wanna experience it (and again, not PLAY but experience it), you should wait for a sale.

P.S. [spoiler] The Jack DLC everybody talks about isn't even mentioned anywhere and it's possible to miss it completely. [/spoiler]

Hello everyone! I am an old player who has been playing this game for a long time. I rarely go to the Sky Ladder PK and usually use drones for retirement. The game is indeed a good game, but I have witnessed the inexplicable account suspension!!! I would like to say to customer service or developers:
Firstly, I have been playing this game for so long and have never used any cheating tools to enter the battle platform, not even the human-machine interface!
Secondly, I did use third-party tools when playing this game, but they were also used to clear the storyline mode. But this game has never mentioned that using third-party tools to complete the storyline mode will also result in account suspension, right??? And it's also something I used a long time ago.
Today, I want to talk to the developers of the Minesweeper Society through STEAM's recommendation system! This is the second account I have worked hard to raise, but it has been banned again! I hope to be granted online access to unban, and I will continue to appeal on the community platform and the official message board of the Minesweeper Society!! Until the lockdown is lifted! | One of the greatest RTS games ever made and significantly better than 3 which is an absolute pos game. My recommendation if you want the dlc for this game is to go online and find a cheap steam key for the "all out war edition" usually around 8$. Gives you every single dlc in the game including all playable factions, so don't waste your money on individual dlc which will cost you a fortune. | I don't even know where to start. The gameplay can be satisfying at times but almost every other aspect of the game is downright frustrating and/or pathetic. Had I known that the campaign was strictly Russia vs Germany, I wouldn't have bought it. Had I known how greedy the game is with all the microtransactions and extra dlc you have to buy for a complete game, I wouldn't have bothered. 

You cannot play as either British or American forces unless you pay extra. Furthermore, you cannot play as any army except for Russia in any of the one-off skirmish maps, unless you pay extra. Also, there are campaign missions that it shows you in-game where you play as the allies, but to play them you have to pay extra. Showing you the other half of what the game should have been with price tags and store page links inside the damn game is so insulting. 

I got it relatively cheap on the winter sale, otherwise I would've refunded it. Odds are, you won't have a good time with this game. I hear Coh3 is even worse, so there you go. Another dead franchise swallowed up by corporate greed. | This game is timeless. not sure what is it that brings me back to it. it is not perfect especially the campaign, but the multiplayer comes so close to perfection. | Game no longer loads, tried every solution possible, nothing. Hundreds of others having the same issue with no developer support for a fix. Money goneski.

 | Full of items to discover ,Challenging and has a funny story line. Enjoyable by all. | While the general combat and gameplay is fast and fluid, and some of the writing has a welcome touch of humour. The game's other systems have some big problems. It tried to emulate the Hades formula where death is not always just the end, you go back to your hub to chat with the NPCs and do your general upgrades. While a good formula to strive for, as it works so well in games like Hades. It just doesn't work here, the npc's have too boring and insignificant updates between runs and I never really care about what any of them say. 

The runs themselves also become extreeeeemely repetetive, the only thing that really changes in the runs are the weapons you get and they are insanely unbalanced where some are literally trash and some swoop enemies away with ease, you do have a living talent tree during the runs but the combinations between upgrades (curses) are so so narrow. Combine this with an extremely slow upgrade cycle for unlocking weapons and perks, and the runs start to become quite unrewarding, the last thing you'd want in a roguelike. After 4ish hours I couldn't force myself to do another run, each one I'd done to that point was largely the exact same and just seeing the upcoming perks which would, for me, make the game more fun was hours, and hours away at least. | I love the game's art style and animation, but when it comes to the gameplay its all rather monotonous. ç”»é£å’Œbgmå¾ˆå¯¹æˆ‘èƒƒå£ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªè§’è‰²æœ‰è‡ªå·±ç‹¬ä¸€æ— äºŒçš„ç©æ³•ä½“ç³»ä¸”å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“ä¸Šæ‰‹ï¼Œå³ä½¿æƒ³è¦å…¨æˆå°±éš¾åº¦ä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆå¤§ã€‚éå¸¸æ¸©é¦¨æ²»æ„ˆçš„çˆ¬å¡”ï¼ | This game is really, really fun. It's pretty unique for a "deck" builder, it has a lot of variety within each Oracle, and it's very smooth/responsive. 

The art style isn't quite my thing, mostly due to some things (especially enemies) looking a bit too much like a blob of color without much depth at times due to the way the shading and outlines are done. It's good, just not my favorite style.

There are a lot of builds you can do for each Oracle, some with more risk than others, and they do genuinely feel significantly different. More impressively, most of those builds involve mechanics entirely unique to each Oracle. There's a ton of effort that, depending on how loosely you define a "build" as separate, results in dozens to potentially over a hundred separate builds, and there's enough overlap and synergy between them that you can mix and match without everything feeling completely useless to each other.

It sounds like a dumb complaint in a game about Dice, but I think a few of the later Oracles are a little too RNG-based. Specifically, Sothis and Austra feel very different to the other Oracles. Sothis causes your dice to trigger twice, but it only happens a certain percentage of the time. You can control that percentage to some degree, but it's an integral mechanic to him and it can be very frustrating when it works against you. Austra focuses much more heavily than other Oracles on random damage. Most of the time, aside from the deck-building elements, the only RNG is the dice rolling, so it can feel bad to play those Oracles when you're used to having fixed amounts of damage at fixed times.

The game's biggest drawback is that the endgame feels a little more lackluster than similar titles. There's tons of replayability on the Oracles and their decks - the devs really put a TON of effort into that - but the variety in enemies is much less, the variety in maps is essentially non-existent, and I would have loved to see them come up with some crazy bosses to match the crazy dice bags you can build (there are a few unique ones, but you're going to be fighting the same bosses A LOT as you start playing the game). Also, to the best of my knowledge, they haven't added Leaderboard of any kind yet, even to the Daily Runs. I would love to see some more community aspects like Leaderboards, Custom Run setups, and maybe some more tweaks to add in extra variety to each run as far as enemies/layout/bosses. | æµ„åŒ–(+)ã¨å •è½ï¼ˆ-ï¼‰ã‚’ä¸Šæ‰‹ãè¨ˆç®—ã—ã¦æˆ¦ã£ã¦ã„ããƒ€ã‚¤ã‚¹ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã€‚

I donâ€™t understand how Aragami 2 received so many negative reviews.

Many critics describe the story as bad and boring, but I canâ€™t really agree with that. While itâ€™s true that the story could be better, itâ€™s important to keep in mind that the game is primarily designed to be a fun stealth game rather than a game that focuses on storytelling.
Additionally, a lot of reviews complain about too many bugs. However, I only encountered a few minor ones during my playthrough, and they didnâ€™t really affect my experience.

A few enhancements that stood out to me:
- In my opinion, the combat system is a huge improvement over the first game. Being able to fight back after getting detected makes the gameplay feel much more dynamic and engaging. It adds an extra layer of excitement while still keeping combat challenging enough to prevent players from simply rushing through the levels.
- I really like the expanded character customization, as it allows you to change the appearance of every piece of clothing individually - unlike in the first game, where you were limited to a small number of pre-made outfits.
- Last but not least, I love the new abilities they added. The skill tree lets you choose your own playstyle by leveling different aspects of your character.

I played for 70 hours and I enjoyed it, and I have beaten this game on its hardest difficulty level.  So I think I can write a short review.

This is a roguelike cardgame.  Slay the Spire is the most famous of this type of game.

This game is probably something like 2nd place for roguelike cardgames, and that is pretty high praise.

That's the TLDR, here are some misc details you may find intersting:

*  This game puts pressure on you from the first fight.  It's not a game where there are a bunch of easy fights, and then a hard boss.  Every fight can kill you.  

*  At the beginning of each run, you draft a leader, one of three from huge pool that you never have complete access to.  Most of these leaders are not really very viable though.   Choose carfully!

*  There are 3 different teams to play as.  One is the sort of "generic" team, but it can specialize in ice, poison, or healing, among a few other minor things.    One is the "summoner" team and summoning is very strong because, you can tank with the summed characters.  One is the "gnome" team which uses gadgets and ink.  The ink is very strong because it cancels the enemy's special ability.

 | This is hard to recommend because visually it's fantastic. They nailed every artistic aspect of this game to a T, genuinely beautiful.

Wanted to get that out of the way since, as a deckbuilder, it's severely lacking, and has critical problems, major one being the difficulty. Because the way the game is designed, every encounter can end up being extremely lethal, and there can be a lot of "checkmate" scenarios depending on whether you got crowns, got a poor opener, or have your build counter-picked by a random pack of stage 2 enemies. 

"Oh git gud!" the content creator that gets paid to play these games bellows! But once you do "git gud" it just showcases more issues, and digs into the game's 2nd biggest problem; the variety.

Some keywords are much better than others (barrage, multiple frenzy stacks), and your ideal strategy is basically a game of kingmaker where you build up 1 insanely oppressive unit and either spend resources to keep his permanence, or buff him further to hyper carry you through fights before they can get in a scratch. And nearly every "good" deck plays like this. Diverging into alternate wincons usually leads to a loss, and rather than trying out cool and unique interactions, you're basically taking mediocre or even bad units just as a meat shield. 

And every class aims for these same deck outlines too, reducing synergy. It's like if you have a Warrior Mage Rogue trifecta, but the most optimal way of building all 3 classes is to stack as much strength as possible, including on the Mage, and really once you figure that out it just turns into a frustrating back and forth similar to Balatro, where you're just fishing in the first stage of the game for a good opener to build your deck around. And mind you, all these issues exist on base ascension (difficulty) so the game has its difficulty frontloaded, doubly so once you realize 90% of builds and cards are terrible.

 It's really annoying coming back and forth to such a lovely looking game, being stuck with a terrible and more linear experience than just about every single other deckbuilding alternative existing on here. Try out out when it's on sale, maybe you'll like it more than I did. | Great game, I loved it - beautiful artwork, unique setting, fun game play with a unique touch to the rogue-like deck builder genre. I played it at release which I thoroughly enjoyed with some different cards and higher difficulty, and end of last year with re balancing and more content.

Even though it has less depth and variety in the genre, the mechanics feel really well. It can be hard to force a certain build, but once star aligned you feel like you're unstoppable. Still, if you don't pay attention, or think the turn through, you can still get your ass whopped. The art direction and setting give a more cutesy-happy upbeat vibe which is not only done well, but gives it a more fresh look within the genre. 

TLDR:
- Upbeat comfy art direction unique to its genre
- A slightly different take on the deckbuilder roguelike genre
- Difficult from the start - leaving a lot of opportunity to mess up. If you start playing it, don't give up on the first few hours, it'll get better and more rewarding over time.
- Rewarding and great feeling when it is the run and plays out as you planned for
- A little less variety (cards and items) and repeatability like other games within the genre. This could be a specific decision by the devs to see similar cards & items appear more often. It still offers daily challenge runs, which I personally did not use as much, but I can see the appeal for others. 

It is a high-recommended on my list if you like strategy roguelikes like Slay the Spire & Peglin, and hope to see more games like this. | Pleasantly surprised after trying crappy StS copiers over and over, regularly being disappointed.

Art is about perfect as long as cuteness doesn't bother you. They really killed it with the art and frankly I'm jealous. The style looks complicated and simple at the same time, yet still manages to have flavor that stands out. It's a great commitment to a just-right amount of detail. Each character obviously took a lot of work. Even the card design looks special, with its raised pieces and lighthearted creatures. The music has similar effect on how much it aids the game.

The gameplay's reasonably unique and avoids the mana per turn trope essentially all card games run with. Instead each card played brings every character 1 closer to attacking and using innate abilities. Each character has different timers which can be messed with. Also a 2x3 battlefield for friendly heroes. As far as depth, games like SlayTheSpire or Roguebook have more going on. But you're still going to lose sometimes as you climb up the ascension, and it's more than enough to keep you thinking for a bit about refining your deck and taking turns correctly.


A few problems:

- Animations and transitions are overly slow and waste a lot of time even if they look good.

Enemy variety is lacking. Runs still feel decently different due to deck archetypes, but overall there are probably not enough fun variables between runs.

- Card readability could be better. It's not bad, but hp/atk don't stand out enough for interpretation of the field at a glance. I can see they probably wanted to avoid going too far and making the cards less attractive.

- Grind gated grinding. You get no credit towards unlocks (cards/items/etc) before the current grind is completed. So you have to start grinds from 0 that you should have already earned. It's just adding a grind requirement before we're allowed to play the full game, and making it even more annoying than it has to. Life is short and this is a gross business practice that gets people addicted and stretches out content. Gaming is sad sometimes. Yes it's satisfying to unlock stuff, but it's obviously exploitative and wastes precious time.

- Last boss/new runs mechanics SLIGHT SPOILERS: [spoiler] You fight your previous winning deck/leader each new game. Very cool, but makes next runs harder the more cohesive your team was with no way to reset it. It makes you feel bad for playing well and having a crazy deck going, or picking up that one extra accessory. I applaud the bravery of this mechanic and enjoy it... while also being annoyed by its direct contradiction to the goal of making the best deck/leader possible. [/spoiler]

Ghostwire: Tokyo can, in some ways, be compared to Death Stranding. However, instead of delivering packages, players find themselves running or flying around the map to locate missing items for Nekomata. This mechanic gives the game a unique vibe but doesn't stray too far from familiar open-world objectives.

The main story is engaging but far too short. If someone were to play solely for the narrative, they'd finish the game fairly quickly. The side missions vary in qualityâ€”some are intriguing, while others feel repetitive, involving either defeating enemies or retrieving items.

Combat is serviceable, but nothing groundbreaking. While it remains enjoyable, even at higher difficulty levels, it tends to become overly simplistic over time. Unfortunately, the DLC "Spiderâ€™s Thread" was not to my taste; I only completed it out of necessity. It lacked the depth or excitement I hoped for.

Overall, Ghostwire: Tokyo is a good game, but I would have appreciated more focus on the main story, particularly in the DLC. While the narrative does conclude, it doesnâ€™t quite end the way one might hope. A few additional cutscenes to flesh out the conclusion would have been welcome.

If youâ€™re looking for something akin to Death Stranding but on a smaller scale with fascinating elements of Japanese folklore, this game is worth exploring. However, if youâ€™re after a deeply immersive story that lasts for hours, this may not be the ideal choice.

PS. TIPS Warning: Spoilers Ahead. Proceed at Your Own Risk.
[spoiler]
1. Itâ€™s not worth searching for spirits before fully uncovering the entire map, as it will likely just lead to frustration. It's worth focusing on this at the end of Chapter 4, right before using the motorbike.

2. Avoid searching for spirits until you have the Spirit Perception Beads II. Once you have them, use â€˜Tabâ€™ to activate spectral vision, and the blue spirit will guide you to the nearest spirits in the area.

3. Quests from Nekomata can be tracked (click "E" on missing one in the shop menu), which will display yellow circles on the map indicating where to find the relics.

4. If you enjoy searching for relics and spirits, itâ€™s highly recommended to unlock the Amenotori X skill as soon as possible. This allows you to summon and grapple to a Tenguâ€™s location by aiming with the right mouse button. However, be prepared, it is tricky to use.[/spoiler] | I have never in my entire life played a game this tedious. Kojima's first independent experience. 2015, [b]Kojima left Konami[/b] after MGSV. They didn't even let him accept the award he very deserved so. For the first time in years, there was no work ahead of him. No office, workers, computers, or resources; the man lost everything. 30 years in the industry, but no chance. Banks? Didn't trust him. Publishers? They didn't understand. Even his own family was against his idea, but if he going to continue creating unique experiences, it has to be on his own terms. He already had an idea that he was compelled to.

A studio that produce AAA games doesn't come in cheap, and Kojima didn't wanted to settle for less. [i]We know you're renowned, but you don't have actual results. [/i]It took him a little while to find a banker that's a fan and trust his vision for a loan. With the studio formed, with a logo that thrown on a paper - because they didn't had any computers - Kojima started to contact with western publishers. [i]You are crazy. [/i]What they told to him, because there was no pitch.

[b]You might think it's crazy too, I won't judge. But hear me out and be honest, Death Stranding is out for years and we know how the game is. If you were an investor, and some guy rushed in your office to pitch you a game where the main emphasis is connecting people together while delivering cargo, would you gave him the green light? I don't think so.[/b]

Despite all the circumstances, out of all game studios out there, there was one studio that was interested with the journey to independence of Kojima, despite being one of the largest game company out there. They understand he didn't want his creative vision to be touched with. A studio that known for getting smaller studios beneath them to create games that exclusive to their systems. But despite their authoritarian and strict policies, they didn't hesitate once when Kojima asked for help, and they basically gave him an empty check for him to pursue his dream.

[b]On December 16th, 2015; a day after Kojima's contract with Konami has been officially ended, Kojima Productions has been officially announced alongside with a strong partnership from Sony.[/b] 

He didn't had a studio to work with, because landlords didn't felt to settle with a company that didn't even produced anything yet. So he's settled for a room he was ableÂ to borrow from a friend and turned it into anÂ office for himself and his three team members.Â He kept his independent endeavour a secret from his family, until the success that he was looking very forward to. But unfortunately, [b]his mother passed away during development.[/b]

He was just 13 when his father passed away, so his mother was a single parent that struggled to see the end of the day. Hideo, being very protective of her, stopped pursuing his dreams after finishing high school, and studied economics to be safe - a choice that satisfied everyone except himself.[b] But he never stopped dreaming.  [/b]He satisfiedÂ his active imagination through other forms ofÂ entertainment, His parents,Â encouraged his interestÂ in movies; they would sit Hideo down to watch a movieÂ together, and discuss the themes and direction with him. He was lonely and isolated and he stillÂ carries it to this day, and television was only thing to let him cope out of this.

[i]What helped me get through that period were movies and books. This was when I discovered the power contained in entertainment  and stories. I decided that when I grew up, I wanted to work in a job that would allow me to create these kinds of stories. [/i]He was determined to become either a film director or a novelist. Unfortunately, at that time, these seen as [b]significant risk.[/b] After his father's passing, financial concerns became unavoidable, adding to the mental burden his mother carried as a single parent.

When he first encountered video games, he realized they could offer a new way to create film-like experiences. The potential of this emerging medium was undeniable to him, ultimately steering him toward a career in the gaming industry rather than filmmaking. However, with the market oversaturated, publishers losing control, and competition among home consoles intensifying, the video game industry crash of 1983 unfolded. His friends and professors thought he was out of his mind and urged him to reconsider. 

[i]ItÂ was only my mother who told me that I couldÂ do whatever I wanted to in life. She was theÂ only one. The ghosts in the game â€” maybe my parents areÂ one of them, seeing me in this world. I wantedÂ Â to have that kind of metaphor, that within you,Â youâ€™re connected to the people that passed away.[/i]

Hideo opted for an existing engine to avoid extending development by months or years. Seeking the right fit, after visiting several studios, they arrived at [b]Guerrilla Games[/b] to assess the [b]Decima Engine[/b]. Impressed by the team, Hideo was deeply moved when managing director gifted him a wooden box containing [b]Decimaâ€™s full source codeâ€”no contract, just pure support.[/b] 

[i]I always feelÂ lonely in society. There are so many peopleÂ who play games feeling like that, like theyÂ Â donâ€™t belong in this society. They donâ€™t reallyÂ feel comfortable. Youâ€™re all alone playing theÂ game. And youâ€™re trying to connect this fracturedÂ society by yourself. The world is beautiful, butÂ youâ€™re small, just a tiny speck. You feel hopelessÂ and helpless and powerless.[/i]

That deep sense of loneliness ties back to his childhood. Leaving Konami brought those memories rushing back, finding comfort in knowing others, even fictional ones, felt the same. He wanted players to experience that feeling, inspiring Death Strandingâ€™s online features, where they can see footprints, hear echoes, and leave helpful tools for others. Hideoâ€™s childhood also inspired oceanic environments and massive sea creatures. His father pushed him out to sea in a boatâ€”a terrifying memory that stayed with him. Another key influence came in 1970 when he attended the Osaka World Expo. For the first time, he saw people from different countries and witnessed a blend of ancient cultures and cutting-edge technology under the slogan [i]Progress and Harmony for Mankind.[/i] This vision of a future where technology unites humanity left a lasting impact on him.

While the internet had connected people like never before, he saw increasing fragmentation and isolation. He wanted to offer a more positive way to connect peopleâ€”without competition or co-op combat. Instead, the gameâ€™s online component would focus on helping unseen players work toward a shared goal, a concept that became the [b]Social Strand System. [/b]

His team was skeptical. They pushed back. [i]But no one plays games to help others. Players want to stand out, to be the strongest. [/i]He wasnâ€™t surprised. [i]A new concept is always hard to explain. Even with stealth games, my first opponents were my own team. [/i]Their doubts grew when they learned the gameplay centred on delivering packages and reconnecting a desolate world. Traversal mechanics would add depth, but no one grasped his vision. Frustration mounted as they kept asking, [i]Where are the guns? Whereâ€™s the combat?[/i]

[b][i]No. This is about something different. Itâ€™s about walking and experiencing the world.[/i][/b] | Death Stranding: Directorâ€™s Cut is one of the most unique game Iâ€™ve ever played, but I wonâ€™t lie the first few hours it really test your patience. Youâ€™ll probably feel like uninstalling it, but trust me, stick with it. Once you get into the story, itâ€™s a whole different gravy. Stick with it itâ€™s worth it. | Sadly, the OG Death Stranding has been fully replaced with Directors Cut, I have over 100 hours in the OG. Just like most people I had bandwagon on the concept of the game when it was announced, Uber Eats delivery guy at the volcano, Norman biker man, monster energy and the tube baby. Silly Kojima I thought. I had then eventually bought the game for the PS4 but shelved it after about 2 hours of play. I would say I was not in the right head space and mood for the game, it was not grabbing me. As I shelved I had thought again, silly Kojima.

After it was released on the PC market, I had grabbed it again and thought once more, silly Kojima, sure I will try your game again. Oh boy, was I hooked. Yes the concept is a bit silly, some times even nonsensical, but it didn't matter. The gameplay and the progression really is the hooking part. Who knew that a delivery game had me do work when I came home from work.

The managing of items and how you delivery them was a fun part, sorting out and building yourself for the optimal approach to getting your delivery done. It was until I had the truck then it just became Mud Runner to Snow Runner gameplay. I defiantly felt like a mailman in my world, I would get into the game and just put on a podcast and off I went into the hostile world.

I think the genius comes from the multiplayer aspect of the game. In the world you are alone but its counter balanced by when your vehicle is running out of juice and you see in the distance a charging pole, left there by a player. That's what the multiplayer mechanics are, useful structures being left by players and to aid a delivery man by a delivery man. The lonely world doesn't feel so lonely after all. The game tracks footpaths from most players and starts to slowly create the path itself on the maps. Building roads, ramps, bridges, are all part of the fantastic multiplayer concept that plays with your world and theirs too. People leave "likes" as an indicator of thanking you or thanking them back. This also goes for the system of lost cargo, players like me in the early game have lost cargo, but other players cargo can appear in your world and you can collect it and return it to them. This is also upgraded by a donation system, where in main hub areas people leave gear for other players to access. I have yet to see a game so far expand on this great multiplayer formula that ties itself for your world.

There are so many aspects of the game I can keep talking about it, the route planning of your cargo, the combat, the many tools you use to get around obstacles, the varies amount of structures such as the slingshots which make traversing the maps super fast, but this is exactly what makes this an amazing game, however though a word of caution is how well would it stand once the player base is lacking to create those elements. I think that's the one major problem with the game is that all these elements and gameplay are crucially connected to the world with everyone else but if player base is lacking, would the person still get the same experience that I had when the player base was thriving. Hard to say, maybe they would implement some system to integrate just fake players.

The story for itself is also crucial, some game journalist expressed the cringe or child like elements of the game, I disagree. I wont touch on anything as the story was also part of the experience of the game, great characters and a good story overall as you piece it together. If you like Kojima stuff, then you will have no issues here.

9,5/10 | Took a while for me to really get into it, but once I did, it was fantastic!

Pro's:
-Creativity
-It doesn't really get stale, because there is something new around every corner (a new game mechanic, a new area, a new part of the story)
-The humor
-it's fun to upgrade your restaurant, as well as your equipment. There is a good feeling of progression.
Because of that, things that are tricky at the start of the game, become much more doable, or even easy. And that's really great, because you feel that you've worked for it!
-The characters! Though it wouldn't have hurt if it had been a little bit less of a sausage fest. There are some female characters, but the main cast are male. Still, they were fun, memorable, and fit well into the story.
-The actual fishing! I loved coming across bigger, faster, stronger, more dangerous beasts of the sea, and besting them! It took a bit to really get the hang off, but once I did, it became so satisfying to dive every day and gather everything that I needed for the restaurant! Slowly unlocking and upgrading more dishes because I was able to catch different creatures. 
-Honestly, it just looks very nice! The colors are pleasant, the locations are pretty, the bosses are kinda cool, the character design is varied, I love that Dave is VERY much a plus size! He's just a lovable teddy bear. 


cons:
-There are some game mechanics that could have been left out? Especially at the end there are things that you need to keep up with that become more like a chore than something fun. But in my opinion, it's not terrible. You have the time, and it doesn't take that long, but still. It is a bit much to do everything.
-Dave in the water: Fantastic! Dave working in the restaurant.... incredibly slow. I know it's part of the game, but it is made worse when you have to poor drinks for customers.. Every time I had to pour a beer, or make a cocktail, I would dread it. And I had staff take over as quickly as I could.
-Some parts can be a little confusing at first, but once you get it, or get the hang of it, it's fine. It's mostly that there is a lot, and it can become overwhelming.


Would I recommend this game?
-To anyone that wants a semi-cozy (semi-stressful) gaming experience.
-If you like a roguelike, but would like a different take on it!
-You like fishies but arn't afraid to brutally shoot a harpoon into them (it's just a game. It's harsh but it's also comical. No actual fishies are harmed in you shooting a bunch of pixels. But people can be sensitive to stuff like this, and that's okay! Just keep this in mind before you buy!)
-You're ready to try something new!

So yes, in general I think this is a fantastic game! But it might not be for everyone (no game is) 
You can always watch some game play so you know what is ahead of you. If what you see seems fun, Go for it!!
If you are on the fence, I'd lean towards getting it anyway, because there is so much to this game, I'm sure there will be at least a few things that will positively surprise you if you are willing to put in the time! | Wonderful cute and fun game that has so much content to offer, great music, great visuals and art and tons of fun catching all the fish.
No Reviews
