After spending over 900 hours immersed in Darkest Dungeon 2, I can confidently say it is a challenging yet rewarding masterpiece. The game strikes a balance between punishing difficulty and the exhilaration that comes with overcoming it. If you're looking for a game that demands strategic thinking, and rewards adaptability, this is it.

Initially, I found the level of randomization in the gameâ€”particularly at launchâ€”to be overwhelming. Too often, failure felt like the result of bad luck rather than poor decision-making. However, the developers have worked  to address this issue through a series of updates and balance changes, creating an experience where every loss feels like an opportunity to learn and grow. Today, success in Darkest Dungeon 2 is far more about your strategic choices, your understanding of the game mechanics, and your knowledge of enemy behavior. This shift has made victories feel even more gratifying and defeats less frustrating - most of the time :)

One of the most impressive aspects of the game is how it encourages experimentation.Â  Every team composition is now viableâ€”a huge improvement from the early days when certain combinations felt sub-optimal. With a bit of understanding of game mechanics and enemy abilities, you can succeed with any group of characters, which has transformed Darkest Dungeon 2 into a sandbox of tactical possibilities.

The journey itselfâ€”navigating the gameâ€™s haunting, beautifully rendered landscapesâ€”is unforgettable. Every step feels consequential, and every decision matters. Whether youâ€™re managing your teamâ€™s stress levels, deciding which encounters to tackle, or weighing the risks of pushing your luck for better rewards, the game constantly challenges your ability to think ahead and adapt on the fly. The tension is relentless, but itâ€™s this very pressure that makes every small victory feel monumental.

Another standout feature of Darkest Dungeon 2 is its community. The gameâ€™s fans are incredibly supportive, and the tight-knit nature of the player base fosters a sense of camaraderie thatâ€™s rare in todayâ€™s gaming landscape. Whether youâ€™re looking for tips, sharing war stories, or just enjoying the creativity of small but dedicated content creators, thereâ€™s always something to engage with. The content creators, in particular, deserve praise for consistently producing entertaining and insightful material that enhances the overall experience.

In its current state, Darkest Dungeon 2 has become everything I hoped it would be and more. Itâ€™s a game that demands your respect, tests your resolve, and rewards your persistence. While itâ€™s not for the faint of heart, for those willing to embrace its challenges, the payoff is unparalleled. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned veteran or a newcomer, this is a journey worth takingâ€”a journey into madness, perseverance, and triumph. Darkest Dungeon 2 isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s an experience, one Iâ€™m thrilled to recommend to anyone who dares to face its horrors. | [h1] YES, IT IS NOT DARKEST DUNGEON 1! [/h1]

However, this game deserves a way higher rating. It is fun, it is well made, it is unique experience.
Unfortunately its main game loop takes away several aspects that Darkest Dungeon 1 players enjoy so much.
This explains the sour ratings for an otherwise highly enjoyable game.

What is different:
Instead of slowly restoring your hamlet, your heroes travel the landscape with a stagecoach.
The expeditions are long and follow a roguelike gameloop. You can choose which regions to travel to and, like in many other roguelike/roguelite titles, select the next waypoint from a choice of 2 or 3 options.

Positives:
1. First off.. the greatest thing about it.. THE SOUNDTRACK. 
Stuart Chatwood filled this game with a bunch of absolute bangers: Sprawl Battle, Traverse the Mountain and Battle of the Mountain - these songs will put you on edge in epic decisive battles, where small mistakes will be even more punished than in the first iteration of the game. Sprawl Battle became my personal most heard song on Spotify.
2. The graphics are great. The pre-move animations add a lot of life and dynamic action in comparison to the more static first Darkest Dungeon. The winddown animations are just beautiful too.
3. The relationships between characters are a fantastic addition. Unluckily, it became a bit too easy to always get good relationships, which often makes the game a lot easier. Unluckily the powered up moves are random and sometimes just useless.
4. The boss fights can be hard if you bring the wrong team comp. To me, these harder fights are very enjoyable. Beating the boss with one man standing basically in the last swing was a very amazing and memorable experience.
5. The token system adds a bit more consistency in your battle plan. For most players, this might be an improvement. I personally enjoyed the randomness of the first part a little more.
6. The reflection shrines tell the stories of the heroes and are really cool.
7. The narrator (June Wayne) delivers once again and the lines slap hard. Yet, most lines feel less iconic than the first part.
8. Less micromanagement.

Negatives:

1. There is no gravitas when failing a run or when a characters dies. You don't lose them. You can just select them again in your next run. This bitter aspect of the first Darkest Dungeon is what made it so thrilling. Here you can basically end a run early with little consequences. Sometimes it is the best course of action to abandon midway and cut your losses.
2. Good team comps are limited. You can't play some goofy stuff anymore like 4 Lepers.
3. Decisions along the way have no impact. You decide on whatever resource you need most in the moment.
4. Many beloved characters are missing in the base game and are trickling in with DLCs. As things are progressing right now, getting the full DD1 roster in the future might cost you another 50-100 bucks.
5. Camping is replaced by the inn, which is less immersive. The fear of ambushes and the little moments of respite inside the dungeons was a great touch.
6. Spending a few hours just to get smacked by a boss or miniboss is pretty bitter. Yes, you can upgrade a bunch of stuff and it was not completely for naught. But the upgrades are whatever.
7. Many paths of the heroes are inferior to other paths and for me there is no reason to play semi-useless builds.
8. Some characters are strong and they play nicely (e.g. Highwayman and Man-At-Arms). Some characters are quite weak like the Runaway.

Conclusion:
It is not Darkest Dungeon 1. It is still a fantastic game. Some gameplay mechanics are better, some are worse.
The DLC money-squeeze is a bit of a turn-off. Especially hiding already designed characters behind a paywall is a huge no-no.

Addendum:
Redhooks EULA agreement is pretty dank: https://store.steampowered.com/eula/262060_eula_0 (Section 5, 14 and 20)

This game is not a "remake" of DD1. They didn't "take away features". Red Hook have made it abundantly clear that Darkest Dungeon 2 is it's own game and while it has the same art style and battle system of the first game (thus why it's called Darkest Dungeon 2 and not something else like other reviews say it should be) it should be viewed as it's own experience rather then compared to a almost totally different game.

I have hundreds of hours in both games and I love them both dearly for their own merits. If you prefer DD1's long campaign and are not a fan of DD2's rougelike confessions mode or the shorter campaign in kingdoms mode. That's totally fine! DD1 isn't going anywhere and you can go and play that right now. But just because you prefer how DD1 did things, it doesn't make DD2 a bad game. It just means you prefer DD1's gameplay loop. The last thing Red Hook wanted to do when making DD2 was make DD1 obsolete so they tried their hardest in not making Darkest Dungeon 2 just more of Darkest Dungeon 1. This is the key thing you need to realise when getting into DD2 when you're a long time DD1 player.

Sadly because of the recent negative reviews I felt like I needed to go on this long rant but I will quickly gush a little about this game for people who are completely new to the series and want to give this game a try.

Darkest Dungeon 2 is a wonderful experience I would strongly recommended to any turn based RPG fan, especially if you're looking for something a little tougher since this game does not pull any punches. The art style is beautiful gothic horror and despite the dreary look, the game's theme of hope is extremely uplifting and inspiring. It is all tied together by Wayne June's (R.I.P) excellent narration. Needless to say, I highly recommend giving this game a try. Good luck and remember that in each of us there is a hopeful light holding fast against the hellish shadows that gather between our good intentions.

A bullet heaven/Survivorslike game that is a beautifully crafted experience with a variety of character classes and several different game modes. Each character class has its own strengths and some offer very unique play styles. In typical roguelike fashion this game starts with quick runs that unlock new content regularly, and after a few hours of play you will be able to understand the different directions the game can go in and what you can spend your time doing. 

This is a great game at a great price that offers a lot of content and can keep you involved for many dozens of hours. | Otro Survivor, pero en este en lugar de armas invocas minions.

Okay, but honestly, I took like a long amount of month break and I don't know why, probably just started playing something else honestly...but when I came back I still knew the controls and the story of what I was doing and why I was doing it. Using AP to solve puzzles is very annoying though, wish there was like a "I guess" option for recommending XD  But that's my only gripe so I suppose "Yes" works here

Jusant is a generally good quality walking sim, but was unimpactful to me. The environments look nice and the animations were generally really good. You have the generic blob-like cute animal companion that makes the generic cute animal companion noises and has magic powers, and that kinda characterizes the game for me: nothing especially unique, but also doesn't falter anywhere obvious. The collectibles struck a good balance of out of the way, but not so hidden that you feel forced to use a guide to find them. My only major complaint was that the camera is terrible; it constantly locked me into looking at some specific part of geometry, which was extremely irritating when I was just trying to look at scenery. I would have also liked to see a bit more loose exploration. The first 4 chapters felt like there was exactly one way to climb and left little to explore and experiment with, but chapter 5 did a good job at loosening up and letting me try more things. Overall, while I am definitely not negative about the game, I just feel very meh; it had good environments and collectibles, but lacked any substance that would have helped me feel more strongly about it.

It took me about 5 hours to beat the game, then an additional 1.5 hours to 100% it (using an excellent chapter select that told me what collectibles were remaining in each stage). | I absolutely fell in love with this game, it is one of the most stunning visually i have ever played. I adore the world and the landscape. 
Climbing is also very dear to my heart, and the way this game captures the phisicality of it, the body language of the protagonist when climbing, and how natural and organic it all feels, is nothing short of insane. It made me want to pick up the sport again. 
I love, love, love this game. Chapter one is my favourite.
[spoiler]I just wish they'd let me climb the whole thing myself. Still love it[/spoiler] | This is a beautifully designed and cozy game that stands out with its charm. The graphics are lovely, with soft, hand-drawn visuals that evoke the warm feel of modern animated films. The music complements the experience nicely, playing subtly in the background to enhance key moments. However, itâ€™s not the kind of soundtrack that lingers in your mind once the game is over. Itâ€™s more about setting the mood than creating memorable themes.

What truly sets this game apart, though, is the gameplay - particularly the climbing mechanics, which are by far the best Iâ€™ve ever experienced in any video game. The game does an incredible job of making you feel the challenge of climbing on a difficult wall. Whether itâ€™s the wind pushing against you, the fatigue creeping in, or the daunting distance still left to cover, every climb feels authentic and immersive.

As for the story, itâ€™s minimalistic but intriguing. While there isnâ€™t a lot of direct storytelling, youâ€™ll find letters and subtle clues scattered throughout the game that hint at a deeper narrative. Itâ€™s up to you to piece it together.

In summary, this is exactly the kind of small game I love. Itâ€™s unique, atmospheric, and worth every hour spent climbing that enormous mountain. I trully recommend giving it a try! | Wow what a beautiful experience. The artstyle is absolutely beautiful and feels so relaxing and calm.
This game felt a lot like playing Journey, The Last Guardian or Far: Lone Sails, same vibe. Feels like youâ€™re only a companion to the main character and joining them on their lonely journey through a dead world.
I really did fall in love with this game. Immediately preordered the artbook as well, super excited.

Oh the game also feels like walking through a ghibli movie.

The gameplay is very simple and repetitive but in a very nice and relaxing way. I really enjoyed the way the climbing works.
The mechanics might be very simple but the visuals are stunning and you will encounter a lot of different biomes on your journey. Even tho there is no dialogue in the game (only text messages from past inhabitants) you could really emerge yourself in the story and the worldâ€¦made me very emotional. | Solid game with cool ideas but some frustrating choices as well.  The climbing system is designed well and intuitive, but you'll definitely run into moments where it doesn't feel as crisp or responsive as you want.  The environment is beautiful, and the visual design is top notch, but you'll also get frame drops and be occasionally forced into frustrating camera angles.

Also, the autosave system is *super* frustrating.  If you're going to take a break, I'd recommend only doing it at the start of a chapter, otherwise you will always lose progress.

Overall, the pros absolutely outweigh the cons, but the cons are definitely there.  8/10

Some time ago, I realized that most movies about an alient invasion are kind of unrealistic.

If aliens really did come come here to exploit Earth for it's minerals, they wouldn't bother with the scraps of metal near the surface that we have access to - they would just slip open the Earth and harvest the nickel and iron from it's core.

This is that, the videogame, and it's awesome. | Very good game, but once you finish there's nothing to do, i'd like a rebirth system or more solar systems. Please give us more content. | Amazing game. Satisfying and fun. I just wish there was more games like it. | Fun little game for a few hours but it hasn't been updated for one and a half years at this point and there are still many tedious issues unresolved.

Those issues have been brought up right at release but never changed. 

While most of the game's mechanics are self-explanatory, a lot remains unclear and the game is virtually void of descriptions or tool tips. 

The developer obviously abandoned the game early. | Would have been nice to make a savefile instead of saving the whole game in registers.
Otherwise it can keep you somehow busy, haven't said entertained.
You'll probably want to mute the game and use your own music aswel.

People are complaining of price increase. I find this absurd. Klei is doing what I've heard of most Early Access games. Please, do not review bomb a good game, because price is increased. I do not know how game development economy works. Game is an entertainment to me and Klei is very good at their job. But, this I can tell. Most early access games have their price increased as they continue to develop. They add more contents, more mechanics and more everything. So, the price is also increased for the more everything. This is logical. This is not something to review bomb a game. Furthermore, Klei regularly communicate with their fans. I'm sure they've told you at some point that the price is going to be increased and what the new price will be. You should have bought the game then. I bought it when it still costed 5 USD. Now, it's 8 USD. When it was 5 USD, people complained about grinding. Now, I do not see people complaining about grinding. They are simply review bombing because, with improved gameplay mechanics, came improved pricing. I can't help. but laugh at people's absurdity. This is an Early Access game. So, even the price is "Early Access". If you want a cheaper game, wait for full development of the game. Once the game has sold enough copies and is old enough, you can expect a reduction in price, at least, here on Steam. Steam sells games for cheap compared to other platforms. |

Genres: Casual, Indie, Racing, Simulation, Sports, Strategy
Reviews:
For the moment, I don't see any reason to play this over Motorsport Manager or F1 Manager 2024. The game advertises as emulating the Formula 1 from the 70's (which is the selling point IMO) but rules, points, accidents and mechanical failures rate are all based on modern F1. There is not in game editor for teams, pilots and sponsors (but there is a modding guide if you want to bother. 

If you are looking for a very light F1 manager game, with minimalist but pleasant graphics and a weird dissonance between the overall ambiance of the game (the 70's) and what happens on track (modern F1), than you could get the game on a discount I guess. 

I will gladly update my recommendation to positive if we get editing tools for rules, teams, pilots, crew and sponsors in game and/or if the game actually emulates the 70's. | I love the concept of this game, as you may notice from my playtime, but I can't recommend it In its current state, as it feels more like an early access than a fully featured, balanced game. I really hope it can be improved over time through updates, which may or may not change my recommendation. | I dont like the game. After 10 min you saw everything. Afterwards its just clicking and waiting, clicking and waiting, clicking and wating..... | To be honest - I don't know what to write or exactly why I am enjoying this game, but I am. I have about 32 hours of clicking and managing my drivers around the corners to push or to relax, plus doing pit, tire and fuel strategies. 

I've read quite a lot of other reviews (positive and negative), and while I agree with even some criticism of what era of racing is being simulated, or what is left out.... this is what I was after. A sit down and manage relaxing time in front of my safe space (PC), without the need to invest too much time in understanding what parts is actually being simulated. So although this is a more relaxed take on the 'racing manager', this is exactly what I craved at the time. 

Thus I am very happy with the purchase and will continue to play untill I find I need more depth :) | This is exactly what I was looking for (TL;DR):
A fun and relaxing casual racing-manager that you can just hop into and start playing without watching any tutorial videos first. Probably wont keep you entertained for hundreds of hours but definitely worth the full price.

Some points to help you decide if this is for you:
Pros: 
-) The menus are self explanatory, everything you need is easy to find and not hidden in sub-menus. You're not ending up playing the game for hours, just to find out, that you've been missing a crucial mechanic. Micro-management is tuned down to a minimum.
-) Looks nice. Everything are pretty and clean. Buttons sound and feel satisfying - typical Funselektor stuff.
-) Instant gratification or punishment. You mess up, you know it - learn and make it better next time.
-) You can play through a season in pretty much one session. So even if you mess up the start of the season because you hired the wrong engineer or gambled too much with your sponsor - it's ok, you dont need to start the career all over again.
-) Addictive gameplay loop. Just one more race - I swear.

Neutral:
-) There are little to no helpers. When to pull your guy in for a pit stop or when to push for that crucial extra gap is pretty much up to your gut feeling (although you could theoretically figure it out yourself). I like it, but you may not.
-) There is very little RNG involved - which is positive if you hate those "BULLSH*T" moments. But on the other hands it makes the outcomes of the races very predictable and is (we are talking about racing here) totally unrealistic.
-) There are no "Are you sure?" boxes. You mindlessly click a button and figure out, you shouldn't have - deal with it.

Cons: 
-) This game is very simple - you want a deep racing-sim, look elsewhere. At least give us a fuel-strategy, it's a game about historic racing, right? Nope, you start with a full tank of gas every race and that's it.
-) Players are complaining, that the "70s F1 racing sim" is false advertising and they are correct. The only accurate 70s aspect is that drivers die - a lot.
-) The music and sound. "Art of Rally" had one of the best soundtracks I can think of and this game is just the same short boring loop and sounds. This is such a disappointment for a "Funselektor" game - probably my biggest complaint.

Looking forward to seeing what comes next from this team - more of the same would be amazing. | If you are one of those people that get weird visceral pleasure from untangling jewelry chains that are stuck together or from getting a particularly bad knot out of the drawstring of a hoodie then you'll probably like this game.

It's an alright game.

Basic borderlands looter shooter concept, but DnD themed.
Skill trees I feel are less impacting than previous iterations of the game.
You can do a dual class system which I like a lot.
The introduction of companions for most classes is cool, but I feel like they fall pretty short, even when trying to spec into them.
The weapons aren't that much different than other borderlands games. With a difference that you can different melee weapons, and a spell equipped. These are nice twists, and spells can be pretty fun with the variety of options.
The story is kind of dull to be honest. Very heavy in dialogue, which I understand it's a DnD game. But you start to tune out after a while.
The gameplay loop isn't really that exciting. The difficulty is pretty moderate with that you can clear most mobs easily, but then you have to play a little tactfully with others.

Overall I'd say it's worth a heavy discount. Definitely never worth the full asking price.
 | Bisschen lame. FÃ¼hlt sich an als wÃ¼rde man kaum etwas sinnvolles tun. Man spielt aber warum? Kein Plan. Ohne meinen Kumpel wÃ¼rde ich mich zu Tode langweilien. Wer krass auf Dnd und Shooter steht ok. Aber wer von der QualitÃ¤t etwas wie BL3 erwartet wird enttÃ¤uscht. | TL;DR I would only recommend this for die-hard Borderlands fans.

The pre-endgame is exceedingly easy despite setting the difficulty to "Intense". I never struggled once up until the end game boss. The most difficult parts of earlier games were the burst damage some enemies did that was hard to overcome as a solo. While I am glad they scaled that back in this game, with no other challenge provided the core loop is reduced to holding down M1 until the enemy dies. To top it off, every quest was just "go here press E, go here shoot this, go here press E". It was a bit disappointing. 

Now admittedly this wouldn't be so egregious if there was a gripping story or moment-to-moment writing like Borderlands 2 had, but personally this game fell very flat in that regard. I listened to every dialogue line and did every side quest expecting at least some moments with the same charm as the previous games, but I didn't find any. Perhaps I have simply become jaded, but there were no hard-hitting lines nor engaging plot lines. I lightly chuckled twice the entire game. I never cringed or wondered what the writers were smoking as I did with BL3, but the Wonderlands plot was simply bland.

This isn't to say the entire game is horrible. I like much of the balance changes they made, the art style is charming, and the class system is interesting. The legendary drop rate is lowered in this game compared to BL3, which was desperately needed as they felt a dime-a-dozen in that game. This is balanced out by having your loot luck increase as you progress in the game which I felt fit very well. The new gun types, the few that aren't recycled from BL3 that is, are fun to play with and a welcome addition. And I appreciate the take on classes with a respeccable second class, although I think I still prefer the per-character system from the mainline games.

Should also be mentioned the end game is potentially the best in a Borderlands game so far: a set of repeatable trial chambers which tie closely into the "Chaos Level" system that increases enemy toughness and unlocks better tiers of gear. I have not completed all the Chaos Levels and won't pretend to have beaten each end game in all BL games, but I would like to say that this feels the most replayable and fair.

Overall a game with fun mechanics that falls entirely flat in the story department. | Some of the best Borderlands-esque gameplay outside of the main series itself. Considering this is essentially a full game inspired by the original BL2 DLC it plays like you would expect. The fantasy and magic elements help it feel unique enough to a mainline BL game. The story, writing and voice acting are all surprisingly good here, i'd go so far as to say better than some BL games. | 10/10
Great co-op game for borderlands fans, I'm really happy that they expanded on Tiny Tina's DnD adventure.

However, why are we not releasing any updates at all for this? Not saying to make it a live service game or anything but I'd like to see more content released, or at least an expansion with a raised level cap or something.

Good fun with friends for a few nights. It looks great, it plays well, has plenty of unique characters with various abilities. 

However, in the long term, this game will not hold up. There are no +500% crazy build possibilities like in Risk of Rain 2 and not enough random elements to the runs as in the Binding of Isaac to sustain numerous playthroughs. The map layout does change every time, but the points of interests on it, bosses between levels and enemies types - don't. There is not enough floating variables to make each run feel unique. Which in tern, makes you excited about new characters and abilities you get after a new run, as apposed to actually playing it. Not ideal.

Still, would recommend, since 4 player coop roguelikes are still hard to come by. | This game would be amazing if there were more map, and enemy variety. As it stands, there are only 3 maps/tile sets and 3 bosses. There are some mini-bosses, but only 2 varieties for boss caves and 2 for quests. There are only 3 quests total (1 for each map). Really wanted to love the game at 25 dollars, but they're certainly asking for more than they deserve. | Did not play a single match in our three hour session tonight where someone's client didn't crash. A more relaxing game and not so funny than Two Point Hospital, this is however a very good simulation. This means that it's a pleasure to watch your minions, i.e. staff and students, going about their business and making you smile from time to time.

There are many courses you can put in your Uni and you must build a lot of rooms to make it functional. I like to build the rooms much more than in TPH because I can put more things in them, not a lot of the same posters.

For those of you not familiar with Two Point Hospital, playing this game is in fact building a University with rooms for classes, dormitories, bathrooms, places to eat and socialize, laboratories. and making sure that you are making money and make all your minions happy and serving the students enough knowledge to graduate with high honors. You can train your teachers and do research to upgrade some of your equipment.
The game is structured in missions and you have objectives to finish them from one to three stars. It's long. I've finished half of the missions in 45 hours. Not including the ones from the DLC, but playing mostly on normal speed, because I really love to watch the simulation. It makes me smile or laugh.

Pros:
- great simulation of an university
- clear and attainable objectives in mission
- relaxing and not at all frustrating (TPH has some annoying grindy moments)
- funny all over the place; the radio is hilarious and some animations too
- it's a pleasure to watch your minions doing their business in your great building af knowledge that you've build with money and sweat
- great music; actually Two Point games are almost the only ones that I play with the sound loud enough to listen what they say

Cons:

This gets a definite Recommend from me. If I only got to say one thing, it'd be "give this a try." especially if you like Isometrics, Roguelikes, ARPGs or *Risk of Rain.*
I was surprised to see it not overwhelmingly positive so lets touch on that. 
"Runs take hours"- a player with 0.5 hours of playtime. No, No they don't. You can loop infinitely though if you choose.
"you can't save"- this is a roguelike. Your overall progress is automatically saved, and each run you start will be different and from scratch...just like every other roguelike.

Now to the obvious: Isometric Risk of Rain. Which is a GREAT thing. Yes there are differences but if that is ALL you have to go on, that is a huge win. Gameplay is smooth, all the characters are viable and can become extremely powerful, unlocking everything was a blast.
Difficulty: This seems to have people divided. There is a difficulty selector for a reason...Though I would say after unlocking everything, learning the mechanics and good builds, they could add something more challenging. 
Lastly: This is in early access! The current state is vastly different then the videos I watched to check it out 8 months ago. It will continue to develop, get content and get polished. and while I do agree, I don't necessarily think it's the biggest problem due to it's lower price point. What I do think is a problem is the lack of any numbers.

When you're choosing stats, or picking up items, there's no numbers. None. What I find fun in roguelites, with perk choices and upgrades, is to make a build. With no numbers you can't really make a build. You end up guessing blindly on what is the best upgrade.

If this complaint is not immediately clear let me explain a specific scenario that happens in this game all the time; 

I want to do more dps. I just leveled up and the game gives me the choice between 3 stats to upgrade. Bullet damage, bullet attack speed, and bullet crititical chance. Dome Keeper is a very fun mining simulator.
crash down on an alien planet and rush to mine out the resources below your base before enemies begin pounding at your doorstep!

this game features multiple modes, challenge levels, run modifiers, dif abilities/ chars to use, and much more!

This game has one of the most relaxing and best put together sound tracks I have heard. On a level with Terraria, Minecraft, maybe even OSRS. I am very big fan of the audio tracks, they play at just the right moments, and really helps give the game atmosphere :)

I am pretty impressed with the quality of pixel art used in the game, the creatures are all very unique aswell as the main character you play as. I am happy to see something new and exciting and this game def offers that.

I like the idea of single go runs but also like the fact they have an endless mode to just try and collect as many resources as you can in one go.

There is mod support (this is huge for me) , I am a firm believer that every game should offer mod/ workshop support. You have the freedom to continue to create assets or other things to be used in a game you very much enjoy playing. This is great for when devs cant put as much time into a project anymore or when someone has an idea to add that maybe not everyone would enjoy. Mods only support the community that plays the game and continues to support the game developer by keeping people on their game. 

Great examples of this are : Gmod, The Elder Scrolls, Spore, Fallout, Left for Dead,  etc, etc

So far I am very happy with this purchase more so than I usually would be and I hope more people give this game a chance :) | Addictive immersive fun. Terraria meets Missile Command, where the gameplay is more simple and the strategy has more depth.

gets a little bit repetetive after an hour I would say, but it was definitely worth playing.

The game mechanics reminded me a little bit of Tetris but different. The goal is to combine small buildings to create even bigger buildings that can house more population (in this case the population is simply the score and has no other effect). You can see the next 4 buildings coming up - similar to the next block appearing in Tetris. However you are not under any time pressure, so you can plan ahead peacefully.

There are a few interesting twists by combining several buildings in a single turn which award you cards if you've done enough of them. In return those cards give you strong moves that would be otherwise impossible such as switching building positions for example. Without them your progress would be much more limited.

Graphics are solid, however I personally dont value graphics that much and completed the game without ever changing the standard building set. But there are several more to choose from to get some variety if you want to.

Achieved 100% after 5 hours, so the achievements are quite easy and fast to achieve. | Very satisfying tile matching gameplay. To me, itâ€™s a mix of Bejeweled and Dorfromantik. I can see myself sinking a lot of time into this while listening to music, podcasts, audiobooks, or interviews. VR mode is a welcome and beautiful bonus. I love the art style and Iâ€™ve only unlocked 2 themes out of maybe 8-10. | I've played this loads, it's an easy game to just run in the background when you're doing things and pick it back up when you have a few minutes. Ideal for working at home and in need of a break. 

The game itself is pretty easy to learn, but takes some time to get used to, certainly if you want to get far in the game. The challenge is to really grow your cities and take advantage of the board setup. 

Nice casual game that combines "city building" with a nice laid back puzzle game. | I played the demo before release and its still such a beautiful, peaceful game. For $6 dollars (and especially while its on sale for so cheap) I could not recommend this game enough. This game is a wonderful stress killer and its visuals and music really cement that fact.

10/10

The first game did its job and set the stage for this sequel, and I would say that nearly everything was better in Requiem. The story was amazing, the graphics were stunning, and the audio design was simply excellent. The characters were well-written and the dialogue was highly entertaining, just like in the first game. Also, the voice acting in [i]A Plague Tale: Requiem[/i] was executed very well, making the game that much more engaging. And while stealth and combat werenâ€™t the gameâ€™s strongest aspects, I feel like they were still solid enough for this game. That being said, I did encounter a few bugs and some janky gameplayâ€”same with the first gameâ€”though these were only minor issues, and the overall gaming experience was still great.

Completing the story for the first time took me 22,5 hours. I am sure that itâ€™s not the fastest possible time to complete the story, even for the first playthrough, but I did spend a good amount of time exploring all the hidden corners in order to acquire all the collectibles and whatnot. My total time after completing my second playthrough of the game was ~36 hours, though I did earn 100% of the Steam achievements a bit before finishing the game for the second time.

All in all, I would highly recommend [i]A Plague Tale: Requiem[/i], especially if you enjoyed the first one. And, if you havenâ€™t played Innocence yet, I would also highly recommend that game. | I shouldn't bought this game/bundle when it was on sale. Cobalt Core carves out its own niche in the roguelike genre with a fresh approach to gameplay and mechanics. Itâ€™s a game that emphasizes strategic ship movement and the precise use of cards, creating tense and rewarding encounters that set it apart from the crowd.

The core gameplay shines with its focus on positioning and timing. Each move feels meaningful, and the balance between ship maneuvering and card usage adds a layer of strategy that keeps every run engaging. The length of each run is just right, avoiding the fatigue of overly long sessions while still offering a satisfying sense of progression.

One of the standout features is the lighthearted and charming cast of characters. Their short, meaningful conversations drive the story forward without bogging down the paceâ€”a perfect fit for a roguelike game. The narrative elements provide just enough depth to make you care about the world and its inhabitants while keeping the focus on gameplay.

Visually, Cobalt Core is a treat. The 2D pixel art style is beautifully crafted, with vibrant colors and detailed designs that enhance the overall experience. The audio complements the visuals well, with a solid soundtrack and sound effects that add to the atmosphere without overwhelming the player.

While the gameâ€™s design is top-tier, its one notable flaw is the requirement to repeat runs to unlock additional content. This repetition can feel a bit tedious at times, especially for players who prefer more variety in their progression. However, the engaging mechanics and overall quality of the game help mitigate this issue.

Cobalt Core is a standout entry in the roguelike card game genre, offering a unique blend of strategy, charm, and polish. Its innovative mechanics, memorable characters, and beautiful presentation make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Despite some minor repetition, the gameâ€™s overall design and execution are top-notch, delivering an experience thatâ€™s as enjoyable as it is rewarding.

You are drawn cards in every X seconds intervals and the time stops while you have your cards at hand, you have mana and you build or upgrade stuff (which will be always located in the middle of the screen) and wait until it's the time for the next draw interval. The game starts out as a roguelike deckbuilder, it has it's difficulty but it's neat, both the visual and audio design in the game are pretty decent, so Heretics Fork does a good job with most of the things it's doing, except for;

End-game.
Unfortunately I cannot say the same for the late game, it's still subjective but for my sake, I would like to keep the game the way it was, in the same genre, but it fleshes out to something different the more you progress in it's meta-progression:
Basically this game has a lot of card unlocks, and in the end it allows you to equip so many different kind of winning styles, except for; "rng"
Sadly this doesn't pair well in Heretics Fork, because you are limited by only a few choices of card rewards in your entire pool, and mixed with you having way too many different card possibilities which sadly do not synergy with another, you are mostly left to the fate, essentially turning this into a casino roll, the fun and the creative aspect of the game dies with it and it becomes a "side-screen" game where you check and click based on the randomness time to time, and the most-time being spent on the "waiting" until next draw makes it even worse since your experience is no longer favored "as much" as it used to be, thanks to the crazy amount of unlocked card pool.

The game offers a lot of challenges, again, they are easier to do on low level and very difficult (rng, not actual difficulty) on late game.

It's still not a bad game per se since fun is subjective at it's best, but I wish it stayed the way it started out as, so do be warned before picking it up | Playing on Steam Deck.

[h1] The layman's dome keeper [/h1]

I see some negative reviews comparing this to dome keeper, and yes it is obvious that inspiration was taken from that game; however, there are some massive differences. What I mean by the layman's dome keeper is that I feel that this game is much more casual. In dome keeper you always feel like you are racing against the clock. You have to make every moment in the mine count just to barely afford the next upgrade for your dome, just to scrape by the next wave, and you always feel regret over your upgrades wondering if you should have upgraded your mining equipment or your weapons, etc. Wall world, none of that. 

[h3] Mining [/h3]

Mines are not a giant sandbox for you to hopelessly dig through, there are barrier blocks you cannot pass, and when you clear a mine it comes out looking very cavernous. That is to say, you have a clear path to follow when digging. That compounded with the points you collect for digging and block means, more often than not, you will completely clear every block in a mine before going to the next mine. In dome keeper you will have to think more about where to mine to conserve the most amount of time, strip mining to efficiently search for ores, which makes sense considering you only have one mine as opposed to the MINES available to you on wall world's vertical surface. My point is, there is no mining fuss like the predecessor. It is much more lenient with you, and it lets you swiftly harvest the wall's natural resources before moving on to greener mines.

Another big thing with mining. Resources! Dome keeper only has three ores I believe, each with a clear purpose. Wall world has an absolute catalog of ores, which makes sense because there is a whole world to search for ores. In my opinion, I do think mining is too easy, and I think there should be a big mine in each 'biome' as opposed to many mines that are available for the player to lay waste to.

[h3] Combat [/h3]

Combat is pretty much the same.

[h3] Political Allegiances [/h3]

I felt that this game had a very obvious agenda that just kidding we are going to talk about the combat. In Dome Keeper, you always come out of each battle worse off. There is no way to avoid damage, and each damage point means you are irreversibly closer to death. You need to restore health points with cobalt, the rarest resource in the world your dome lies upon, and as you continue mining the cobalt just gets sparser and sparser, making it very clear that you will die to attrition if you cannot lock tf in and clear the relics. Wall World: Each mine has a different color that makes it apparent what resources will be available in the mine. In the early game, if you are low you can look for an emerald mine and mine a couple dozen and be good on healing for the rest of the run. 

In the late game with wall world, your character comes out of each run with upgrades that make you way better than when you started. Dome keeper has a similar thing where when you win you get more domes or equipment to swap out for your existing ones; however, on the wall you get to directly upgrade your existing equipment. Dome keeper lets you continue running with a novel feel each time due to the myriad of domes and equipments while wall world gives you upgrades to allow you to survive longer to reach further along the wall than you were previously capable of. This makes sense in the sense that there is essentially a new dimension in wall world that dome keeper is missing, the ability to physically change your scenario by picking up the dome and setting it somewhere else, and likely somewhere less hospitable. BUT, I think wall world takes it too far.

Wall world will give the late game player massive advantages, such as the ability to stomp on wall walking melee enemies, making them no longer a threat, or having a shield that regenerates every round at no cost at all, removing the health conservation you felt in dome keeper, if it had migrated over to this game at all. That is my qualms with this. At some points it upsets me, but again it does allow this game to be much more laid back of an experience.

[h3] Gameplay Loop [/h3]

Dome keeper lets the player use their available resources and their brainpower to effectively harvest ores in the mine and fend off natives from breaching the dome, but after the game you get more items and you are simply left to do the same thing again. Wall world expects you to die and keep replaying in order to win, and it expects you to die a lot. Every round you get points for mining which you spend on upgrades after you die; meaning, slowly you will get more capable at achieving your goals. This made me realize that Dome Keeper is missing a campaign sort of deal that you can sort of see in Wall World. 

[h3] Polish [/h3]

First thing I noticed playing this game was the movement. The player moves very sturdily; there is no smooth movement like most games. Maybe it's better, but it also doesn't really make sense. In my opinion the player would jump around the mines and have a jet back to boost himself, but in game it feels like the engineer isaac clarke guy moves like something out of scratch idk. Dome keeper has the player slide around, makes sense considering you are using jets. You don't stop the second you stop pressing down a movement key. A little thing that you get used to a couple hours in, but I'm trying to dig deep and I remember that bothering me.

The music in this game is great. It is very peaceful. There is one track that is really pleasing.

The artwork in this game is good, don't get me wrong; however, dome keeper has artwork that is just beautiful. It looks amazing, and I think that is the main thing people point out between these two games. This game has amazing details like the rain falling onto your dome vertically, I think that is really cool, but dome keeper did really nail the hostile planet setting quite well.

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]

I think both games are good. They are both fun. Dome keeper is a beautiful game. Wall world is easier to continue playing and dying in order to achieve my goals. In Dome Keeper if I die then i failed my goal, and am no closer to achieving it. I like it when the opposite happens, and this game does that. This game also lets you die and lets you play without really having to stress largely over time and dying. Dome keeper can be stressful, which can make it worse, but can also make it better. I think everbody should get both.

The game is generally playable, but you can see that it's absolutely unfinished. 

TLDR: The "cult management" aspect is shallow and empty, not balanced in the slightest.
---------------------------------------------------
1. There's not nearly enough paths to evolve into. Right now it doesn't have a path for even every general theme of your symbol. (no dinosaur cult, no great old ones cult)

2. The depth of the theme you choose is not even closely enough for a management sim saying you are "Managing your cult". There's only 3 special rooms, 2 garments, and 1 wall colour for every theme, and none of them are really useful so you can complete the game forgetting about them, only doing tasks for your theme progression.

3. Your choice of theme comes only around the second half of the game which means that you will in every playthrough have to do the very same things you do every time.

4. At least the Peace Path (perhaps also other 2) doesn't really have any kind of occult or mystical in it. And that is considering the game has canonical mythology creatures (Mages in events, Ghosts in Spirit Room, etc.). The game feels like every other general management sim.

5. Actually, it feels even worse because after about an hour of play it just turns into a tycoon/idle game where only thing you do is wait and do nothing, because there is virtually no possibility of losing it after you've got at least some basics and you only sit around having the game on your second screen, waiting for something to happen.

6. The followers to cultists system is absolutely broken. Even after building every single room and having your reputation maxed out, the followers that come to you can still very much have very poor quality, and good ones are extremely rare. And you also almost never know their actual quality because even with the right room, only about 1 follower a day will open their traits to you which normally results in them being kicked out because their quality is lower than the Bikini Bottom.

In the end, if you want anything that feels like a cult simulator and not a generic management sim with a fleur of something magical, don't buy this game | The game starts out failry entertaining but the poor UI design will have you clicking all over the place once your cult grows to a large size. Ever wondered what itâ€™s like to run your own cult? Well, Honey, I Joined a Cult lets you live that dream in the funniest and most chaotic way possible.

This game is a mix of hilarious storytelling, quirky management challenges, and endless creativity. You get to design everything about your cultâ€”its theme, its sacred objects, even the outfits your followers wear. Itâ€™s ridiculously fun to watch your compound grow as your followers (somehow) buy into your crazy ideas.

The graphics are cute and retro, which just makes the whole thing even more charming. But donâ€™t let that fool youâ€”thereâ€™s plenty of strategy involved. Youâ€™ll need to manage resources, keep your followers happy (or at least too busy to complain), and deal with all kinds of hilarious and random events that keep things interesting.

What really makes this game shine is the humor. It pokes fun at cult life in the best way, and I caught myself laughing out loud more than once. But itâ€™s also super addictiveâ€”one minute youâ€™re just tweaking your templeâ€™s decor, and the next youâ€™re building a global empire of believers.

If you love management games with a side of absurdity, this oneâ€™s for you. Honey, I Joined a Cult is a blast from start to finish.

10/10 Would definitely recruit new followers for the Great Cosmic Pineapple again!

I want to say that I enjoy "Survivor-Likes" a bit too much. I have played almost every version of them. (atleast it feels like it)

VS, HoT, Death Must Die, Deep Rock, Genesia, Army of Ruin and some more. Each 100 hours+.
Makes me want to believe, I can see the good and the ugly in these games.

Halls of Torment is in my opinion in the Top 3 of Survivor-Likes and even succeeds in almost every aspect of it's "father".

One of the major flaws (imo) I experienced in these types of games, is the end game. What happens if you unlocked everything. Upgraded everything to the max. 

Usually these games lose themselves in senselessness.



Halls of Torment has a very befitting name and for sure it reaches it's point of illogical endless progession too but they have found ways to make the gameplay, on the 1000x repeating maps, quite interesting. 

You have a good arrangement of characters, each (so they make it feel) with their handcrafted and thought-through designs. They feel very unique and you can experiment alot. 

On top of that add some Items, some of them are mandatory for specific builds but yet there's alot of freedom to experiment around because they managed to keep most of them very useful.

That alone already sold me for most of the time I enjoyed the game. 

If one goes further they have added a cute endless mode. Cute because I personally love endless modes but this one didn't hit me as hard as some other games. You can pay gold to get random debuffs on your next endless run. Which I think can be alot of fun but I enjoyed their "Artifacts" far more.

You can play the basic maps with a mutator but the good thing here is you can decide which ones and how many you take, though each artifact will buff enemies base-stats no matter which artifact you pick. (...and yourself by granting more xp.)

That is in which I have lost myself, enjoying this game just the last few weeks.

If you manage to debuff the hell out of your run and kill the bosses in the end you get a currency to endlessly upgrade your characters. 

Now the kicker: In other games you have 100 of the progression upgrade-thingies.
You apply it to one character. 
Now you have 0 upgrade-thingies. Here you can upgrade them all simultaneously.

Fcking broke my mind.

First I resetted all the stats before applying it to a different character, because I was so used to games robbing your time and making you upgrade all characters each on their own.

But in HoT even characters you "don't like" will become viable only by playing your favorite character.


Halls of Torment. A big YES!

On the other hand, that is all it has going for it, yet it still sits at 95% positive reviews. This rating seems too far from what I think it deserves, so I want to shine some light on its weak points to help out those who got blinded by the visuals (you know who you are).

tl;dr: Game has no performance issues and looks like Diablo (which is 95% of its merit). Gameplay is unengaging and grindy and peaks at "not harsh anymore". Not good, far from fun, just "not as bad as it was starting out". 
If you REALLY need your survivor-like to look like Diablo, then go for it. Otherwise go for Holocure or Death Must Die (or Vampire Survivors) as they all outclass it in every aspect aside from maybe your personal preference in visual style.

Be warned that a long, rambling yap is following.
The game starts slow, as in "your character moves at a snail pace and barely clears the enemies" slow. Matches the visual style and the unforgiving gameplay of the era that its visuals draw from, but that's about as far as the compromise goes. Maps have a few different point of interests you can reach, but due to the movement speed you likely won't get to complete more than one set of them at a time during your first runs, if at all. Combat feels adequate, with some desperately needed stat increases on level up to make your first character not fall behind too far and maybe survive 10-15 minutes on your first try.
Go back to the camp and spend a few coins on meta upgrades to your stats. Rinse and repeat a few times until you get enough stats to have your character not feel crippled, but instead appropriate to have a chance at clearing the level. Repeat for 10 hours until you realize that the grind never stops and you have yet to reach the point where you feel strong instead of handicapped, and the game did not hit actual fun territory once during your playtime.

Sounds overly dramatic, but that is what my experience with the game was like. 
It is understandable for your power level to be too low for a chance to clear the first map on your first tries, but here it feels sadistic. You move slowly, barely get to pickup resources due to your tiny pickup range, and attack slowly. Once enemies start to come in at a faster pace it won't take long to die. It takes a few runs to grind enough stats to have enough power to clear, and even more if you want to get some QOL stats, such as movement speed and pickup range, just for gameplay to be less [i] tedious [/i]. The first map and its accompanying missions provide enough motivation and rewards to offer a quick increase in power level, but all that does is unveil the plethora of other systems the game has been graciously saving so you don't get swamped with too many grinds at once.
One at a time you get to unlock (and grind to upgrade) meta progression such as: more stats to upgrade, reroll and banish options on level up, items to equip, and also new classes. Just for those you will need to run maps plenty of times, not only do you collect currencies, the equipment you want to unlock only reaches your camp if you collect them during a run and then send it back, one at a time, during the level to save it, and thus have access to it in future runs. You need to sacrifice power during any given run in favor of meta progression since you lose a well needed upgrade to unlock it permanently. On its own that sounds fine, but it is so slow. You only get to do that for one item per run (at first? Could be upgradable, but who cares to play enough to find out), and with the amount and variety you want to build up for the roster of heroes, that is gonna take a LOT of runs you play just to collect items and send them back. And then do it again, but this time purposely pick an item that does not fit your class, but hasn't been unlocked. And then again. And there is no other option, such as playing well and getting to carry out all the items you carry. Only the one item you send back to camp, everything else collected is lost.

Is that bad? So bad that I would go out of my way to write a negative review?
No, but it's one of the more egregious systems that require running maps over and over. The real bad part is that running maps is not fun. The core gameplay that the meta systems loop you around is slow and unrewarding, and that is the actual sin.
I started out talking about the game feeling slow, which is due to the default movement speed, along with attack speed and no access to advanced skills. This gets better after all, since your gold goes into rectifying that. But then you complete dozens of runs and find out that the game is a different kind of slow aside from the meta grind: Actually clearing maps is an uninteractive waiting around until the time ticks down. Once you hit the desired power level to comfortably grind meta items, you get to enjoy not being threatened by mobs anymore. That is where you find out that leveling up is presenting you with a screen showing multiple rewards to pick from, yet there is no real decision to be made. It might have felt like it during the first map when every stat was lacking, and you had to assess which area was lacking most at any given moment, but later on those stat increases become less impactful. The real meat should be in the advanced skills you get to upgrade every few levels, yet there is not enough variety among their upgrade paths, or interactions between skills to force any actual decision making. Skills are just a different visual that enemies die to. No matter which one I committed to, the gameplay felt the same. The way you move and engage with enemies does not change depending on what you picked. It is easy to see the clear best option, and then it is back to waiting for another 5 level ups to pick another one. There is no crafting a build in this game, no theory crafting synergies, there is only choosing which skill you want to carry you through a level, and then investing in it once unlocked. 
And once you do, it doesn't even get fun. Even with a strong loadout and great items, you might be strong and delete enemies, yet not even this state is actually fun to be at. Enemies come at you too slow to make it satisfactory, so even the ideal endgame power level is just...not fun. After all the grinding to get past the painful early stats, and the grinding to unlock enough meta systems, and enough grind to earn meta currencies, you go into a run, auto pilot your "build", and the reward is watching enemies not kill you. You don't explode the screen, no shredding hordes of mobs that threatened you before. No happy brain chemicals. The game goes from "you feel slow and weak" to "you are not slow and not weak anymore". The best it gets is not being painful. Gameplay peaks at "not bad" instead of good, let alone actually fun. This is the real death sentence.

Torturous beginning that flows into a steady stream of meta systems that require grinding their currencies. A slog of repeating maps and doing runs that do not require actual decision making, and do not offer the depth to allow theory crafting build. All of that just to make a character reach a power level where you do not die, and do not even get any real satisfaction of looking at waves get annihilated, but instead just trickle in through the border of your screen before dying. A roster of characters that play too similar and not engage or synergize with skills either, so no real depth here either. Pick whoever has the best stats, and by the time you hit level 10 in the level, it's all the same.

This game encourages you to grind a boring repetition of levels and refuses to acknowledge good gameplay with meta rewards or even the basic satisfaction of "build goes brrrrrr". Painfully tedious at the beginning, slightly less tedious by the time you realize that is all it has, and drop it for a better game. Ğ§Ñ‚Ğ¾ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğµ, ĞµÑĞ»Ğ¸ ÑƒĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ´Ğ°ÑÑ‰ÑƒÑ Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ³ÑƒÑ€Ñƒ Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½ÑˆĞ¾Ñ‚ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ĞºĞ½ĞµÑ‚, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»... | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | It was a great fun game with levels that get a little bit harder, and you can get different shotguns and after each round you pick a card that upgrades your side, and the enemy. The normal amount of turns in a round is maybe 20-30, and 9 rounds in the level and i think 8 levels. There is also endless and chase.
 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.

If you're looking for a cozy train game, this is not it. It went from fun to stupid hard very quickly. If you like to bash your head against brain-straining puzzles then you will enjoy this game. If you want some relaxing wind-down time, this is not the game for you. | This game is the definition of a [i]cozy[/i] puzzle game:

 - The visuals are great and satisfying to look at, especially the transition of the land when a line is completed.
 - The soundtrack is great and gives the game a good feel.
 - The puzzles are not hard, at all. They are not "easy" but also not unsolvable and have a lot of room for errors which makes the game way less frustrating.
 - Trains.

I really enjoyed playing this game and would recommend it to anyone who just wants to chill out and pass the time. It also contains a level editor and procedural levels, if you are done or want to build something, by yourself, so even if you are not keen on solving a puzzle, you can just build something nice. | connect dots - the game!
- now with great voxel graphics

I expected a train game. It's too simple and there are no train mechanics at all. | It was good up to certain point, the more  you advance the messier it gets and it's more stressful with ugly train lines than cozy.

In the puzzle way of thinking is just good. I would still recommend it because sometimes is satisfying to make some crazy connections that reward you a lot. 

Buy on sale. | I'm generally not a fan of these level-based logistics games. I like to have just one map and build forever, but I can live with it if they're really good. This one has just not gripped me. The types of challenges that it has are not interesting and not very intuitive. I also don't really like that you're not really managing trains, just connecting stations and everything else is automatic. It just wasn't able to hold my attention despite being the type of game I usually like.

Genres: Action, Casual, Indie, RPG, Early Access
Reviews:
The game is very fun but it will never go out of early access, devs are very lazy or the business model sucks and they are out of funds. Almost the same state of the game was available 1 year ago. I thought buying the early access would speed up the process, but it seems game is going to the void. | It might be a bit controversial to say this, but I like this game more than the Hades series. I don't know exactly why, but something about this game makes me want to keep playing it and spend hours on it. Don't get me wrong, I loved Hades, but Death Must Die is a better alternative in my book. Not because it's too simple or easy to play. Death Must Die is a really challenging and hard game. Also, I love the easy pacing of this game, to be fair, yes it's a bit repetitive right now but it's still an early access game and the developers are working on pumping out new updates and keep adding new things to the game. Looking forward to the new updates. | Game is Good. It would be better if there is a Chinese version. | Only 2 levels right now - This game is awesome and I have been playing it a lot. I reached the end of the second level though and realized there are no more. Now what? I have gotten 20 some hours out of this game but this took most of the enjoyment out it for me. Kind of a let down unfortunately. | Honestly. It is a quite decent Survivor-Like.
Problem is their updating cycles. Updates feel like they take ages,
and that update introducing Mastery Trees really kicked it out for me.

It limited all characters to playstyles you get from their respective Mastery Tree.
Forcing characters to be played with certain attributes,
which you maybe didn't even want.

You have almost an unlimited, boundless variety of items. Too much if you ask me.
Some giving stats that are useless or do not explain how they work.

For example (if I remember correctly) you had the Attribute "+1 Power - Projectile"
Means all Abilities in the "Power-Class" get 1 Projectile.
One Power-Ability is an Aura and if I remember correctly it sadly didn't double the aura, no your "Power-Ability" needs to have a projectile so that your Attribute can function.

So often you get Items that are almost perfect but have that one trait that just goofs it all up.

Was fun the first few hours and I tried to find my fun after the update but I have lost my appetite.

And they released it 2023? What did we have like 2 updates that really changed some things?

I cannot recommend it anymore.

I love the concept of this game but it does get dull quickly, which is not what you should think for a game that only lasts about 10 hours. Only a few hours in and I started seeing the same conversations happening and I would just revisit the lighthouse on repeat whenever those freaks asked me to because they've decided reality TV is the best means of gazing at lighthouses and that's the only way to not get laid off. I do think this game is very funny and looks great.

There aren't many games like this one and if this matches your freak AND you understand it's flawed, then this game is worth a shot. But for your general viewing audience, just try watching Real Housewives or something. | This game has a good premise and fun mechanics. I actually look forward to see where the story takes me.

However, the game suffers from repetitive dialogue at parts where it doesn't make sense. Changing up the morning dialogue from season to season just a little bit would have gone a long way. 

Another glaring issue is the color palette. Bright, over-saturated pastels make this game difficult to play and watch as was noted over and over by those daring to check out my livestream. | I straight up do not understand the hate for this game. I loved it!! I bought it after it was mentioned on a Yahtzee video, and had a great time. 

I don't find the gameplay repetitive; if you are playing through the main storyline, you should be chasing different goals each time. If people are finding it repetitive, I'd recommend trying different cast members [spoiler]and making sure that you are talking to everyone at night.[/spoiler] There is also a fast way to end days, [spoiler]dying.[/spoiler] You can do this at pretty much any point. Just like real life!

I know I enjoyed seeing all of the interactions with different characters and the variations for each individual character. It was also a fun puzzle to see how I could get the most audience engagement at the same time. 

The ending does leave a lot unanswered, which is a bummer, but I still enjoyed my time. 

I'm replaying it now [spoiler]to get the second ending, [/spoiler]and by the way, I really recommend a certain ORDER OF OPERATIONS. Without spoiling, just. Just trust the [b]AL[/b]PHAB[b]E[/b]T when it comes to what CHOICES you might MAKE. Unless you want to start from the beginning. So yeah, the replay value is meh, but it's not as rough as others said. I'm still finding new dialogue and I'm enjoying the e[b]x[/b]tra hard mode now that I know how to please the audiences. 

Look, i[b]f[/b] you like a s[b]i[/b]lly little time with a bit of myste[b]r[/b]y, you'll have a ball! It's a fun little puzzle with funny writing, entertaining character[b]s[/b], a gripping gameplay loop, and an in[b]t[/b]riguing, if not fully fleshed out, mystery. I like it and am going to get it for my friend who loves reality TV. 

part of me also wonders if some of the hate may come from the children and losers who like to find random games and just trash them/complain about them being "too woke" bc the game has gay ppl lol | Game was fun but is unplayable because of crashing.
