æ€»çš„æ¥è¯´æ˜¯å€¼å¾—ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½è¯„çš„ï¼Œå…¥æ‰‹æ¨èå²ä½ï¼Œå¦DLCé£è¯„è¿œä¸å¦‚æœ¬ä½“ï¼Œæ…å…¥ã€‚ | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | ä¸å…¶è¯´æ˜¯åŸå¸‚è¥é€ æˆ–è€…åŸºåœ°å»ºè®¾ï¼Œæ›´åƒæ˜¯æœ‰é™èµ„æºç®¡ç†æ¸¸æˆï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆæˆ‘çš„å…´è¶£

Some, but not much, skill (movement) is required (depending on your build).  The graphics are great, the weapon effects are awesome!  The floor scaling is well designed.  The itemization is phenomenal.  While this game does so many things well, I have a few suggestions:

1. Add additional music track(s).  The floor track is great, but 1 track only gets old quick.
2. Incorporate some kind of guidebook that explains what things are, how they work, etc.  I'm glad that you don't force a tutorial on players, but there's a small bit of learning curve, via trial and error that could be fixed if people could simply find a resource that explained what certain things are (for example, what drops from barrels, how # of inventory slots are obtained after each floor etc).

Those are the only major "flaws" if you call it that.  Otherwise, I'd love to see an infinity tower that lets you keep going beyond floor 20.  And more content!  Add more items.  Downloadable item packs, etc.  I really love this game, but want even more!   Great job, devs! | When you have backpack hero meets roguelite, you get God of Weapons.

Very unique , interesting game style & mechanics.

Hope to see more content from the devs!

Definitely money Worth!
Highly recommend! | Not memorable in the genre. Once you understand item system (like in few runs) it becomes boring for first 20-30 levels which consumes half an hour each run.
- You can literally just stay in middle and past the first 10-15 levels.
- Even after, you can easily past level 20 with minimal move right or left.
- You cant save between runs. If you need to quit its over

In short if you are not going to play like more than 1 hour for 1 run you cant play this game.
I rarely killed in the run, most of the times it past 1 hour or so and I got bored and need to quit because there is not save.

As a fan of Luck Be a Landlord, Endgame of Devil and emergent gameplay, I really dig this game!

18 hours in. Still enjoying the game BUT success IS HIGHLY dependent on RNG with little you can do to mitigate it, at least at 18 hours in. I have played the same battle over dozens of times only to come up short at the last boss. Difficult but enjoyable but I feel that it needs more ways to leverage the RNG and roll-overs for unit stats are sorely needed.

Deceive Inc. is a undercover "Battle Royale" where you disguise yourself as npc to extract the briefcase from a vault against other teams of players.

This game tested your mettle in how much of an NPC you can realistically look like while fooling the other players. It's sad that this game is no longer getting updated, but the player base for the game is basically gone at this point. It took me forever to find matches to complete all the achievements for this game.

My friends and I had a lot of fun setting up traps for others teams, or acting completely like NPC's and then taking them out from behind. It would be nice if they made the game at least F2P for a while so other people could experience the fun I had, but finding a match is almost impossible at this point. 

I'm still going to recommend it based on what it was, rather than what it is now. | It's a great shame this game has such a minuscule playerbase at the moment, it's a truly fun, creative and overall well-designed game.

The mix of stealth and tense chases is just as, if not more enjoyable than the combat, which is rather enjoyable itself. i have played a lot of games, for a long time. many different genres, design sensiblities, and art styles, across several decades, on so many different systems. from NetHack to Hades II, from SpaceChem to Cookie Clicker, from DOOM (1993) to DOOM (2016).

this, for my money, might be the best game ever made.

intuitively simple; exquisitely complex and deep. i have every achievement and still cannot see a future where i don't play this anymore. arguably, this video game's existence is a testament to the undying creativity of the human spirit --- that we make works of dear significance and utter perfection almost by accident simply by following those pursuits we enjoy most.

furthermore, here i am, inspired to write all this pseudopoetic drivel about a video game next to meme reviews by accounts pretending to be Goku or whatever. but i wouldn't be sitting here calling it the best game ever made if it didn't also drive me to write "the undying creativity of the human spirit" in a steam review

Moves are unlocked using â€œstickersâ€ which can be removed from beasts and added to others as often as you like, which makes for some really unique combinations and lets you play the game your way. 

Also the soundtrack is boss.

I want to like this game, but the truth is it feels the exact same 12 hours in as it does 30 minutes into it.  Maybe a slight bit faster, but not much.  

This is what building a game by the numbers feels like.  "We want each difficulty to be 10% more difficult."  That's what this feels like, and very little changes that.  The permanent upgrades you can get for each class are so small and insignificant that they may as well not exist.  They are often just 2 or 3 level upgrades, which you can get literally by the hundreds once you get going.

2.4/5 - Needs tuning.  So close to great, but not quite there. | omg this is amazing fun
you're basically a little turret (despite your character choice) and you have to kill the waves of enemies from each direction
can you survive 20 nights? 
it starts out seeming easy but it ramps up in a fun way
the upgrade paths are a cool way to do this instead of "choose one" like other roguelites
the presentation is on point, when it gets serious the music gets more intense and it's such a rush

this is a wonderful game for the price, get it you'll have fun | This is a neat game with a really fun idea as well as lots of things to unlock.

The gameplay loop itself is really simple, monsters come towards you from 4 different directions, you need to kill them.
Whether you'll be using arrows, mines, magic, minions, swords all depends on your chosen character and the talents you pick as the night progresses.

There's many different talents to find and many of them being unlockable. You can unlock new sets of talents by just doing runs with that character.
There's also challenges that unlock new talents or skins, though I am not a big fan of the skins since I'd rather have had something more serious and cool looking than the more goofy skins the characters get (at least the ones I have seen) but that's just my opinion).

This game is something you can play for 20-30 minutes every so often, it is quite fun and quite original :D | "Talented" was fun for a few hours, but it has what I might uncharitably refer to as "dim man's depth": it presents many choices but ultimately, subject to a few very basic common sense principles one could easily boil down to a rather simple set of algorithms (like selecting best "scaling of scaling"), there's very little by way of truly satisfying skill going on. Decent time sink, but fans of serious strategy will find themselves pondering "is this it?" because there's not much true player agency and only a rather basic sort of decision making. It's done well to "package" that limited bundle of choices in such a way that people who frankly aren't that bright will be convinced it's much deeper than it is though.

If you love the process of selecting skills much more than actually using them precisely or skillfully, you'll probably be extra likely to get some enjoyment here. This is definitely true for some people who just really love "builds". Prospective players should beware the tags, however (for anyone buying on that basis), I really wouldn't call this an action roguelike in any meaningful way. It would be much more accurately described as a roguelite autobattler that plays like something bordering on a TD with a very big emphasis on hard power mechanics and selecting upgrades for optimum raw power scaling.

As for me, while I had fun, the 8 hours I've put in now is already more than enough. I won my first however many runs maybe like 8 or something without any losses or serious difficulty and I don't know, there just really wasn't much to it getting on the right side of the optimisation problem it presented, and for me at least, nailing optimisation problems like this only really feels truly satisfying if I don't also feel like any random key pressing monkey could have pulled off much the same thing. Children and teens might get more mileage here than adult players I think, and ultimately a game being simple is not exactly a bad thing, it's just that like I said, I'd be a teensy bit weary about the accuracy of the user tags.

Talented is adding a serviceable piece of content to the market, so it's a lukewarm but amiable recommended / thumbs up from me. | æœ‰è¶£è€Œä»¤äººç€è¿·çš„è½»é‡çº§roguelikeï¼Œè™½ç„¶éšæœºç”Ÿæˆçš„æŠ€èƒ½æ ‘ä¹Ÿæ— æ³•æŠ¹å¹³æ¯å±€æ¸¸æˆä¸­åæœŸç•¥æ˜¾é‡å¤çš„ä½“éªŒï¼Œä½†å¯¹ä¸€ä¸ª18rçš„æ¸¸æˆæ¥è¯´å·²ç»è¶³å¤Ÿå¥½äº†

Black Skylands à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¸­à¸µà¸à¹€à¸à¸¡à¸™à¸¶à¸‡à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸ªà¸™à¸¸à¸à¹à¸¥à¸°à¹„à¸¡à¹ˆà¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸™à¹ˆà¸²à¸œà¸´à¸”à¸«à¸§à¸±à¸‡à¹€à¸¥à¸¢ à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸ªà¸™à¸¸à¸à¸ˆà¸²à¸à¸à¸²à¸£à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸ªà¸³à¸£à¸§à¸ˆà¹„à¸›à¸¢à¸±à¸‡à¹€à¸à¸²à¸°à¸•à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¹† à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸šà¸¹à¹Šà¸—à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¹€à¸”à¸´à¸™à¸¢à¸´à¸‡à¹€à¸­à¸‡à¸à¸±à¸šà¸¢à¸´à¸‡à¹€à¸£à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸«à¸²à¸°à¹ƒà¸ªà¹ˆà¸à¸±à¸™ à¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¹€à¸à¸¥à¸´à¸™à¸ˆà¸²à¸à¸à¸²à¸£à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¸Ÿà¸²à¸£à¹Œà¸¡à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¸¡à¸²à¸­à¸±à¸à¸­à¸¹à¸›à¸à¸£à¸“à¹Œà¸—à¸±à¹‰à¸‡à¸­à¸²à¸§à¸¸à¸˜à¸à¸±à¸šà¹€à¸£à¸·à¸­à¹€à¸«à¸²à¸° à¹€à¸™à¸·à¹‰à¸­à¹€à¸£à¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸‡à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸™à¹ˆà¸²à¸ªà¸™à¹ƒà¸ˆà¹à¸¥à¸°à¸ªà¸™à¸¸à¸à¹ƒà¸Šà¹‰à¹„à¸”à¹‰ à¸­à¸²à¸ˆà¸ˆà¸°à¸¡à¸µà¸•à¸´à¸”à¸™à¸´à¸”à¸«à¸™à¹ˆà¸­à¸¢à¹€à¸£à¸·à¹ˆà¸­à¸‡à¸­à¸ªà¸šà¸²à¸‡à¸•à¸±à¸§à¸à¸±à¸šà¸„à¸§à¸²à¸¡à¸‹à¹‰à¸³à¸‹à¸²à¸à¸šà¸²à¸‡à¸Šà¹ˆà¸§à¸‡ à¹à¸•à¹ˆà¸à¹‡à¸¢à¸±à¸‡à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¹€à¸à¸¡à¸¢à¸´à¸‡à¸Ÿà¸²à¸£à¹Œà¸¡à¸‚à¸­à¸‡à¹€à¸à¸¥à¸´à¸™à¹†à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸”à¸µà¸¡à¸²à¸à¹†à¹€à¸à¸¡à¸™à¸¶à¸‡ à¹à¸­à¸šà¹à¸™à¸°à¸™à¸³à¸•à¸­à¸™à¸¡à¸±à¸™à¸¥à¸”à¸«à¸£à¸·à¸­à¸‹à¸·à¸­à¹à¸à¸„à¸„à¸¹à¹ˆà¸à¸±à¸š Planet of Lana à¹€à¸¥à¸¢à¸„à¸£à¸±à¸š à¸„à¸¸à¸“à¸ˆà¸°à¹„à¸”à¹‰à¹€à¸à¸¡à¸™à¹‰à¸³à¸”à¸µà¸ªà¸­à¸‡à¹€à¸à¸¡à¹€à¸¥à¹ˆà¸™à¸£à¸§à¸”à¹€à¸¥à¸¢
 | It's entertaining for the time you spend with it, though it loses some steam towards the end.

If you like what you see from the trailer video and aren't looking for a masterpiece, I would say to go for it!

All that being said, it feels like a game where the developers ran out of time and pushed it out the door.  The narrative is bare-bones but functional, the combat it fine, the gameplay loop is entertaining enough.  But it constantly feels underbaked and that if the developers had put a little more time into it, this could've really been exceptional.

My hope is that the developers learn from this and that we see what this game could have been in one of their next titles.

2/5 Stars if I was to give it a rating. 

Played on Steamdeck. 

The game is trying to be a few too many things at the same time and is I think maybe spread a bit too then as a result. 

What I liked: 
- The world building within the books. The spaceship and train books were really cool conceptually! 
- The art style, and overall aesthetic both visually and audibly. 

What I didn't like: 
- No fail state, not that I want this to be dark souls but if you present turn based combat the actual outcome of losing is completely null. You get kicked out of the book and the enemies you were fighting are more than often just gone, so its an easy win. 
- The combat isn't fun or engaging but a way to prolong your playtime by maybe 2 minutes. Its really boring. 
- The illusion of choice, often the game would give you dialogue choices, you would pick one, then another and then magically a third one would show up. It became predictable and eventually revealed itself to be linear in nature but presenting the illusion of choice. 
- The actual puzzles - I think some were kind of serviceable but mostly they were find the right thing to click, or item to use and then use it on the thing. Problem is, is that there was generally only one obstacle at any given time. On top of that, your NPC companion would often tell you what to do. Now there is a hint function, but I am stating that he would tell you sometimes before you even had a chance to maybe think about using it. 

Finally, the actual story conceptually is interesting. A guy with writers block, in a world that has these laws, does illegal thievery of items from books and brings them to and from the fictional world to his own world. Cool. Unfortunately the final act feels rushed, not dramatic, and felt frustrating when it just kind of wrapped up. 

I was hoping for more, but got a linear walking simulator with the illusion of choice, combat and puzzles. Definitely worth buying with a discount. | I really loved Saints Row 3 and 4 and even going into the Saint's Row reboot with low expecations left me more than disappointed.

I can live with the weird gameplay choices and also the not very well received characters but besides that, the game is just broken and shouldn't be up for sale. The whole audio in this game doesn't work properly - being it sound effects not playing or just horribly mixed or just being straight up bad. It is just not fun at all and should officially be erased from the franchise. | Not as horrible as many seem to believe, but not a great game either.
The SR series has been a bit "rinse and repeat" for awhile now (just a collection of side activities and challenges to repeat, with the same flavour of comedy throughout, and fairly basic missions to string it together), but if you really enjoy the other games in the series, there isn't really any reason you wouldn't enjoy this one.

The only possibly "game breaking" issues I encountered were:

Some collectables seem to disappear at times, but a reload or travelling to another area seemed to fix it.

DX12 mode seems to become unstable if there's too much going on, and it will crash your graphics card. This happens even on a decent machine, but seems to stop when using DX11. | after getting 100% completion on this game, i am more than qualified to say that this game sucks and i hate myself for even forcing myself to complete it

The gameplay is boring, the story makes no sense, the characters are beyond insufferable, the side missions are tedious and the enviorment is dull. O yeah and the bugs, there is literally a common bug which makes you unable to leave your car or even PAUSE THE GAME, you have to alt+tab to exit the game.

All the enemies have way to much health so the combat is neither challenging nor does it make you feel powerfull. Take downs now need to be charged up and the animations drag on way to long. Human shield are completly gone. Granades are now a skill you have to unlock and assign as one of your 4 skills. Nearly all the skills and perks either suck or beter left as upgrades. The player customization feels limited and all the clothing options are scathered across different interchangeable stores. All the minigames/activities are not very fun, most of them are just you listining to the dialogue, than you shoot some enemies, than you drive for a bit and your done. Even in insurance fraud you feel weirdly heavy like a floating wet piece of paper. All the collectables are also annoying to collect.

The plot feels all over the place and unfocused. Almost every mission can be summerised as "you and your friends decide they want to do X, than a shootout happens". Your friends are the most annoying losers to have graced this earth. There's Kevin who is a quirky bisexual DJ, who is always shirtless because LOL XD (he's basical;y this games version of Johnny Gat except he's not cool). There's Eli, he's the stereotypical Steve Urkle who really cares about money and finance (
he's Pierce exept he's not charming or funny). There's Neenah, who's the mechanic and getaway driver (she helps you get away only in like one cutscene), she's also into art and seeks revenge for the destruction over her mother's car (she's Shaundi, but she's angry over a car, it's just a stupid car). There's also the character who obviously will betray you (the prologue just spoils it). There's also a McGuffin book, it's never explained what does it do it's just valuable and everyone want's it for some reason. The three enemy gangs are forgetable and are one by one completly dealt with in 4 back to back missions. Also there's a cat. Did i mention this game doesn't take it self seriously and treats it self more like a crappy episode of friends rather than a Quentin Tarantino movie or a crime simulator?

TL;DR just don't buy this game. It's better to just play the older saints row games. Saints row 2 is still a very good game despite the pc port being very buggy and prone to crashing (even with mods and patches). 3 is also pretty good and is a lot more stable on pc. 4 i only recommend to those who already liked the previous games or really want a prototype 3

è°¢è°¢ä½ ï¼ŒLarianã€‚

A Love Letter to the Ninth Art â€“ A Middle-Aged Player's 100-Hour Journey Through Baldur's Gate 3

As someone nearing forty, with both elderly parents and young children to care for, finding large chunks of time to sit in front of a computer and savor a game is no easy feat. This Spring Festival, I made up my mind to finally taste this cup of coffee that had been brewing for years. With the understanding and support of my wife (for which I am deeply grateful), I managed to carve out a week to indulge in uninterrupted play. After 99 hours and 40 minutes, I completed the game. Sitting in front of the screen late at night, I was left in awe, unable to shake the profound impact it had on me. This journey will undoubtedly remain one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life, a radiant milestone in my personal gaming history.

What Larian has created here is far from an ordinary video game.

As a game, every design element is seamlessly integrated, perfectly balanced. The freedom it offers is almost overwhelmingâ€”you can truly be yourself. The equipment, levels, and stats are meticulously crafted, catering to a broad spectrum of players.

As music, Down by the River drifts with the breeze, becoming a flowing narrative. I Want to Live tears at your soul during moments of decision, and The Power resonates as you grasp the prism in victory. Each theme song fits its scene so perfectly that it transcends the medium, transforming into an interactive symphonic poem that I found myself revisiting and reflecting on long after the game had ended.

As a novel, the content itself is a masterful piece of fantasy literature. The writers clearly possess the skill to craft a best-selling fantasy novel. Themes of justice versus evil, life versus death, and killing versus sparing provoke deep philosophical reflection. If watching a movie in a theater is like spending 2.5 hours appreciating a thought-provoking film, then Baldur's Gate 3 is like spending over 100 hours living a tumultuous, magical life filled with difficult choices and moral dilemmas.

I named my final save file in the camp, where I chatted with everyone before the end, "Do Not Want to Say Farewell." After journeying together, sharing both hardships and triumphs with these friends and comrades, I truly wished we could continue living together. I exhausted every dialogue option in the camp, searching for more interactions, especially with Shadowheart, whose seven or eight hugs still lingered with the warmth of data. I couldnâ€™t bear to say goodbye. Yet, Larian, in their cruel yet merciful way, allowed each companion to move forward with their scarsâ€”some destined to carry the stars on their shoulders, others to return to the mundane life of hearth and home. This, perhaps, is the most tender form of realism: all encounters must eventually be returned to the passage of time.

Thus, my Dungeons & Dragons tale has been sealed in the evening breeze of the Sword Coast. In this lifetime, I will return to experience the lives of Astarion and other characters. Perhaps this is the greatness of CRPGs: they allow us, in the crevices of our real lives, to live countless versions of ourselves we never had the chance to be.

While there are some criticisms and suggestions for improvement regarding BG3, they are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless gem. Some aspects could indeed be tweaked for player convenience, while others are subjective preferences rather than flaws.

Once youâ€™ve spent 10-15 hours learning the gameâ€™s mechanics and fundamental principles, crossing that threshold, you canâ€™t help but marvel at how Larian managed to create such a masterpiece. If this work remains unrivaled, itâ€™s because it is truly exquisite and deserves to be cherished. If it is ever surpassed, then another jewel will have been added to the annals of gaming history, another gift for us all.

This game has taken over my life and I love it so much, lol, and showing no signs of putting it down any time soon! | I started playing this game a year and a few months after it was launched and immediately got into character creation which took me over an hour not to mention building my Dream Guardian. Since purchasing it at full price, I was weary to buy a game for 60 bucks, but it has been the best 60 bucks I've spent in a LONG time. 

The whole game itself doesn't hold your hand during the game, but it does help you build up your skills and learn how to play as you go which is great for those who haven't played CRPG turn based game before. I have basically played this nonstop since October to pass time and as you can see with my 527 hours on record, I absolutely LOVE this game. The options for responses and endings are endless. I'm thoroughly blown away with the voice acting and, yes, the mod options. There are many people who hate playing with mods, but to me it adds a lot to the game and enhances my game play experience making me want to play it more. I have done numerous campaigns and as of January 2025, I'm doing my 2nd durge campaign trying to play a somewhat evil character which is hard as I've cried from being evil to pixels haha. 

Overall, I think this game may be the best game I've ever played and I love how Larian and the VA's show their active participation in the community along with Larian giving us FREE updates and gives modders the toolkit. This company could've charged $100 or more for this game with the amount of work and thought put into it along with the (again) FREE updates, but they didn't. They have shown they care more for the player's experience and making a game that out beats other new games and certain *ahem developers AHEM Bethesda* by giving us a game that is completed at release (from what I've been told by other gamers who played this at release). I recommend this game to anyone who wants a rich, fulfilling game that doesn't have any extra catches outside the initial price. | I have played this game for 6 hours (2h on character creator), never played this type of game before.. can say I am impressed and enjoying it a lot.

18 hours in the game: I think that I'm addicted. The stories are surprising and wholesome. I feel like a hero in this game, living for the good of the people.

50 hours: I finally finished act 1. And oh boy did I turn from good to evil with every step I took. I didn't mean to be... How was I supposed to know that pulling the wrong lever, I'll be catapulting a gnome to space. That wasn't my fault.

80 hours: Yes! Give me your gold. All the shiny trinkets you have. Give me your soul and all the power you hold. Give me more... MORE!

100 hours: How dare you look down on me, thinking like you could ever defeat me?! Hit me with all you got, it will never be enough!

120 hours: ... *only screams echo in the darkness* ...

130 hours: *Muahahaha-*
You may call me the blood queen,
but your agenda is also driven by greed.
The battle you lost, your advisors lied.
Your heroes are dead, your city is mine.
No evil as dark or vengeance as red,
have never been seen as I took the kings head.

Unlike some other games, you do not need to spend a whole days working at a map; sometimes a half hour is enough, leaving you time to play another round or just to avoid the necessity of trying to cram two hours of sleep before the morning alarm clock. There are many modes to try; I particularly like the Hegemony battles - not because I always win but because I sometimes don't although I wish there were a forum for each of the various civilisations (factions) so that I could see if there are other players that consistently favour one or some civs over others rather than just wondering if folks are merely jumping onto the bandwagon of the one leading faction.. The developers are good at staying on top of the little issues. | Not a bad game per session, and I was actually having a lot of fun. Until I went to multiplayer.

The movement there is just broken to the point of being unplayable.
Everyone makes the orders on their turn, then the movement and attacks happen in a seemingly random order.
This means that if you're the last in turn order you can get your big unit move blocked by a scout. 
You'll get shot first before getting to do anything. 
You'll get flanked because you've not moved yet, so the enemy has perfect knowledge.
You'll have your disembarks move blocked - the charge card you paid for? Wasted. Pick a different cell next turn? Then can just move to it.

It's not just bad, it's infuriatingly unfair if you're not player 1. | This is not civ. It doesn't pretend to be civ. If you want a week long cozy game of civ, go buy civ. Or buy it anyway and leave a long review about how it's not civ. You do you.

Risk of Rain Returns has completely won me over, despite my usual aversion to rogue-likes and platformers. The gameâ€™s music struck the perfect balanceâ€”catchy and immersive, without being overpoweringâ€”and the visuals were clean and appealing, with a unique art style that kept me engaged throughout. What really hooked me, though, was the sense of progression. The game makes you feel like you're constantly growing stronger, whether you're playing solo or teaming up with friends. The artifacts, which let you customize your experience, add an extra layer of depth and replayability that you donâ€™t really get with most games.The best part? The game doesnâ€™t let you off the hook with a single playthrough. Beating the final boss feels like just the beginning, as youâ€™ve only scratched the surface of the gameâ€™s true potential. After a month of playing and 87 hours logged, Iâ€™m only 61% through all the content the game has to offer, which speaks volumes about its replay value. Risk of Rain Returns is the perfect game to pick up for a quick session or dive into for hours on end, and I can already tell Iâ€™ll be playing it for a long time to come. Itâ€™s got the kind of addicting quality that keeps you coming back, and I can easily say this is one of the most satisfying, rewarding experiences Iâ€™ve had in a video game in a while. Thank you, Dakota

å¦‚æœä½ æ˜¯ï¼šçœ‹ææ€–ç”µå½±ç©ææ€–æ¸¸æˆèº«è¾¹çš„äººåœ¨ä¹±å«ï¼Œè€Œä½ å› ä¸ºç”»é¢å¤ªå¿«å¤ªæš—è§‚å¯ŸåŠ›ä¸æ•é”åå°„å¼§å¤ªé•¿ç­‰é”™è¿‡äº†æƒŠå“ç‚¹çš„äººï¼Œé‚£è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆæ¯«æ— ä¹è¶£ï¼Œä½†æœ‰å‚¬çœ ä»·å€¼ã€‚ | When it comes to the liminality phenomenon there are two major genres on Steam: the backrooms and those games with anomalies. [i]Exit 8[/i] belongs to the latter.

These software feature a relatively small playable area and our job is to simply pass it. We can find games taking place in hotel corridors, an office area, a small street or - as it is in this case - an underground passage.

The concept is always the same: go through the area but only in case you haven't found anything unusual. The first couple of times we go through it are considered the tutorial: we have the opportunity to carefully observe everything in our path. There are lamps, posters on the walls, doors, an expatriate walking towards us and even the painting on the floor is important. Not to mention the cameras and the signs.

In case we notice anything odd compared to the original state, we immediately need to turn back. Overall, we need to pass the underground passage 8 times (as in the title) but the final session must be without anomalies as we need to reach the staircase leading up to the surface.

There are over 30 anomalies and following our first completion the game puts up a sign with the number. As we find new anomalies this will decrease. The 2nd achievement is tied to finding everything. Now, finding means actually noticing the anomaly and turning back. 

But what if we make a mistake? That we go through the passage where an anomaly is present? Then we start from the beginning. Just before entering the long corridor, a huge sign shows what level we are on and should we make a mistake we are back to zero. In certain cases failure to react in time can result in death. If you see something fast coming towards you, I suggest you immediately turn back and run.

Due to the concept of liminality (that we are against such supernatural phenomena alone) this can be considered a horror game and some anomalies further justify this. In general, I find these games quite the niche on Steam and the only problem I have with them is that they are short. Really fun game at first, and it has a lot of potential. Unfortunately you are very strongly incentivized to NOT UNLOCK ANYTHING (i.e. the meta-progression).... because after you unlock many additional items and get to the higher difficulties, the vast majority of runs become impossible since there are way, way too many items in the pool and way, way too few rerolls (and no ban feature for some reason), so you end up with random unrelated crap almost every run and auto-lose because of it, as strong synergies are mandatory to win on the higher difficulties. It feels really bad having to fish RNG over and over again just to get a run that's actually winnable. They could easily fix this with many solutions, like: stronger reroll tag affinities, more choices per round, item bans, 10x the amount of rerolls, builds/profiles with more limited pools, map-specific limited pools, etc. etc.  If they fix this massive roadblock then this game has the potential to be a amazingly fun. | ĞŸÑ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ¹, Ğ°Ğ»Ğµ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»Ñ– Ğ²ĞµÑĞµĞ»Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ñ–Ğ½Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»-Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº, Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾ Ğ¶ Â«Ğ°Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ½ĞºĞµÑ€Â». ĞšĞ»Ğ°ÑĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ñ„Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚ Ğ¿Ñ–Ğ´ Steam Deck, Ñ– Ğ²Ñ–Ğ´ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ°Ñ€ĞµÑ— Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ° Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸. | a good roguelike will have elements that influence the RNG to allow for builds to be created. This does not have that, the balls simply go where ever they want, you can hope for the best but chances are they're going to miss what you place anyways. | Ballionaire is an addictive and interesting roguelike pachinko simulator that, similar to Balatro or Luck be a Landlord, takes a well known and loved game, and gives it a randomized roguelike twist. Instead of building a deck, you place symbols on a board that are bonked by marbles as they travel through the pegs. Placement  on a 2D board allows you to control the probability of different symbols comboing in to each other in fascinating ways that a deck's blind randomness can make difficult sometimes. 

This game has a solid amount of depth for the price tag, but I found myself running out of unlockable symbols *very* quickly. Compared to a game like Slay the Spire's 10 ascension difficulties or Luck Be a Landlord's 20 floors, the 4 available difficulties feel a little light. This is slightly compensated by the randomized penalties applied by the difficulty, but with both available difficulties and unlockable symbols being a little shallow, progression feels a little one note. Lucky for this game, the gameplay is so fun and addictive, you'll go rounds long after you've conquered the final difficulty.

The game does have a rough and difficult onboarding while you learn how to combo symbols in to each other, but the game's Lab allows you to freely play with board placements and discover interactions without the gameplay mechanics, providing players an easy way of discovering, inventing, and perfecting metas without worrying about the randomness of it all. It does take learning this game with a little intent, but that intent is rewarded with incredibly satisfying success. 

Also, the game's multiple maps aren't just different arrangements of pegs- each board offers an interesting twist on the existing formulas. Each map interacts with symbol combos differently, and must be adapted to slightly differently. While portals are incredibly effective redistributing balls on the slot machine map, trying to run the same portal strategies on the ferris wheel inspired map is a recipe for disaster, just as one example.

All this with a charming art style, fun music, and fantastic game feel makes this a great pickup for that 20 minute "quick game" hole in your life.

The Good: Beautiful visuals, audio, and really fun play experience.  Rewards mastery, and the controlled randomness feels more fun to interact with than traditional deck building. 
The Bad: Harsh learning curve and somewhat shallow progression mars an otherwise very fun game to play
Verdict: Strong recommend in its current state, and a great time for anyone, but I hope future patches increase depth and add new unlocks. | Items are poorly balanced, and physics does not work as expected. The fact that I have more available unlocks than unlockable content is worrying; it seems like there was no plan for the gameplay loop. I frequently revisit this to see if there is unexplored merit, only to find the same item combinations.

While this game certainly has potential, and I can imagine it being a lot of fun in multiplayer, I would not recommend this game in its current state if you intend on playing it single player.

It seems like this game is balanced around having four people running around doing tasks because playing alone means you simply do not have time to engage with many of the mechanics. Even with just seating for 12 and with 3 of the NPC assistants, just pouring drinks and making alcohol occupies most of my time. I donâ€™t have time to grow my own crops, much less foraging/hunting, doing deliveries or any of the questlines.
The core of the game is customers will sit down at a table, and you will go up to them and take their order. You will then have to gather the necessary ingredients and prepare whatever they ordered before bringing it to them. Once they are done, they will leave their dirty dishes at the table which you will then collect and wash. On top of this you will have to sweep your tavern, fix machines when they break, refill your dishwashers with water and kick out drunk customers. This is a lot, and it does not take many customers to completely overwhelm you. 

Now the game lets you automate some of it, you can buy helpers that can preform a limited set of tasks. Cleaners will sweep for you and bring dirty dishes to the dishwasher. Then there are waiters which will take orders and deliver food and drink. While this is definitely helpful and allows you to serve more guests by yourself, you can only have 16 items on hand by default and you cannot increase this number until you are level 11 (several hours), meaning you cannot leave for very long without running out of food. These helpers are also very expensive at 1800 coins. For reference, most early game food only gives you a profit of 10-20 coins and the mid late game stuff is like 50. At level 8 you will unlock the automatic washing machine which removes the washing minigame you have to play, but that is the extent of the automation. 
If you want to do hunting, gathering or farming which is necessary to make more complex recipes that yield more money, you will need to close your tavern. However, the increase in profit does not make up for the lost sales, so you are better off just sticking to the core loop.

With just one more player you can easily have one player managing the tavern while the other gathers supplies which would massively increase your profit margins, and with even more players you would have even more options, so I can see it being a lot of fun, but in single player its really difficult to get stuff done. 

While I hope this game continues to be updated into something great, this game is supposedly a full release. However it definitely feels like early access. The upper area of your tavern is inaccessible and there is not a tone of content here. They have done a few updates, but there is no roadmap and it is unclear how much they plan to do.

 | Ale and Tavern has a cool idea with running a fantasy tavern with friends, but falls short in most areas. The best part is definitely the inn itself - hanging out with friends and pretending to be innkeepers can be a lot of fun, especially if you get into the role-playing side of things.

But man, the combat and quests are rough. Fighting feels sluggish with bad lag even when you're the host, and the weapons just feel weak and boring. There's barely any weapon choice, no real armour system, and levelling up your character feels super basic.

The quests are probably the biggest letdown - they're just boring old 'go kill X number of monsters' tasks that feel like they're from some ancient MMO. What's worse is that sometimes the monsters you need to kill don't even spawn, so you end up running around for ages looking for creatures that aren't even there.

The final boss pretty much sums up the game's problems - I just jumped on a wall where it couldn't reach me, and the whole fight was full of bugs anyway.

While running the tavern with friends can be a good time, especially if you're into role-playing, this one good feature can't make up for everything else that's wrong with the game. Right now, it feels like it needed way more work before release. Only buy this if you're really interested in the tavern part and have friends to play with - just don't expect much from the adventure side. | Ğ”Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ°Ñ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¾Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ñƒ Ğ²ĞµÑ‡ĞµÑ€Ğ¾Ğ².

I still want to like this game. It's not that it could have been so much more, it's not that the 4x and combat elements are still too disconnected. It's quite simply that the actual gameplay is not fun. 
The case study that prompted me to write this review:
I'm playing a greedy game where I'm the only civ on my relatively large continent. I pick England and build Strongholds in various strategic locations. I own the whole continent and have lots of tech and buildings but a fairly small army - just enough to strongly defend a single attack point. I begin building ships to explore the world. I finally encounter another civ, then another. The world congress begins almost immediately. One of the civs demands 2000 gold from me. I naturally refuse. They push the issue to congress. I don't have an embassy yet, so I can't do anything about that, but fine. They won't be able to break into my continent. They pillage one of my two harbors. This gives them enough warscore to enforce peace, get the 2000 gold plus another 2400 gold for war reparations. I'm in bankruptcy. I work my way out of it. They demand 2000 gold again and now I can't refuse because my people don't want war.
What is the gameplay here? Pillaging a single district is enough to instantly end a war and enforce demands strong enough to cripple the enemy until you can immediately send more demands and declare war again? The war didn't even last long enough for me to attempt to fight it. I wouldn't mind if they enforced demands after they had landed a force and begun sieging my cities or thoroughly pillaged my entire coastline, but it was one single district. Honestly most games seem to end with one stupid mistake or lucky break, which is already not that fun, but you throw mechanics like that in and it just isn't worth trying anymore. | æ…ç©ã€‚è§£å†³äº†æ–‡æ˜ç³»åˆ—çš„å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå‚è€ƒäº†æ–‡æ˜ç³»åˆ—çš„0é¡¹ä¼˜ç‚¹ã€‚ | I love this game. [h3]High Quality of Life[/h3]
The first game start was such a positive experience.Â Â 
No endless loading times, no endless publisher/developer screens.
The design of the startingÂ screenÂ is so pleasant.
The volume out of the box was set to roughly 1/3 of max volume, which was the absolute sweet spot for me.
The game and its sounds actually pause when you ALT+TAB to a different window.
The system requirements say: Stay hydrated :)

[h3]Game concept:[/h3]
The game is a puzzle-citybuilder-deckbuilderÂ mashup with a story (with the citybuilder aspect far in the background). You have 4 different types of basic blocks, which are associated with the 4 factions (government, elite, business, public). For every block you put down, which you do by playing 1 of the 3 cards you have, you gain resources for the associated faction, and you gain additional resources for building districts (4 blocks in 4 particular shapes) which are also associated with factions. 
Building 4 public blocks in a row will thereforeÂ also give you resources with the business faction. The factions require resources upkeep every 10 turns. If your resource value drops below 0 with any faction, the game is over.Â 
During the story, you get missions from the factions, which require to build your way to construction sites and to build on every block around those sites. When you manage to do that before you're game over, you get influence with this faction. Your goal is to collect so much influence with each faction that you can advance in the story.
That being said, the elements that allege it is a citybuilder are really just a matter of designation ("Districts"), because in terms of mechanics, it's just another layer of puzzle-gaming. The game lacks the depth & freedom to qualify as an actual city builder imho. 

[h3]My experience[/h3]
The start of the gameplay was a little hiccup, as the introductory explanations went off on a timer. I had to yawn during one, so I didn't get to finish reading it because the next slide was already there.Â  After that, the dialogue was connected to user input, thankfully.

The tutorial is a start, but it could be clearer in some points, especially that you have to build your path to a person you are supposed to talk to. That wasn't clear enough in the tutorial imho.

Every 5th day out of 10, an event occurs to which you get 3 different ways to react to. Your choice will either increase/decrease your amount of resources with one or more factions, or increase/decrease your upkeep. I need to criticize how this is implemented, because you are shown the symbol of one faction, and yet in most cases your decision influences more than just one faction, and often you have no idea HOW this decision will influence this faction. A few can be logically deducted, but most can't. So when you click on your option, you have to hope that it will do what you want.

A non-negligible design flaw is in my opinion, that you cannot end a run at any time, which you would want when you are at -200 upkeep but you start the 1st round after reset with less than 100 resources for 3 or 4 factions. The next time you play, you will only resume from where you left off. You have to actually play until your resources with one faction goes below 0. 

Sadly, as opposed to the trailer, the AI does not actually speak, nor does anyone else. There are no voiceovers in the game. You have to read all the dialogue, which thankfully is not a lot, but I just think it could have been nicer with actual voiceover.

The game has 37 achievements and all but one can be accomplished with moderate grind. The last one, however, is quite luck dependent though (increase criminal influence 6 times in one run). In most runs I haven't even seen a single option to influence crime, much less 6. Although luck was on my side and I got it LITERALLY in the next attempt after writing this review .

Otherwise, I can recommend the game. It was quite enjoyable, and the music was ok for 7-8 hours before I had to mute it, which is above average for me. I played through the game in 4-5 hours, and got all achievements but the luck based one in around 9-10 hours. After that it was playing for the luck based achievement which I got in a little over 14 hours. | A very pretty game with not much going on under the surface. On the plus side - it's cheap, it's quick, and the cyber-deco-noir style is really beautiful. I wish more games looked like this. On the minus side - the story is basically non-existent, the city building is simple, and the achievement design is bad. 

The gameplay consists of being dealt a small hand of three cards that represent buildings you can put down and trying to keep four factions above water points-wise by building stuff that gives them more resources, making their buildings more efficient at generating resources, and balancing events so that nobody drops below zero. Every week everything gets more expensive and eventually you'll fail. At the end you get xp with the four factions and get more stuff added to your deck of buildings. None of this is bad, it's not particularly great either. I found myself wishing I was just playing a game like [i]Reus 2[/i], which takes this same idea and does it so much better. 

It took me about two hours to finish the "story" and another two hours to get all but one achievement. The final achievement requires you to get random events that let you give influence to the fifth faction that isn't represented on the board and only comes up every so often. I get the feeling I'll be playing as long again trying to get a run where I get the choice to give this faction enough influence for the achievements as it took me to do everything else put together at least. 

My other main criticism of the game is that for as simple as it is, it explains almost nothing. What is coming next in the faction level ups, why I get certain events and not others, what exactly all the game terms mean, the game just doesn't want to let you know (you can guess a lot of it, but it's annoying to have to). The sort of advanced planning that more interesting builders take advantage of to keep you engaged isn't really possible here given how little you know about what's coming and how much of what you can do is based on what you draw and what flips as you expand the map.

It's cheap and pretty and will keep you entertained for a few hours, so if you're looking for that it's a good choice. If you're looking for anything more than that I would look elsewhere. | 100% achievement in 5 hours.  Enjoyable gameplay.  Good value for the price. | Very pleasant and great style. I really like how they weaved the story inside the game mechanics. I wish it were longer, maybe with more modes. | Very enjoyable but they should add an infinite mode after you have completed the story

[i]Umm... how many times do you think YOU can shoot your friends in the face?[/i] I mean, I could do it all day long, as long as they're willing to give it a shot with me. 
Not that Buckshot Roulette is just regular Russian roulette. First off, itâ€™s with shotguns (duh, itâ€™s in the title, I know), but above all, the fun of the game comes from the strategy and gadgets it gives you. Donâ€™t take my word for it, search for some gameplay, and youâ€™ll totally get what I mean. It's the perfect game for a LAN party, Discord party, heck, any party, as long as itâ€™s with friends.

I canâ€™t guarantee youâ€™ll still have friends after playing, but hey, play it anyway. You'll see.

And seriously... for this price? I wouldnâ€™t think twice before buying. Just do it! | This game is alot of fun with friends, can be frustrating at times, but is well developed and alot of fun.

It's decent, though it has some really questionable design decisions. The Steam comments mentioned it was too easy on easy mode which the game recommends, so I started on the second difficulty, and it has been fairly challenging. The biggest challenge has just been figuring things out though, which has not been particularly fun.
My biggest complaint is some units just feel pretty useless, straight forward tactics generally are the best option. Once you get enough resources going you can start to mix things up, but 95% of my deck will still just be melee minions. There is some tactics to the battles, but it's more around when and where you summon minions.
Got the game for like $3 though so it has been pretty good for price. I'd recommend it on sale.

EDIT: Alright, some of this game is just literally unplayable. Content that's better just to skip, worthless units, overall strange mechanics. Not worth it, I'm done. They need to revise a good amount of content. ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼ Ğ¾Ğ³Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ¿Ğ»ÑÑ, Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ´ĞµĞ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¾Ğ²ÑŒÑ, Ğ²ÑĞµ ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ»ĞµĞ½ÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğµ Ğ·Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸ÑĞ¾Ğ²ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ²Ñ‹ Ñ Ğ±Ğ¾ÑÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¸, Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¼ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğµ Ñ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ·ÑƒÑ, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»ÑÑÑ‚ ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ°, ĞºĞ°Ğº ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ„ĞµÑ‚Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ĞµÑ€ Ñ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ„Ñ„Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸, Ğ¿Ğ°ÑƒÑ‡ÑŒĞ¸ ĞºĞ¾ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‹ Ğ¸ Ñ‚.Ğ´. | å‰ä¸­æœŸçš„æ¢ç´¢å’Œæˆ˜æ–—ä½“éªŒéƒ½è›®æ–°é¢–çš„ï¼Œå¯æƒœç©åˆ°åæœŸé‡å¤åº¦ç¨å¾®æœ‰ç‚¹é«˜ã€‚æ€»ä½“æ¥è¯´æ˜¯ä¸ªæœ‰æ–°æ„çš„å°å“æ¸¸æˆã€‚ | ĞÑ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ñ€Ñ‹Ğ³Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğº, Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¾ÑÑŒ Ñ‚Ğ¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚Ğ° Ñ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ‰ÑŒÑ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ¸Ğ· Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ, Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµÑ, Ñ Ñ†ĞµĞ»ÑŒÑ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ¾Ğº Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ» ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞµ Ğ·Ğ° ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞºĞ¾Ğµ Ğ²Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ñ | I feel like this is a good strategy game with very weird choices for the meta structure of moving between fights. There is no time limit on how long you can spend just roaming around clearing fights, the enemies only get stronger. How much stronger? No clue. I have no idea how much easier or harder this game would have been had I spent more (or less time) before the final fight.

 The game is also not particularly challenging. I was able to beat all four stages of the 'balanced' difficulty (the easiest one was reccomended and the last two were locked) first try. The ability to retreat from combat, losing some of the cards in the process is nice and has saved me multiple times from forgetting to bring a card that can damage the enemy boss

I feel like there are probably some interesting pathing options on the map for getting a good deck, someting I did multiple times was to hunt down the boss that  moves the move 1 forward item and combine that with riders. But you don't need those if the game isn't hard, you can just collect everything and then build good decks when you need them.

The game also doesn't do a very good job of explaining itself, combat was initially very confusing,
and the meta structure is more confusing still. If you defeat the king, you start over with a new objective. This time you will have to help a spider queen first, new objectives and cards in new locations are added upon each clear up to the final and fourth clear. That is cool, but I do not know what happens when you die. Initally I thought that you would keep the unlocked things, but the fact that the game seems to treat it as one run (it says new run with no option to continue on the main screen now that I defeated the king a fourth time) makes me think you might start over at ascension 0, losing the run.

The rations never ran out, I think their purpose is to force you to take some combats (you can get cards just by looting graveyards as well).

Being able to adapt the deck to every single combat is an unusual design decision and I like it (for this game). It brings variety into the deck building and allows the devs to add more distinct encounters.

Run lengths are something I can say little about, my run consisting of 4 repetitions (or 1 playthrough and 3 repetitions, words mean whatever you want them to) took about 8 hours in total (had the game open for another 4 hours without playing), but I have no idea whether a more optimized run would take longer (to farm more powerful 1 time use items for strong encounters) or shorter, because you need none of that and beating the king is what matters.

I am still going to reccommend the game, as the game has taken some risks in multiple aspects of its design, overall succeeds in many and that makes for an interesting roguelike to play.

(Review given after 100% achievement, roughly 16 hours)

     A tips for better story experience but contains level spoiler : [spoiler]If you reached a level called Pillars of Creation which you starts with the motorcycle, better go find online walkthrough of it otherwise you would spend hour getting lost in a badly designed open-world map and probably lost the motivation to continue playing the game.[/spoiler]

     I liked the first game a lot and I actually think GR2 improved some stuffs. Movement tech in GR1 is still applicable and they added blocking and tons of assisting skills which seems aim towards casual players, also the boss fight is so much better and fun compare to GR1. If you are new to Ghostrunner series I think it's still worth a try. If you already played GR1 you'll see some positive about it also more problems about it.

     The Story is so John Cyberpunk you might as well just ignore it. The millennial dialogue is painfully cringe where the conversation is barely based on any character background but more like a bunch of college students trash talk each other.

     GR2 added so much things that are either not helping with the identity of Ghostrunner's gameplay or even conflicting with it.
     It has some Free Roam map with nothing worth exploring and just serve as making your objectives farther from each other, not to mention the terrible level layout that makes it notoriously bad among the community. [b]That one map does everything WRONG and there's nothing redeemable about it.[/b]
     New enemies don't feel fun to fight at all and sometimes even felt random (they did made Warden from the first game better tho)
     FPS spike occurs and bug still happens, a lot areas felt so unpolished.

     I didn't give negative review because it's a bad game, It is fun to me. But they went to a really wrong direction while developing the game. Sadly it's probably better if they remove whatever they added into GR2 and just focus on fixing the issues GR1 had and it'd be a much better game. | ä¸ªäººè§‰å¾—æ— è®ºæ˜¯è§‚æ„Ÿè¿˜æ˜¯ç©æ³•è¾ƒç¬¬ä¸€ä»£éƒ½æœ‰æå‡ è®©äººä¸èˆ’æœçš„æ˜¯ä¸€ä»£æ¸¸æˆç©å®¶å·²ç»ä¹ æƒ¯çš„ è£‚éš™å¹²æ‰° çš„é»˜è®¤é”®ä½ä»åŸæ¥çš„â€é¼ æ ‡å³é”®â€œ        æ”¹ä¸ºäº†â€Eâ€œ å°†å³é”®æ”¹ä¸ºæ ¼æŒ¡      æˆ‘æ˜¯å°†é¼ æ ‡å³é”®æ”¹å›è£‚éš™å¹²æ‰° å°†é¼ æ ‡ä¾§é”®è®¾ä¸ºæ ¼æŒ¡

ã€ŠåŒäººæˆè¡Œã€‹æ— ç–‘æ˜¯ä¸€éƒ¨ä¸å¯å¤šå¾—çš„å¥½æ¸¸æˆï¼Œå®ƒç”¨ç‹¬ç‰¹çš„æ–¹å¼è¿æ¥èµ·äººä¸äººä¹‹é—´çš„æƒ…æ„Ÿï¼Œä¸ºç©å®¶å¸¦æ¥æ— ä¸ä¼¦æ¯”çš„æ¸¸æˆä½“éªŒã€‚ | If you believe that playing games with your partner can strengthen your relationship, then It Takes Two isnâ€™t just a game â€” itâ€™s a full-blown course in couples therapy. The story is as simple as an IKEA chair manual: a couple on the verge of divorce is magically turned into dolls. To become human again, Cody and May must learn to work together. Sounds adorable until you find yourselves yelling at each other in perfect harmony.

The gameplay is a constant experiment. One level has you shooting nails and swinging on ropes, another has you steering a tiny minecart, or even fighting a talking vacuum cleaner. Yes, an evil vacuum cleaner. Probably the one I forgot to clean for years.

The visuals are bright and vibrant, as if the artists binge-read childrenâ€™s books while drawing... and maybe took a bit of, letâ€™s say, inspiration from Madagascar. The levels are so diverse that by the end of the game, you might start to suspect they tried to cram EVERY genre into one box. Youâ€™ve got platforming, racing, and even a marriage argument simulator.

But the real star of the game is Dr. Hakim, the talking relationship book. With his charisma and lines like "dance like a butterfly, love like a boss," heâ€™s clearly aiming for the title of the most annoyingly wise NPC of the decade.

It Takes Two is a game that reminds you relationships arenâ€™t just about "press a button and it works." They require teamwork, a little grease (literally and figuratively), and, of course, the ability to laugh at yourself â€” or at each other. | La verdad es un muy buen juego no por nada se llevo el GOTY, pero mejor jueguenlo con su pareja por que lo juguÃ© con un amigo y el kbron se enamoro de mi el pinche ptvo dizque para reforzar la amistad aww auxilio

Game went from online only to offline only.  Character was deleted cause I didn't think to check a less than year old game for the chance that its shutting down its servers and making the players be incharge of the character transfer. | Do not buy - it is abandoned. If you still want to play it, check the discussion for an important mod to make it better.

It has really good puzzles, some really challenging ones. But they never solved the keep the company alive puzzle. | I don't recommend this game. The idea was great, promises a great variety of puzzles, and to a certain extent it delivers. The puzzles are interesting, some of them are very challenging. And the open world feels great to roam around and progress.

I'm not as bothered by the fact if it's offline or online. But I was pretty sad to see no support to the game after release. I would've loved to see new content come in, new types of puzzles, new areas, etc. The game had dailies and skins so it kinda feels like it could've been a "live service" game.

Unfortunately, it feels lika a quick cash grab from the hype around games like The Talos Principle. Definitely not worth the full price. If you manage to get it for the price of a cup of coffee, go for it. It will occupy your attention for a couple of hours for sure.

Oh and lets not forget, when they made the switch from Online only to Offline only, they didn't migrate the saves. So my progress is gone. | [b]I have only played this in offline mode, but I must say that is is still one of the best puzzle experiences out there.[/b]

Positives:
- There are so many different puzzles. The smaller islands that introduce the mechanics are have well designed tutorial sections and manageable challenges.
- The difficult end game content feels very rewarding to solve. It tests you on absolutely everything you have learned and seen on the island.
- Just on a walk from one waypoint to the next, you can easily get distracted by random puzzles on your way, often dozens of times in a few minutes. These random puzzles don't contribute to the game's main progress, but it is still incredibly fun when you can solve 30 different puzzles back to back when each takes at most 30 seconds. I sometimes go back to the game for just that when I want to turn off my brain for half an hour.

Neutral:
- The RPG and upgrade system is a weird mix of making puzzles easier and rewarding you for being good at puzzles. I think instead of that they should have just built in adjustable difficulty for more or less hints.
- Difficulty ratings are only present on puzzle boxes. It's about a 50/50 if you can agree with the rating. Other puzzles don't have visible ratings, which is unfortunate.

Negatives:
- They used the Unreal Engine physics for movement based puzzles and parkour challenges. These are also by far the least fun puzzle types in the game. | This game was fantastic. Then they removed online play, and stopped updating it despite poor optimisation and performance. This probably lies more with the publishers than the devs, so i hope they don't get too much kickback from this if that was the case. The game itself is very pretty, and the puzzles range from relaxing to genuinely challenging. There's a nice variety to them too, from sliding puzzles and glass mazes, to simple "view from the right angle and perspective". 
I'd like to see more from this dev in the long run, but less from the publisher. Considering I found this game through Steam Discovery Queue and not once have i seen advertising for it to any degree, I'd hope the devs learn that they didn't actually need a publisher for this.

Intravenous 2 improves on this first game in all ways

You can you stealth, you can go loud both are fun !
Story is a bit cringy but is very secondary

Achievements are fun to do | I've just completed the story on the "True" difficulty, and I must say this game is an exhilarating and brutal experience. Throughout, I altered my play style from level to level, either being quiet as a mouse or unleashing fire and brimstone; the versatile options and tactical nature of the gameplay are an immediate hit with me. The story is straightforward and interesting, though I feel as if the dialogue was written too simply. Looking forward to playing the second game soon!

8/10 | This isn't a terrible game, but it's sort of the difficulty of hotline miami but with espionage elements. 
You can go in guns blazing, but the game really punishes you for it. This is meant to be played stealth for the first part of missions, then fight your way out essentially. 
I am curious if two is better, but i can say that if i had to compare other espionage, stealth action games, it lacks the true stealth of metal gear solid, it lacks the gunplay of rainbow 6 or tom clancy, it lacks the visuals of any of them, it lacks the story of any of them, its all about the gameplay and the gameplay is... ok. 

This isn't a bad game, and me not recommending it doesn't mean i don't recommend the developer or anything else they produce, but this is more of a "buy it on sale and don't expect too much" purchase. | This writing is so poor I couldn't continue playing.  It's like a pool of profanity, and there aren't any pool noodles or floaties in this pool.  The gameplay is underwhelming in a way that can't be guessed by viewing the screenshots.  It felt like even the settings menu was iffy, as I'm weird and wanted the music to be muted, and there was no way to lower the scale of the music with a controller.  There was not a good narrative nor good gameplay.  There was much written curse words (written because there is no recorded speech), and a buggy menu.  Skip this and go to McDonalds and get a Big Mac and you'll have created a better story.
